name: Billionaires
bio: One of America's youngest billionaires, Scott Duncan inherited a stake in his late father Dan Duncan's Enterprise Products Partners in 2010, alongside his three siblings. The company owns natural gas processing plants, oil and gas storage facilities and 49,000 miles of pipelines. Scott's sister Randa Duncan Williams, who serves as non-executive chairman of the board, is the only sibling actively involved in the business. Along with Randa, Scott's other two other siblings, Dannine Avara and Milane Frantz, are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Milane Frantz is one of four siblings who inherited a stake in her father Dan Duncan's energy pipeline empire after his death in 2010. The Houston-based company, Enterprise Products Partners, owns nearly 49,000 miles of pipelines and the largest oil storage facility on the Gulf Coast. Her three siblings are billionaires as well, but only sister Randa Duncan Williams is on the board of Enterprise. Frantz, meanwhile, is a board member of Houston's Hermann Park Conservancy and Baylor College of Medicine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gong Hongjia is the vice chairman and largest individual shareholder of video surveillance maker Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technologies. The company has been working to expand in North America and donating to charity to build goodwill. Hikvision opened a branch office in Canada in 2015. Gong Hongjia once dreamed of becoming a reporter or lawyer. Instead he ended up going to Huazhong University of Science and Technology, which led to his much more lucrative move into technology. His advice to those looking for success: Do what other people don't want to do and don't dare to do.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Yonghao handed over the chairmanship of listed China agribusiness giant New Hope Liuhe to his daughter Liu Chang in 2013, but he is still involved in the business. New Hope Group teamed up with developer VIC Investment Management Group of Australia to pay $110 million for land in New South Wales; the two parties will invest up to $440 million to build residences and offices. In July 2015, New Hope Group unveiled a dairy joint venture with Australia's Moxey family, Perich Group and Freedom Foods Group. Liu also has interests in real estate and chemicals.

name: Billionaires
bio: George Roberts is one of two billionaires running publicly traded private equity firm KKR, the other is his cousin Henry Kravis. Together, they founded KKR in 1976 with Bear Sterns colleague Jerome Kohlberg. They were private equity pioneers who sometimes pursued hostile takeovers that characterized the high finance of the 1980s. Kohlberg left KKR in 1987. Roberts and Kravis went on to earn one of Wall Street's enduring epithets--the titular "Barbarians at the Gate," the now classic b-school tale of private equity pursuing and sacking Nabisco. Outside of private equity, Roberts runs a San Francisco venture philanthropy nonprofit, supporting 50 social enterprises that employ 9,000 people and generate more than $140 million in revenues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mark Scheinberg made a fortune off of online poker. With his father, Isai Scheinberg, he built PokerStars into the world's biggest online poker company. Founded in 2001, the company first operated out of Costa Rica, but eventually moved to the Isle of Man. PokerStars' parent, Rational Group, which also owned Full Tilt Poker, was sold for $4.9 billion in 2014 to Amaya, a publicly-traded Montreal company, in a deal that was backed by Blackstone's GSO credit division. Scheinberg was the biggest single shareholder of Rational Group. Born in Israel, Scheinberg moved to a suburb of Toronto at age 13. He left college after one year, worked in the hospitality industry and traveled for long stretches to Asia and South America, before getting into the online gambling business at age 28. PokerStars became revered by players for hosting massive tournaments. The company benefited tremendously from the poker boom that swept the U.S. and the rest of world starting in 2003 after an unknown Tennessee accountant named Chris Moneymaker became a famous millionaire by winning the World Series of Poker's Main Event. Moneymaker got his seat at the World Series of Poker by winning an online PokerStars play-in.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a dentist, Reinhold Schmieding passed up medical school to start Arthrex, which specializes in making products for minimally invasive arthroscopic surgeries. The Michigan State-educated Schmieding got his start at the German subsidiary of medical devices firm Richards Medical. There, he became interested in developing procedures and tools for orthopedic surgeries. He bought a $50 drafting table and began sketching tools at night. Over the years, his Naples, Florida-based company has developed 8,500 products used in shoulder, knee and other joint operations, including devices like sutures to reattach injured Achilles tendons and specialized knives used to shave off human bone. Schmieding owns an estimated 95% of the privately held company and still actively participates in developing new patents.

name: Billionaires
bio: The eldest of the four Duncan siblings, Randa Duncan Williams is the only one actively involved in running Enterprise Products Partners. The company, founded by her late father Dan Duncan (d. 2010), owns 49,000 miles of energy pipelines, as well as natural gas processing plants and storage facilities. A former lawyer, Williams was elected as the company's non-executive chairman in 2013. The Rice alumna also serves on her alma mater's board of trustees. She is actively involved in the University of Texas Health Science Center's Children's Learning Institute, which has a clinic named after her father.
title: Non-Executive Chairman of the Board
employment: {'name': 'Enterprise GP Holdings', 'title': 'Non-Executive Chairman of the Board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With little more than a high school education, the young Korean couple came to the U.S. in 1981 in search for a better life. Husband Do Won, just 22 at the time, worked the morning shift at a coffee shop, pumped gas during the afternoon and started a small office cleaning business that kept him busy until midnight. Jin Sook, 25, toiled as a hairdresser, a skill she acquired back in her home country. While at the gas station, Do Won noticed that wealthy men in the garment industry drove the nicest cars, inspiring him to take a job at a clothing store, where he was determined to learn the ropes. "I treated it like it was my own business," he told FORBES. After three years in the U.S., the couple pooled $11,000 in savings and opened a 900-square-foot apparel store in L.A. in 1984. Calling it Fashion 21, first year sales reached $700,000. It eventually became fast-fashion juggernaut Forever 21, which has $4.4 billion in revenue from 790 locations in 48 countries. But after years of expansion the company appears to be facing some setbacks; sales have been flat and in the past year it's reportedly paid some vendors late. Forever 21 denies any financial difficulties and says business remains solid. The devout couple, who goes to early morning prayer at a local church nearly everyday, has the Bible verse John 3:16 printed on the bottom of the chain's shopping bags.

name: Billionaires
bio: James Dyson, the eponymous inventor of the bagless vacuum, credits his firm's continuing success to its R&D focus. It employs 650 engineers and scientists at its large research center in southwest England and has more than 560 patents.  The $2 billion (sales) company increased R&D spending by 40% to $160 million  in 2014, the last year available. Dyson himself is a tinkerer. He went through 5,127 prototypes before perfecting the G-Force, the upright vacuum powered by centrifugal force that made him famous. It was introduced in England in 1993. A rare setback came for Dyson in 2015, when the European Court of Justice threw out a case brought by the company alleging that the vacuum cleaner industry needed more regulation because it allowed rivals to "cheat like Volkswagen" by securing misleadingly strong ratings. Outside of his Dyson ownership, the entrepreneur now also owns 25,000 acres throughout the U.K.

name: Billionaires
bio: Han Chang-Woo is chairman and CEO of Maruhan, Japan's largest pachinko parlor operator. The privately-held company also runs bowling alleys, golf driving ranges and movie theaters. Han, a Korean-Japanese businessman, also continues to invest in his homeland, Korea. His latest project is Dream Island, a $2 billion entertainment hub including hotels, shopping malls, and golf courses to be built on reclaimed land on Korea's Yeongjong Island.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bertil Hult dropped out of college after just a year to start a business in his dormitory's basement, organizing summer trips to help Swedish students learn English in the UK during their holiday break. Today his company, EF Education First, offers cultural exchanges, educational travel, language training and degree programs in 53 countries. It was the official supplier of language training for several Olympic games, and will be it again for Rio De Janeiro 2016. It expects to help teach English to 1 million Brazilians. Hult has passed the reins of EF to his three oldest sons. A dyslexic, he donates money to a Swedish school that focuses on innovative approaches to educating children with the learning disability, and he is a trustee of the Mentor Foundation which works to prevent substance abuse. He is also the benefactor of the Hult Prize, a partnership with President Clinton which awards $1 million USD in seed funding to the winners of a student competition focused on launching a social business that solves specific challenges like food security, water quality and access, and early childhood education in the urban slums.

name: Billionaires
bio: Movie directors have used James Jannard's RED Digital Cameras to shoot films, including Avatar, The Martian and Straight Outta Compton. A year ago Jannard said RED would move into augmented and virtual reality, but so far that hasn't happened. "Changing the world does take time," he says. His RED has already come a long way from being called a 'scam' when it was founded more than a decade ago. He was already a successful entrepreneur by that point, having founded Oakley in 1975 as a retailer for motorcycle and BMX bike accessories. It eventually became a hugely popular sunglass brand, which Jannard took public in 1995 and sold to Luxottica for $2.1 billion in 2007, just two years after founding RED. He stepped down as RED's CEO in 2013 and now serves as chairman. A University of Southern California dropout, he opened a resort on a Fijian Island in 2015.

name: Billionaires
bio: Record sales of the iconic Royal Enfield motorbike kept shares of Indian two-wheeler tycoon Vikram Lal's Eicher Motors aloft. The company reported its highest ever revenues of $309 million in a recent quarter. After launching its much-anticipated Himalayan adventure bike last year, it has begun selling it in Australia and Colombia. Royal Enfield opened its first U.S. store in Milwaukee in 2016, the home of rival Harley-Davidson, followed by its first Australian store in Melbourne. Son Siddhartha, who runs Eicher, is overseeing the company's global expansion from London. Last year, the family sold 4.2% of its stake in Eicher, but it still retains close to 51%. Vikram's father Man Mohan Lal founded a tractor shop called Goodearth Co. in 1948; a decade later he partnered with German firm Eicher, renaming the business Eicher Tractor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nancy Walton Laurie's fortune stems from the stake she inherited in retail behemoth Wal-Mart. Her father, Bud Walton, cofounded the company with his older brother, Sam, in 1962. When Bud died in 1995, Nancy and her sister, Ann Walton Kroenke, inherited enough Wal-Mart shares to make them both billionaires. She and her husband, Bill Laurie, also own Missouri's Providence Bank, several homes and a yacht. In 1998, Nancy founded Columbia Performing Arts Centre, a performing arts school for children through high schoolers in Columbia, Missouri. She remains actively involved, overseeing curriculum and regularly attending performances. Nancy and Bill purchased the NHL's St. Louis Blues in 1999. They sold the hockey team six years later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iskander Makhmudov is the main owner of copper producer Urals Mining and Metals Company (UMMC, also known as UGMK), which has controlling stakes in more than 300 companies in nine regions of Russia. He is also a shareholder in Transmashholding, Russia's largest maker of locomotives and rail equipment. Born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan, he lived in Tashkent and graduated from a local university with a degree in oriental studies. In 2009, Spanish authorities named him in a money laundering case, which they handed over to the Russian attorney general's office for further investigation. In March 2012, the case, which also implicates billionaire Oleg Deripaska, was sent to the investigative department of the ministry of internal affairs. The investigation remains open, but no findings have been announced.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fracking billionaire Terry Pegula has turned his attention to the sports world, where he owns the NFL's Buffalo Bills and the NHL's Buffalo Sabres. He picked up the Bills for $1.4 billion in September 2014, outbidding groups led by Donald Trump and Bon Jovi. This came four years after he made his first big move into sports when he bought the Sabres for $189 million after unloading much of his oil and gas holdings. His East Resources sold the bulk of its assets to Royal Dutch Shell for $4.7 billion in 2010 and then sold an additional 76,000 acres of land and assets to American Energy Partners for $1.75 billion in June 2014. Pegula still retains oil and gas interests in places like Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Colorado. He and his wife, Kim, are also behind HarborCenter, a $172-million development in downtown Buffalo that features two ice rinks, a hotel and a restaurant. A former math major, Pegula switched to petroleum engineering on a scholarship and joined Getty Oil after graduation before founding East Resources in 1983 with a $7,500 loan from friends and family to drill sand wells. His daughter, Jessica Pegula, is a professional tennis player.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Property developer Jerry Speyer has developed landmarks like Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building in Manhattan, as well as skyscrapers in Berlin, London, Frankfurt, Paris and Sao Paolo. Jerry is the chairman and his son Rob is now CEO. (They previously held co-CEO titles). The company is now betting heavily on China. Its flagship project there is The Springs, a 66-acre mixed-use complex outside of Shanghai, where Nike is one of the office tenants. The company has invested $11 billion in equity funds. But Tishman Speyer hasn't been without failures. One forgettable project was their disastrous $5.4 billion acquisition of New York's 80-acre Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village in 2006, later the biggest mortgage default in U.S. history. Speyer started the firm with his late father-in-law, Robert Tishman, in 1978. Marriage ended in divorce, but Tishman Speyer survived. Speyer is chairman of the Museum of Modern Art and vice chairman of New York Presbyterian Hospital. His wife Katherine chairs the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and oversees Tishman Speyer's China and Brazil business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonard Stern owns more than 37 million square feet of property in northern New Jersey and New York, as well as One Superior Place, a luxury tower in downtown Chicago. His Harmon Mountain company has sold most of a major New Jersey shopping center in the past two years. An active philanthropist for Jewish causes, Stern backed the first comprehensive poll of anti-semitism that surveyed over 50,000 adults in 102 countries and territories, published in April 2014. Three years earlier, he helped publish a book, A Convenient Hatred: The History of Anti-Semitism. He also has given over $30 million to his alma mater, New York University, which named its business school after him. Stern joined his family's Hartz Mountain Pet Products in 1959, but began buying land and eventually sold the pet business for $350 million in 2000.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lucio Tan's LT Group has interests in banking, property development, beverages, spirits and tobacco. In 2014 Tan retained 100% control of Philippines Airlines, the country's oldest airline. Tan, who mopped floors to pay for school, got his business start as a chemical engineer. He enjoys flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israel's richest woman, Shari Arison inherited the basis of her fortune from her father Ted, who founded cruise ship line Carnival Corp. It remains her largest asset. She also holds stakes in Israel's Bank Hapoalim and infrastructure firm Shikun & Binui Holdings. She controls her investments and philanthropy through the Arison Group and the Ted Arison Family Foundation, which each year contributes to nonprofits involved in health, education, disabilities and research. The Tel-Aviv resident has tried to position herself as a force for good in business by investing in a number of green projects, including a desalination plant, a green shopping mall in Israel and a $100 million venture dedicated to maximizing the efficiency of large urban water systems. She also launched International Good Deeds Day to advocate community service, creating a website and network called Goodnet.org that she says has connected some 6 million people around the world. In 2015, she released her fourth book, "The Doing Good Model."
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: A former military man-turned-financial whiz, Leonid Fedun met Vagit Alekperov in the late 1980s while teaching in the Siberian city of Kogalym. At the time, Alekperov headed the local oil and gas company. In the 1990s Fedun helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed from top Russian oil properties. Alekperov now heads Lukoil, and Fedun works as his right hand man. Fedun owns a nearly 10% stake in the company, which was hit with U.S. sanctions in 2014. He also oversees the investing activities of diversified holding company IFD Kapital. Fedun built a $500 million stadium for his Moscow soccer team, Spartak, in 2014. It will apparently host some World Cup matches in 2018.

name: Billionaires
bio: The bulk of Frits Goldschmeding's fortune comes from his estimated 35% stake in staffing company Randstad Holding. He founded the business in 1960 and called it Uitzendbureau Amstelveen, then changed the name to Randstad four years later. Within a decade his company had 32 offices in four countries, including Belgium, Germany and the U.K. He took Randstad public in 1990, then merged it with Dutch group Vedior in 2008. Now retired, Goldschmeding is a professor at the Centre for Entrepreneurship of the Nyenrode Business Universit, and he enjoys sailing in his free time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martha Ingram took over as chairman of her family's distribution conglomerate, Ingram Industries, in 1995 after her husband's death. She spun-off the computer distribution unit into publicly traded Ingram Micro in 1996, then led Ingram Industries until 2008. Sons Orrin and John now steer it. One part of the business, Ingram Content, provides physical, on-demand printing and digital services to big players in the books and publishing industry, like Amazon.com, Barnes and Noble, O'Reilly Media, Taschen, Kaplan University and Random House. Ingram Marine operates 5,000 barges and more than 140 towboats on America's inland waterways. Another son, David, runs the separate Ingram Entertainment. Ingram sits on the boards of various cultural institutions in Nashville, Tennessee.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Rupert Johnson Jr. is vice chairman of Franklin Resources, the parent company of mutual fund giant Franklin Templeton. His father, Rupert Sr., founded the mutual fund shop as Franklin Distributors in 1947 and the business has stayed in the family ever since. Rupert Jr. joined in the 1960s and his billionaire half-brother, Charles, ran the company for 56 years before stepping down as chairman in 2013. Assets under management have increased from $2.5 million when Charles took over to more than $750 billion today. His nephew, Gregory, now runs the company as chairman and CEO. Rupert's foundation donates to educational programs, schools and academic institutes. He pledged $100 million to the Washington and Lee University in 2007, $85 million of which has been designated for scholarships.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Edwin Leong is the sixth son of Henry G. Leong, a comprador of British trading house Jardine Matheson. Just nine years old when his father died, Edwin went on to build a fortune of his own. His investment firm, Tai Hung Fai Enterprise, specializes in residential, commercial and industrial properties. His foreign partners include Oakwood, an apartment rental company in Los Angeles, Thailand-based Onyx Hospitality and Inter-Continental Hotels. His Tai Hung Fai Charitable Foundation focuses on ways to help needy children and the elderly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mary Alice Dorrance Malone is the largest shareholder of Campbell Soup Co., which her grandfather John T. Dorrance transformed into a global food giant with his condensed soup formula in 1897. She holds a 17.2% stake and has served on the board since 1990. Her brother, Bennett Dorrance and cousin Charlotte Colket Weber are both fellow billionaires. Campbell has some $8 billion in annual revenue and owns brands including Pepperidge Farm, Prego and V8. Malone is the president of Iron Spring Farms, a horse breeding and performance center west of Philadelphia.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Sall founded business analytics software firm SAS in 1976 with partner James Goodnight, whom he met at North Carolina State University. SAS was originally developed to analyze agricultural data. With its analytics software in use in over 75,000 companies around the world, SAS revenue in 2015 was $3.16 billion. A history major at Beloit College in Wisconsin, Sall saw a weak job market in front of him upon graduation and opted for graduate work in economics and statistics, which led him to earn a masters in statistics from N.C. State. His interest in history continues; he sits on the advisory board of Smithsonian Institute's National Museum of Natural History. Sall owns a one-third stake in SAS. The company is known for employee-friendly programs that include sports leagues, day care and on-site dry cleaning. Sall and Goodnight also own a country club and a hotel, and founded private college prep school Cary Academy.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former eBay executive Jeff Skoll has spent the past decade as a philanthropist and film producer, using his wealth to try to improve the state of the world. In April 2015 he took on the interim CEO role at his issues-focused film company, Participant Media, after the departure of CEO Jim Berk. Participant brought on a new CEO, David Linde, in October 2015. Skoll started cable channel Pivot TV, which is aimed at millenials, in 2013 and has reportedly put $200 million into the effort. He made his fortune as the first employee of eBay. He left there in 2001 and started the Skoll Foundation, which backs promising social entrepreneurs working to improve education, health care, and access to jobs in some of the poorest parts of the globe. He launched Participant Media in 2004; it has since co-produced more than 60 films aimed at inspiring social change, including "The Help'', "The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel" and the documentary Citizenfour about Edward Snowden, which won an Academy Award for best feature documentary in 2015. Skoll was born in Montreal, later moved to Toronto and pumped gas to pay his way through the University of Toronto. He obtained U.S. citizenship in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a bricklayer and a homemaker in Brooklyn, Sheldon Solow was a small-time builder when he risked everything to build a single Manhattan high-rise in 1972. Today, that tower at 9 W. 57 St., famous for its unobstructed view of Central Park, is home to KKR, Apollo Global Management, Tiger Global Management, and Chanel. As the real estate market has soared, so has Solow's fortune. But it is his art collection that gotten more attention lately. In May 2015, Solow sold his Giacometti sculpture "The Pointing Man" at Christie's for $141 million, shattering the record for the most expensive sculpture ever sold at auction. Solow also has many more pieces, including works by Boticelli, Balthus, Matisse, and Kline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhou Jianping sits atop apparel manufacturer and retailer Heilan Home. Though e-commerce gets the headlines in China, Heilan has continued to put money into bricks-and-mortar venues, adding new stores in 2015, bringing its total to more than 3,380 stores. Zhou, Heilan's chairman, got into the apparel business by contracting out manufacturing to a collective-owned textile factory in Jiangsu Province using money he earned from running a photo studio. The company now trades on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Zhou runs an equestrian club near the company's headquarters that puts on colorful shows every Saturday.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heinz-Georg Baus is founder of the German home-improvement chain Bauhaus AG. A carpenter by trade, he opened his first store in a former carpentry workshop belonging to his parents in Mannheim, Germany, in 1960. He saw a niche in the trend towards do-it-yourself construction and home improvement that had already gotten underway in the U.S. Baus relocated Bauhaus headquarters to Zug, Switzerland in the late 1960s and expanded the company's reach into Austria in 1972. Today, the private, family-owned company has more than 260 stores and 23,000 employees in 19 European countries, with Germany accounting for more than half of its roughly $6 billion in annual revenue. With the acquisition of 24 stores from insolvent Praktiker (Max Bahr), Bauhaus added an estimated $700 million in annual sales. Baus is married and lives in Monaco. His only son, Bernd, serves as a managing director at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Denise Coates' fortune jumped over the past year as her online gambling firm, Bet365, saw net profits soar. Coates, who owns around half of the privately held company, is co-CEO with her billionaire brother, John. Coates started out working for her father, crunching numbers in his betting shops while still in school. She then trained as an accountant and took over some of those shops, turning around their fortunes before selling them to large bookmaker Coral. Noting the success of online gambling businesses, Coates bought the domain Bet365.com in 2000 and launched the website in 2001. Bet365 is now one of the world's largest online gambling companies, with $51.6 billion in bets placed in the year through March 2015. The company also owns a majority stake in the Stoke City Football Club. In 2015, Bet365 moved its headquarters to Gibraltar because of its favorable regulations.
title: Founder and Joint CEO
