name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Skorobogatko and his billionaire partner, Alexander Ponomarenko, have been moving from sea ports and banking into airport construction. In 2013 the partners, together with Arkady Rotenberg, President Vladimir Putin's judo partner, won a tender to develop part of Sheremetyevo, the state-owned airport outside Moscow. The project includes a new terminal for 15 million passengers, a building that will hold 500,000 tons of cargo, a refueling complex and a tunnel connecting the airport's southern and northern complexes. The partners have already invested $1 billion in the project. In August 2015 Putin consolidated the airport's assets, giving the three billionaires a 70% stake. Skorobogatko and Ponomarenko got their start after the 1998 financial crisis, when they began buying up shares in cargo companies and combined them to form  Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port. It went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 they sold 20% of their holdings to Rotenberg. In 2011, the two original partners made $1 billion when they sold a stake in the port to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital. Skorobogatko has served as an elected deputy in the State Duma since 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: After 28 years at the helm, Helmut Sohmen retired in 2014 as chairman of the family's BW Group and listed BW Offshore. Though BW Pacific, one of BW Group's subsidiaries, was expected to go for IPO in November 2015, the company pulled the offering. Sohmen's Oxford and Harvard-educated eldest son, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, replaced him in November as the head of one of the world's largest maritime firms. Married to the daughter of late shipping tycoon Pao Yue-Kong, the Austrian citizen has lived in Hong Kong for more than 30 years. A Southern Methodist University law school alumnus, he supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at SMU's Dedman School of Law.

name: Billionaires
bio: Song Zuowen's privately-held Nanshan Group has interests in aluminum, apparel, education, tourism and a regional airline. It listed its main aluminum company, Shandong Nanshan Aluminum, on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 1999. Nanshan Group is the majority investor in startup Qingdao Airlines, which launched in April 2014. It has flights from Qingdao to Chengdu, Beijing and several other cities. Song is the airline's president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pat Stryker's grandfather Homer Stryker (d: 1980) was an orthopedic surgeon who invented and patented medical devices and later founded Stryker Corporation, which had $9.9 billion in sales last year. Born in Michigan, she now lives in Fort Collins, Colo., and is the owner of Bohemian Companies, a group that includes venture capital activities, real estate development, restaurants, and a winery in Sonoma County, California. Her private Bohemian Foundation supports youth and community programs. Her siblings Ronda and Jon are also on the list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tang Yiu founded footwear and sportswear retailer Belle International in 1982. Top brands include Teenmix and Staccato. The company went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2007. Despite slowing growth he added 1,380 stores last year, bringing the total to almost 21,000, mostly on the mainland. He says pace of expansion will slow because of the slower Chinese economy. Tang chairs The Federation of Hong Kong Footwear and is the honorary president of the Sam Shui Natives Association. Son Tang King Loy is a director and senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tse Ping, a member of the billionaire Dhanin clan from Thailand, surprised investors in June 2015 when he stepped down as chairman of Hong Kong-listed pharmaceutical maker Sino Biopharmaceutical. He ceded the role to his 22-year-old daughter Theresa, who has an undergraduate degree in economics from the Wharton School. Tse stayed on as an executive director. Tse owns nearly 41% of Sino Biopharmaceutical.

name: Billionaires
bio: Private equity investor Bulat Utemuratov continues to focus on his banking endeavors to temper declines in his Russia real estate investments, including his Moscow Ritz Carlton. His asset management company, Verniy Capital, is building Talan Towers, a $350 million complex in the Kazakh capital of Astana and planning a new Ritz in Astana for 2017. Utemuratov made his first windfall in 2007 when he sold his ATF Bank to Italian bank UniCredit for $2.1 billion (for 91.8% of the bank); and then again in 2013 when he sold his mining assets to Glencore Xstrata and the Kazakh sovereign wealth fund. He is an avid tennis player who heads the Kazakh Tennis Federation and has donated millions to update the country's tennis facilities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yeoh Tiong Lay's net worth slumped last year as revenue at his 60-year-old YTL Corp. dropped 13% to $4.2 billion last year. Lower fuel prices hurt its utilities business. It also runs hotel and property-development businesses and boasts a 2,000-acre land bank in Malaysia. It owns PowerSeraya, Singapore's second-largest power plant, and  co-owns the Eastern & Oriental Express, the luxury train that runs from Singapore to Thailand. And it owns the Ritz-Carlton in Kuala Lumpur. In 2013 he donated $11 million to King's College London to set up the Yeoh Tiong Lay Centre for Politics, Philosophy & Law. All of his children are involved in the business. His eldest son, Francis, is at the helm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhou Yahui is chairman of Beijing Kunlun Tech, one of China's  biggest web game developers and operators.  The company paid a reported $93 million in January 2016 for 60% of Grindr, the largest all-male mobile social network in the world with over 2 million daily users in 196 countries. Kunlun, which went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2015, invested $34 million in UK lending service LendInvest in June 2015 and is also a Chinese partner of Rovio Entertainment of Finland, the company behind the online game Angry Birds. Zhou founded Kunlun as a web game distributor in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saif Al Ghurair is the former chairman of family holding company Al Ghurair Group. He and his brother Abdulla, also a billionaire, are scions of an old Dubai merchant family that originally harvested pearls from the Arabian Gulf. A stormy boat trip to India in the 1930s to sell dates left him blind in one eye. Saif's six sons hold positions in the group, which has interests in banking, steel, and packaging. His son Abdulrahman is chairman and son Majid is chief executive. Saif is also a major shareholder in Mashreq Bank, a leading Emirati bank run by his nephew, Abdul Aziz Al Ghurair.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Arrillaga built a fortune in Silicon Valley real estate. After graduating from Stanford, which he attended thanks to a basketball scholarship, Arrillaga partnered with Richard "Dick" Peery, buying farmland in Silicon Valley in the 1960s and turning it into office parks. Their Peery-Arrillaga firm sold about half its commercial real estate portfolio in 2006 for $1.1 billion. Current tenants include Google. In 2013 Stanford announced that Arrillaga was giving the university $151 million, its largest gift from a living donor. Arrillaga's name adorns several buildings on the Stanford University campus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Semahat Sevim Arsel is a member of the board of directors of Koc Holding, the family conglomerate. She manages the group's tourism investments including Setur Tourism and Divan Hotels. She suffered from an extended childhood illness, which motivated her to support nursing education and research. She is the president and founder of the 22-year-old Semahat Arsel Nursing Education & Research Center (SANERC), the vice president of the Florence Nightingale Foundation and the founder of the Koc University Nursing Academy. Her sister Suna Kirac, brother Mustafa Rahmi Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Benson started out as a bookkeeper at a Chevrolet dealership in New Orleans before funneling his earnings into auto dealerships, local banks and, eventually, sports teams. He bought the Saints (NFL) in 1985 and picked up the Pelicans (NBA) in 2012. In New Orleans Benson also owns a 26-story office building that's named for him and Champions Square, an outdoor entertainment venue next to the Superdome arena where the Saints play. Benson spent the past few years locked in a bitter dispute over control of much of his fortune. He had been planning on leaving his teams to his daughter and two grandchildren, but in January 2015 decided instead to leave them to Gayle, his wife of 10 years. His daughter and grandchildren sued, at one point claiming Benson was no longer competent to run the teams. In June 2015 a judge declared Benson competent. But when he tried to exchange team stock held by trusts for some $500 million in promissory notes and forgiven debt, his (potential) heirs moved to reject the deal. The parties reached a confidential settlement, ending all litigation, in February 2017.

name: Billionaires
bio: When Ernst Blickle took over SEW-Eurodrive in 1945, it was a small manufacturing company. "SEW" stood for Sueddeutsche-Elektromotoren-Werke (Factory Motors South of Germany). Sons Jurgen and Rainer took the reins some 40 years later, transforming the business into an industrial powerhouse specializing in drive-automation and power-transmission solutions. Its motor, gear and electronic components are used to power conveyors, lifts and other applications in contexts ranging from auto assembly, offshore oil production and lumber processing to airport baggage handling, mineral extraction and large-scale commercial baking. Worldwide, the company employs more than 15,000 people and generates annual revenue in excess of $3 billion. In the U.S., it operates a manufacturing plant in Lyman, S.C., and has five regional assembly centers and 60 technical sales offices. Besides offering efficient, high-torque drives that meet tough reliability standards for the heaviest loads and harshest environments, the company prides itself on engineering custom modifications for specific customer applications and on its extensive support and distribution network. Jurgen owns 50% of the company and Rainer, 44.9%. Just under 5% is held by Rainer's charitable foundation. The brothers shun all publicity; not much is known about them.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hubert Burda is a publishing baron who likes to mingle with movie stars, media personalities, fashionistas and captains of industry. A celebrity in his own right, he's married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler. In 2010, he handed over day-to-day control of Hubert Burda Media to Paul-Bernhard Kallen, a former McKinsey & Company consultant and Burda chief financial officer, and subsequently transferred a 40% ownership stake to his two children, Jacob and Elisabeth. (He still owns the remaining 60%). Burda's portfolio now consists of 500 media products worldwide, including the German editions of Elle, InStyle and Playboy. Though built via mass-market print publications -- the German newsweekly Focus and the celebrity magazine Bunte are company mainstays -- digital sources now account for fully half of Burda's roughly $2.65 billion in annual revenue. A big success in both print and digital is BurdaStyle, a portfolio of media brands aimed at women. (BurdaStyle has been publishing Harper's Bazaar in Germany since August 2013, in a joint venture with U.S. media company Hearst.)  In March 2014, Burda entered into a joint venture with F+W, a New York City-based content and e-commerce company, to run the BurdaStyle brand in the U.S. and Canada, as well as the UK digital activities of BurdaStyle. Among Hubert Burda's philanthropic endeavors are the Felix Burda Foundation, which is committed to reducing the number of deaths from colon cancer in Germany (it's named after his son Felix, who died of colon cancer in 2001, at age 33). He also supports the Hermann-Lenz-Prize, a German literary award; the Burda Center for Innovative Communication, a media center at Ben Gurion University in Israel; and the Burda Academy of the Third Millennium, an interdisciplinary forum for researchers and thinkers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Smita Crishna-Godrej, who belongs to the storied Godrej clan, makes her maiden appearance on the billionaires list by virtue of a one-fifth stake in the family assets. Her brother Jamshyd runs consumer goods firm Godrej & Boyce. Her husband Vijay Crishna, a well-known theatre actor, and daughter Nyrika work in the group. Two years ago, Crishna-Godrej made news when she bought a heritage bungalow that once belonged to Homi Bhabha, India's atomic energy pioneer, for $60 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paints tycoon Ashwin Dani is nonexecutive vice chairman at $2.1 billion (revenues) Asian Paints, founded by his father and 3 others in 1942. The company saw a double-digit rise in revenues and net earnings in the latest quarter helped by a spurt in demand for decorative paints in the festive season. Asia's third-largest paintmaker is adding capacity by investing $345 million in a new factory in south India. A yoga practitioner, Dani sits on the board of pharma billionaire Dilip Shanghvi's Sun Pharmaceutical Industries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eduardo Eurnekian, the son of Armenian immigrants, first delved into the textiles industry, and then the cable TV business in the 1980s. He added to his media portfolio, buying radio stations, newspapers, and a TV channel. In the 1990s, he offloaded all of his media holdings, netting $750 million with the sale of Cablevision, as a wave of privatization brought capital into Argentina. In the late 1990s, he led a consortium that secured a 30-year concession to build and operate Argentina's airports. Today, he and partners have a portfolio of more than 50 airports in multiple countries with annual revenues of approximately $2 billion, including the first privately operated airports in Brazil. After Argentina's economic crash in 2001, he bought assets through his Corporacion America, a holding company that owns more than 260,000 acres of land dedicated to crops, cattle and vineyards. It also owns an infrastructure development company, a chip factory called Unitech Blue, a biodiesel production facility, and land in Armenia used for fruit production and wine. Eurnekian has been investing in oil and gas in Argentina. In 2011, he sold 21 duty free shops in Argentina, Uruguay, Ecuador, Martinique and Armenia to Switzerland's Dufry AG for $957 million. He has never married and has no children. Martin and Hugo Eurnekian, sons of his deceased brother Alberto, work with him. Martin is the president of Puerta del Sol, the company that manages the group's airport business in Uruguay. Hugo leads the biggest challenge that Corporacion America has taken on: the construction of a tunnel passing through the Andes called Bioceanico Aconcagua, in which it plans to invest more than $3 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Fisher has taken a backseat at his family's retail conglomerate, Gap. Fisher,the youngest son of Gap founders Donald (d. 2009) and Doris, is the only one of the couple's three sons who is not on the company's board. Fisher has shown more interest in sports than retail: He owns the majority of the Oakland A's and has small stakes in the San Jose Earthquakes of the MLS and the Scottish Glasgow Celtic football club. Like his brothers, William and Robert, he went to Princeton University and Stanford University's Graduate School of Business. John chairs the board of the KIPP Foundation, which trains and funds teachers for the KIPP public charter school network. He has supported conservative candidates and causes throughout his life, reportedly working in the mailroom at the RNC and as a staffer for Ronald Reagan and Vice President George Bush right after college.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Much of Beijing is under watch by closed-circuit TV. Such moves have benefited Zhejiang Dahua Technology, one of China's biggest surveillance businesses. Fu Liquan, his wife Chen Ailing and another partner cofounded the forerunner of Zhejiang Dahua Technology in 2001 with $60,000; Fu and his wife sold their property and borrowed money to raise the cash. Fu worked at a small electrical equipment factory before starting his first equipment plant in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch Adi Godrej chairs the 119-year-old Godrej Group, a $4.1 billion (revenues) consumer-goods conglomerate. Listed outfit Godrej Consumer Products, which he oversees, acquired Canon Chemicals, a Kenyan maker of home and personal care products, in February. Last year, agribusiness firm Godrej Agrovet bought a  majority stake in agrochemicals maker Astec LifeSciences for $30 million and took control of milk producer Creamline Dairy in south India. Despite a dull market for real estate, the group's property arm run by his son Pirojsha sold 300 apartments in a week when it launched The Trees, a mixed-use development at the family's estate in suburban Mumbai. This year, Godrej's fortune  excludes stakes held by his brother Nadir who is listed separately for the first time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jamshyd Godrej, the cousin of Godrej clan patriarch, Adi Godrej, runs privately-held consumer durables arm Godrej & Boyce as chairman and managing director along with his son Navroze. The $1.3 billion (revenues) firm, best known for its appliances, furniture and security solutions, has set up a design and innovation lab at its Mumbai headquarters. It recently acquired a majority stake in India Circus, a home decor brand and plans to launch a new range of air conditioners under its premium NXW brand. A keen sailor, Jamshyd's fortune this year excludes stakes held by his sister Smita Crishna-Godrej who is listed separately for the first time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nadir Godrej, the younger sibling of Adi Godrej, debuts on the billionaires list thanks to his 20% share in the assets of the Godrej Group, the 119 year-old family conglomerate. With degrees from MIT, Stanford University and an MBA from Harvard Business School, he joined the family business four decades ago. Today he oversees Godrej Industries as managing director and chairs agribusiness unit Godrej Agrovet. He has a flair for languages and writes poetry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Noam Gottesman has an appetite for food, at least when it comes to investing. He owns 100 Burger King franchises and also has six trendy restaurants in New York City and the Hamptons, including Eleven Madison Park, which was awarded three Michelin stars for the first time the year after Noam invested. His Nomad Foods, a publicly traded investment vehicle that he cofounded in 2014, purchased Iglo Group (known for Birds Eye frozen brands) in June 2015. Gottesman made his original fortune in hedge funds, cofounding London-based firm GLG Partners in 1995, initially a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers. The firm was later spun off, went public in 2007 and was eventually sold to Man Group for $1.6 billion in 2010. Gottesman stepped down as CEO at the time of the sale. Gottesman, who sold his London home to Indian billionaire Lakshmi Mittal for $190 million during the financial crisis, now lives in a converted ice factory in downtown Manhattan. He got married in May 2015 to the sales director of fashion label Reed Krakoff in Italy, an elaborate event attended by such celebrities as Beyonce and Jay Z.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'TOMS Capital', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Walter Haefner, the oldest billionaire at the time of his death at 101 in June 2012, Martin Haefner inherited half of his father's stake in American IT management software maker CA Technologies (formerly Computer Associates). He also inherited part of car dealer AMAG, which sells brands including Volkswagen, Audi, Bentley, and Porsche. Martin's sister Eva Maria is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Caroline Marie Hagen Kjos, 32, was appointed to take over the family company started by her father, budget-grocery billionaire Stein Erik Hagen. In 2015 she assumed the chairmanship and 97.5% ownership of holding company Canica AS, although Stein Erik Hagen still controls some 70% of the votes. A resident of Switzerland since 2009, Hagen Kjos inherited a fortune while avoiding an inheritance tax (of which her family is a vocal critic). Stein Erik Hagen founded discount supermarket Rimi with his father in the 1970s. The chain merged with Dutch retailer Ahold in 2007 and Hagen eventually sold his stake, forming Canica AS with the proceeds. Canica AS now has various investments across Scandinavia, including goods manufacturer Orkla ASA and hardware store chain Jernia.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2008 Bahaa Hariri, the eldest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, split from Saudi Oger, the family construction business, to focus on his own interests. He has invested heavily in Jordan. In partnership with the Jordanian government, his real estate holding company, Horizon Group, developed a swath of downtown Amman into a new commercial and residential area. The Boston University graduate is also majority owner of Globe Express, a logistics company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Josh Harris invested in English Premier League soccer club, Crystal Palace, in late 2015, adding to his portfolio of sports teams. Harris also has investments in the Philadelphia 76ers and the New Jersey Devils. While his teams have been losers in recent years, investment wise, Harris, who has made a fortune in distressed investing, can't complain. The value of the 76ers is up significantly since he and partners bought the team in 2011. Not doing as well: Apollo Global Management, the private equity firm he co-founded with fellow billionaires Leon Black and Marc Rowan. Shares of the firm, which he helps run, hit their lowest level in more than three years at the start of 2016, prompting the firm to announce a $250 million share buyback. Harris may win more fans through his family foundation, whose focus is to use sports and wellness to improve lives and communities. Recent grants have included $3.5 million to the Police Athletic League in Philadelphia for its youth programming and $5 million to Mt. Sinai Hospital to fund innovations to health monitoring and wellness management. A former wrestler, he competes in marathons and triathalons.

name: Billionaires
bio: B. Wayne Hughes built a fortune storing other people's excess stuff. He founded Public Storage in 1972; it's now the largest self-storage chain in the world, with more than 2,200 locations throughout the U.S. and Europe. He serves as chairman emeritus. His daughter, Tamara Gustavson, is a board member and the company's single largest shareholder. Both she and her brother, B. Wayne Hughes, Jr., are also billionaires. After the market collapse in 2009, real estate values fell while demand for rentals increased. To take advantage, in 2011 Hughes formed a publicly-traded REIT called American Homes 4 Rent, to acquire, renovate and rent single-family homes. A lover of thoroughbred horse racing, he owns a farm in Livingston, Kentucky, with a stable of stallions that have sired championship horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Min Kao's GPS maker Garmin has sold over 141 million products, including 15 million in 2014, but the company faces stiff competition from smartphones. In response, Garmin is diversifying into consumer electronics, including watches to help golfers navigate greens. An engineer, Kao got his start working on navigation products at Teledyne and Magnavox. Future partner Gary Burrell recruited Kao to King Radio. In 1989, the Burrell and Kao left to start Garmin. Kao stepped down as CEO in 2012 but remains the executive chairman. The Taiwan-native got his doctorate at the University of Tennessee, where he was involved in NASA and U.S. Army research. He has donated $17.5 million to his alma mater's engineering college, and his foundation partners with select universities to provide scholarships for engineering students.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Garmin Corporation', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Kentucky native Brad Kelley made his fortune from discounted cigarettes. He founded Commonwealth Brands, maker of USA Gold and Malibu cigarette brands, in 1991. In 2001 he sold it for $1 billion. Kelley apparently thinks that print is the way forward: struggling travel guide publisher Lonely Planet --which Kelley bought from the BBC for $80 million in 2013 -- shipped 450,000 copies of newly launched Lonely Planet Magazine in September 2015, their first for a U.S. audience. Kelley invested in ranch land and is now one of the largest private land owners in the U.S., with some 1.5 million acres across Texas, Kentucky, New Mexico, Florida and most recently Hawaii.  The son of a farmer, Kelley's horse Oxbow won the Preakness in 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alicia Koplowitz inherited a stake in one of Spain's largest construction companies, Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, from her late father. In 1997 she sold her share to her older sister Esther, for $800 million. Back in the 1960s, Alicia married Alberto Cortina, six months after Esther had married Cortina's cousin, Alberto Alcocer. "Los Albertos," as the Spanish press called them, ran FCC until both marriages ended in 1989 and the sisters took over. Alicia had three sons with Cortina. After selling her FCC stake, she diversified her investments and has seen her fortune grow steadily. Over the years she's invested in steelmaker Acerinox, electric utility Iberdrola and Banco Sabadell. She also has a stake in Hospes, a chain of luxury hotels in Spain, and owns hotels in Italy and Miami, along with real estate in Washington, D.C. and Chicago. Through her charitable foundation she sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. at places like Columbia University's Medical Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lower palm oil prices and falling demand hit the fortune of Kuok Khoon Hong, the Singapore-based nephew of Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok, who oversees agribusiness giant Wilmar. It reported a 10% drop in revenues to $38.8 billion in 2015; net profits  fell by 8.7% to just over $1 billion in 2015, an 8-year low. The company, which he cofounded in 1991, formed two joint ventures in January with listed Singapore Foods, a unit of inflight catering firm SATS, to supply 'quality foods' to China. Last October it  teamed up with Saigon Co-op in Vietnam for a venture to make sauces and condiments. American agribusiness firm Archer Daniel Midlands, Wilmar's long term business partner, increased its stake in the company to 18% in October. Kuok's nephew Jeremy Goon is Wilmar's chief sustainability officer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund titan Edward Lampert has failed to turn around Sears since taking over as CEO of the ailing retailer in 2013. Rather than rebuild Sears, he has broken it apart, spinning off many of its assets, including Lands' End, Sears Canada and Sears Hometown and Outlet Stores. His latest move: casting off 235 stores into a new, publicly traded real estate investment trust called Seritage Growth Properties. The $2.7 billion transaction bolstered Sears' bottom line and produced the first quarterly profit in Lampert's tenure as CEO. But the news was overshadowed by an 11% decline in same-store sales, and investors dumped the stock once again. Lampert helped create today's Sears by merging Kmart and Sears Roebuck in 2005. Revenues have declined every year since 2006. A lawyer's son, Lampert read corporate reports and financial textbooks in high school before heading to Yale, where he was a member of Skull & Bones. After graduating, he learned alongside fellow billionaire investor Daniel Och in the risk arbitrage department at Goldman Sachs before going solo in 1988. He survived a kidnapping in 2003 and was released by his captors after two days. In 2012 he bought a mansion on Florida's ultra-exclusive Indian Creek Island for $38 million, complete with its own private police force that circles the island in boats.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made billionaire Lee Joong-Keun built his construction and property business, Booyoung Group, at a time when government policies favored rentals. After declaring bankruptcy in 1979, he put Booyoung shares in his relatives' names so that he could do deals. Starting in 2004, he served a three-year jail term and paid $11.5 million in fines after being convicted for embezzling company funds. Since his release in 2007, he has been an exemplary success. In the private sector, Booyoung is Korea's largest provider of rental housing. Now he's looking to Southeast Asia for new places to build. In Korea, he's been buying up hotels, country clubs and resorts. In early 2016, Booyoung agreed to buy the 25-story Samsung Life Insurance building in central Seoul for around $460 million. Lee places considerable emphasis on corporate responsibility, and is known to be a generous benefactor -- donating to families of disaster victims and granting scholarships and school supplies to support education in developing Southeast Asian countries. A keen student of modern Korean history, he has authored and published two books. "Liberation 1,775 Days" chronicles what happened during the five-year period after liberation from Japanese colonial rule up until the outbreak of the Korean War. His previous book is titled "The Korea War 1,129 Days."

name: Billionaires
bio: Lim Sung-Ki is founder and chairman of Korea's largest drugmaker, Hanmi Science Co. In 1966, after obtaining a pharmacy degree from Chung-Ang University, he opened a pharmacy in Seoul bearing his name and expanded seven years later by launching Hanmi Pharmaceutical Industry Co., whose first product was an oral antibacterial power. (Hanmi literally translates as "Korea and U.S.") Hanmi Pharmaceutical, a subsidiary of Hanmi Science, had a blockbuster year in 2015, clinching agreements worth over $7 billion to license drugs to global pharmaceutical companies, including Eli Lilly, Boehringer Ingelheim, Sanofi and Janssen. In early 2016, Hanmi Science announced that Lim would give personal shares worth around $90 million to the company's 2,800 employees as a bonus. The amount was determined based on each employee receiving the equivalent of 1,000% of his or her monthly pay.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian media baron Kalanithi Maran's Sun TV Network has been under a cloud since last June when the federal home ministry withdrew the broadcaster's security clearance. The ministry alleged that Sun was a potential threat to national security because Maran and his politician brother Dayanidhi are embroiled in a telecom corruption case being investigated by the Central Bureau of Investigation that also involves their partner Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan. The Marans and Krishnan have denied all charges. The government also barred the group from participating in an auction for radio fm licenses, but 2 courts ruled in Sun's favor, allowing it to participate. The tax authorities took Maran to court for allegedly evading taxes. Maran responded that he'd paid all his taxes. Despite these legal troubles Sun TV is eyeing expansion; it recently tied up with US-based YuppTV to launch its channels in West Asia and North Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Duty-free-shopping tycoon Robert Miller cofounded DFS in Hong Kong in 1963, and since 1997 he's co-owned it with French conglomerate LVMH. The retailer has expanded beyond its airport shops with downtown locations under its Galleria brand. The U.S.-born entrepreneur is internationally known for his headline-grabbing daughters--Marie-Chantal, crown princess of Greece; Alexandra von F√ºrstenberg; and Pia Getty. He's donated millions to support Hong Kong's arts scene through the Asia Society, where he is a trustee emeritus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shigenobu Nagamori is the founder, chairman and CEO of Nidec, which bills itself as the world's largest manufacturer of motors for hard disk drives and optical drives. Nagamori, who owns just over 12% of the company, plans to double revenue over the next five years to $18 billion, with half of that growth coming from acquisitions. Motors for automotive use will be one of the main drivers of growth. He also aims to decrease Nidec's dependence on PCs and laptops. In 2014 Nagamori brought in the former president of troubled LCD-maker Sharp, Mikio Katayama, as chief technology officer to lead development of self-driving car technology and health care robots. Nagamori, a workaholic, only takes off the morning of New Year's Day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bird lover and photographer Rishad Naoroji is the low-profile cousin of Indian billionaire Adi Godrej, who gets his fortune from a one-fifth share of the Godrej family assets. The wildlife enthusiast, who has never been involved in the business, founded the Raptor Research and Conservation Foundation to focus on the conservation of Asian birds of prey and sits on the governing council of the Bombay Natural History Society. He spent three years in Africa studying and photographing predators. In the past he has lobbied the government of Rajasthan state to stop the illegal use of diclofenac, a drug banned for veterinary use, as it has led to a steep decline in the population of birds of prey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gabe Newell runs Valve Corp., which dominates the world of PC game sales through its Steam digital game store - essentially, the iTunes of videogames. He cofounded it in 1996 with former Microsoft colleague Mike Harrington and has run it ever since. The company found initial success with games like Half-Life and Portal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Publicity-shy San Francisco developer Jay Paul has built 8 million square feet of office space in Silicon Valley, and has 6 million more in the pipeline. His high-end office towers have attracted companies such as Google, Amazon and Microsoft as tenants. Google, which already leases 1.2 million square feet from his privately-held Jay Paul Company, is taking over its new 1.9 million square foot Moffett Place development in Sunnyvale, Calif. starting in early 2016. The company is also building a new 860,000 square-foot campus for Apple in Sunnyvale. Paul's first project in the city of San Francisco, expected to open in 2017, will reshape the city's skyline with the tallest mixed-use tower west of the Mississippi. Paul lives in San Francisco's affluent Pacific Heights neighborhood and owns two yachts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard "Dick" Peery partnered with Stanford grad John Arrillaga and the two became some of Silicon Valley's earliest property barons. They bought farmland in the 1960s and turned it into office parks. Peery, who dropped out of the Stanford MBA program, had gained some early experience managing his father's small property portfolio. In 2006 Peery and Arrillaga sold many of their buildings for $1.1 billion. They held onto some, have acquired others, and count Google as a tenant. Peery's son Dave runs the family foundation, which supports social entrepreneurs and organizations addressing poverty in the San Francisco area and around the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of private equity firm Apollo Global Management, Marc Rowan now has a family investment firm, RWN Management, with nearly $1 billion in assets. Unlike his co-founders Leon Black and Josh Harris, Rowan has been consistently selling shares in the firm.  Rowan attended the University of Pennsylvania and took a job in M&A at Drexel Burnham Lambert. When Drexel collapsed in scandal,  Black, Rowan and Harris struck out on their own to found Apollo.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Rubenstein, one of the three private equity financiers behind Carlyle Group, is donating nearly $19 million to restore the 94-year-old Lincoln Memorial and expand exhibits and research there. It's the fourth national monument that Rubenstein has helped refurbish. In all, he's given $44 million towards historic preservation of US attractions, including the Washington Monument. He has funded panda procreation at the National Zoo. Rubenstein got his start as a Carter Administration official and later became an attorney. He cofounded Carlyle in 1987 with William Conway and Daniel D'Aniello. Conway scrutinized the deals; D'Aniello handled administrative tasks. Rubenstein raised the money and managed its stable of advisers, which has included George H.W. Bush and ex-British prime minister John Major. Those VIPs came in handy when Carlyle was making a name for itself by investing mostly in defense-focused firms.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Alvaro Saieh Bendeck owns nearly 50% of the Chilean bank Corpbanca, which he built after buying Chile's Banco Concepcion in 1995. He added Banco Santander's Colombian unit in 2012 and announced a merger with the Chilean unit of Brazilian bank Itau Unibanco Holdings three years later. Saieh's insurance holdings include a majority interest in Corpseguros and Corpvida. He also serves as the president of SMU, a Chilean supermarket chain in which he is also a major stakeholder. In 2013, Saieh invested $300 million in the company, which has been struggling in recent years due to integration problems following more than 70 acquisitions. He also owns the Grand Hyatt hotel in Santiago, Chile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shen Guojun started 2015 as the chairman and controlling shareholder of shopping mall chain Intime. There were great expectations following Alibaba Group's 2014 purchase of a 35% stake in Intime for $692 million. By mid 2015, Shen was out as chairman and board member, following a reshuffle that left executives tied to Alibaba in charge. Sun's other businesses include Yintai Resources, a mining company, and Metro Land, a real estate business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shwed cofounded Check Point Software Technologies in 1993 with Shlomo Kramer and fellow billionaire Marius Nacht.  Shwed remains the company's CEO and Nacht sits on its board (Kramer left to back other cyber security firms). Shwed first joined the billionaires list in 2001, only to fall off in 2003 following the tech bubble burst. He returned in 2011, and today his company does $1.6 billion in sales. He devotes much of his spare time to photography and cooking. Shwed sits on the boards of Tel Aviv University and Yecholot Association, whose charter includes reducing dropout rates in high schools.

name: Billionaires
bio: Siebel was once Larry Ellison's top salesman at Oracle. He left in 1990, created software firm Siebel Systems and sold it to Oracle for $5.8 billion in stock in 2006. These days, he runs C3 Energy, an energy-analytics firm he founded in Redwood City, Calif., in 2009. The company, funded with $150 million from Siebel and other investors, has inked deals with large utilities and brought on Condoleezza Rice and former Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham as directors. Siebel owns a cattle ranch in Montana and invests in real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paul Singer's hedge fund firm settled a fifteen year battle with the government of Argentina in 2016 over outstanding bond payments, earning his Elliott Management a $2.4 billion dollar profit. Singer's hedge fund posted returns of 13% in 2016 after fees. Singer founded Elliott Management in 1977 with $1.3 million, and it has since grown to $31 billion in assets under management. Elliott is one of the country's most successful hedge funds, having lost money in only two years since its inception. The firm is known for taking activist positions in publicly-traded companies and agitating for change. Outside of the financial world, Singer is regarded for his political engagement, particularly in support of conservative causes. He has also backed LGBT rights and pro-Israel efforts. He was a large donor in the 2016 U.S. election cycle, giving more than $10 million in support of Republican candidates.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Former media mogul Ted Turner has settled down. Turner spends his days at his many ranches around the world, pushing for environmentalist causes and giving to philanthropy. In 2011, his friend John Malone overtook him as the nation's largest individual landowner; Turner owns about 2 million acres of land across seven states, as well as the world's largest bison herd and land in the Patagonia region of Argentina. Born in Cincinnati, Turner attended Brown University and served in the Coast Guard before joining his father at Turner Advertising. He was forced to take control in 1963 when his father committed suicide, building an empire that came to be Turner Broadcasting and inventing the 24-hour news cycle after founding CNN in 1980. He sold the firm to Time Warner for $7.3 billion in shares. His net worth--tied up in Time Warner shares--took a $7 billion fall after Time Warner bought AOL in 2001. Turner pledged a $1 billion gift to the United Nations in 1997, a pledge he has finally fulfilled. His wholly-owned Turner Renewable Energy has partnered with utility Southern Co. to invest in solar power installations. An avid sailor, he won the America's Cup in 1977.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mark Walter became a familiar name in 2012 when he was disclosed as one of the investor group (along with Magic Johnson and others) bidding $2.2 billion to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team. Walter helped found investment firm Guggenheim Partners in the late 1990s after he folded his Chicago-based investment firm, Liberty Hampshire, into the Guggenheim family office. Guggenheim Partners now boasts more than $240 billion in assets under management. The Guggenheim family still holds a small stake; Walter owns an estimated 18% slice. Guggenheim was investigated by the SEC for  failing to disclose that someone had loaned a senior partner $50 million for a personal investment structured by Guggenheim; it was speculated that Mike Milken was the person. In August 2015, the firm agreed to pay $20 million to the SEC to settle the charges.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiao Wenge is the chairman of DMG Entertainment, a movie and TV company that helped make the hit movie "Iron Man 3" in partnership with Walt Disney's Marvel unit. Its DMG TV has produced some of China's most popular TV shows including All Quiet In Peking and Love Is Like Diamonds. Xiao first became a billionaire in 2014 when Sichuan Gaojin Food, previously a meat processor, issued new shares to the owners of Yinji Entertainment and Media in exchange for a 100% stake in the company. Xiao obtained a 74% stake in the new company. He also invests in real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: At 91 years old, Slim-Fast founder S. Daniel Abraham isn't slowing down. Since selling the weight-loss brand to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000, he has devoted himself to political causes that support a peaceful two-state solution for the Israel-Palestine issue. He is the founder of the S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace and travels to Israel several times a year. He also signed his name in support of the Iran nuclear deal last fall. Abraham is a World War II veteran and founded Thompson Medical Supply in 1947 before launching Slim-Fast in 1976. Sales of the weight-loss products sky-rocketed in 1989 after former Los Angeles Dodgers manager Tommy Lasorda became the company's spokesperson. In the past year, he cashed out about 80% of his portfolio and is waiting to reinvest when markets settle. Today, he enjoys traveling and spending time on his yacht.
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Emilio Azcarraga Jean is the president and CEO of Mexican broadcaster Grupo Televisa, one of the world's largest producers of Spanish language TV content. He became the CEO after the death of his father in 1997. In January 2015, Televisa sold its 50% stake in mobile phone company Iusacell back to its partner Grupo Salinas (owned by billionaire Ricardo Salinas Pliego) for $717 million plus an undisclosed amount of debt. It had purchased that stake from Salinas in 2012. AT&T then bought all of Iusacell from Salinas for $2.5 billion, including $800 million in debt. Televisa increased its hold on cable TV,  buying Mexican cable TV company Cablevision Red in January 2015 for $695 million. Televisa has acquired other cable TV companies in recent years. Azcarraga is a board member of Endeavor, an international non-profit development organization that finds and supports high-impact entrepreneurs in emerging markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Brown ran Stryker Corp., a medical device and software company, for 32 years before retiring as chairman in 2009. The company had $9.9 billion in sales last year and agreed in February to buy Sage Products, which specializes in products that fight the spread of infections in hospitals. The current CEO says more deals are coming. Brown owns slightly more than 5% of Stryker. He also sits on the board of St. Jude Medical, and runs 4 miles a day in retirement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Bang was dabbling in property and overseas investments more than a decade ago when he met a retired ophthalmologist who explained the economies of scale in the eyecare business. Chen's Aier Eye Hospital Group now has more than 80 eye hospitals in 24 provinces in China. The Shenzhen-listed company expects to build 200 eye hospitals by 2020. Aier said in July 2015 that it will set up a wholly-owned Hong Kong subsidiary to expand its overseas business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jaran Chiaravanont is the eldest of four brothers of the clan behind Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group. Jaran, who started working in the family's livestock feeds business in the 1950s, used to manage the Charoen Pokphand Shop. Jaran is listed separately from his younger Dhanin Chearavanont for the first time this year based on his ownership of a 12.76% stake in the family's vast assets and new information on their private holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: James Coulter's payday from a long-rumored initial public offering of $74 billion (assets) TPG Capital seems to be on indefinite hold as the Fort Worth, Texas firm deflects criticism over high-profile bankruptcies including Caesar's Entertainment. On the positive side: TPG closed a $3 billion fund last year. Dartmouth and Stanford grad Coulter met David "Bondo" Bonderman while working for billionaire Robert Bass in the 1980s. They later struck out on their own, investing $66 million in faltering Continental Airlines and making a $640 million profit. The two are still principal owners of TPG, though Bonderman operates from Texas, while Coulter lives in San Francisco where he works on education issues in his free time. Coulter, who  formed a group to study how digital technology can improve schools.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former metals trader, Oleg Deripaska came back from the brink of collapse . Facing margin calls and billions of dollars in debt triggered by the 2008 financial crisis, he personally negotiated with the Russian government, banks and other creditors to restructure his loan obligations. He managed to defend the majority of his assets from creditors, including car maker Gaz and power producer EuroSibEnergo. But his biggest holding has always been Russian aluminum company, UC Rusal, worth more than $18 billion at its peak. Today it is worth less than it was during the financial crisis and his fortune is way down too. Having helped build the Olympic Village and much of its infrastructure, Deripaska is still a big investor in Sochi. He also has stakes in an airport, an Austrian development company, and one of Russia's biggest insurance companies, Ingosstrakh. He married into the family of former Russian President Boris Yeltsin.

name: Billionaires - Metals & Mining
bio: A former metals trader, Oleg Deripaska came back from the brink of collapse . Facing margin calls and billions of dollars in debt triggered by the 2008 financial crisis, he personally negotiated with the Russian government, banks and other creditors to restructure his loan obligations. He managed to defend the majority of his assets from creditors, including car maker Gaz and power producer EuroSibEnergo. But his biggest holding has always been Russian aluminum company, UC Rusal, worth more than $18 billion at its peak. Today it is worth less than it was during the financial crisis and his fortune is way down too. Having helped build the Olympic Village and much of its infrastructure, Deripaska is still a big investor in Sochi. He also has stakes in an airport, an Austrian development company, and one of Russia's biggest insurance companies, Ingosstrakh. He married into the family of former Russian President Boris Yeltsin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco died on June 24, 2016 at age 81. He was chairman of Brazilian food giant M. Dias Branco. His father started the business as a small bakery in the northeastern state of Ceara in 1936. Dias Branco joined his father at age 19 and over the years modernized and grew the company exponentially. Today the conglomerate boasts 16,700 employees and 12 factories across Brazil. While most of Dias Branco's wealth stemmed from his stake in M. Dias, he also owned a vast portfolio of real estate in Ceara. He is survived by his wife and five children.
person: {'name': 'Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco', 'uri': 'francisco-ivens-de-sa-dias-branco', 'imageExists': True}
personName: Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: The Oetker fortune -- of which Bergit Graefin Douglas is one of eight billionaire beneficiaries -- was built on baking and pudding powder. Now broadly diversified, Dr August Oetker KG -- a holding company whose subsidiaries employ some 26,000 people and generate around $15 billion in annual revenue -- traces its roots 1891, when August Oetker, a pharmacist, started selling non-perishable baking powder. After World War II, his grandson Rudolf August Oetker, a former Nazi SS officer, quickly rose to prominence as the driving force behind one of Germany's most recognizable brands. In 1950, according to the family history "Die Oetkers," Oetker produced more than 750 million packages of baking and pudding powder. Personifying Germany's Wirtschaftswunder, or economic miracle, he developed additional food products and expanded into beverages, container shipping, financial services and luxury hotels. He died in 2007, at age 90, leaving eight children from three marriages. The heirs, who along with their families each own 12.5% percent of the conglomerate, have disagreed over the management and future direction of Oetker, however. Split into two camps, the rivalry is between the children from Rudolf August's first two marriages -- Bergit Douglas and Rosely Schweizer, plus Richard, Christian and August Oetker -- and the siblings from the third marriage: Alfred, Carl Ferdinand and Julia Oetker. Alfred was expected to take over as general partner from his half-brother August in 2010, but he was blocked by the older siblings, who instead crowned Richard Oetker. In January 2015, with a proxy fight pending before an arbitration tribunal, the groups agreed to recruit an outside CEO when Richard retires in 2017. Bergit Douglas, who has an interior design business based in Frankfurt, redesigned some of the family's hotels. She is married to Christoph Douglas, an art consultant and former head of Sotheby's in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Dunstone chairs both telecom TalkTalk Telecom and electronics retailer Dixons Carphone. He's the founder of Talk Talk, as well as the Carphone part of Dixons Carphone. He merged what was then Carphone Warehouse with Dixons in August 2014 in what was seen as a bet on the growth of the Internet of Things, where parts of the home become increasingly connected to the Web. He had previously sold back his 50% of Best Buy Mobile for $355 million and split off TalkTalk Telecom from Carphone. Talk Talk now represents the bulk of his fortune. He started Carphone Warehouse in his London apartment in 1989 with $12,000 in savings. Outside the office, he's an avid yachtsman and participates in sailing regattas around the globe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Feng Hailiang chairs diversified Zhejiang-based Hailiang Group, whose businesses include copper smelting, real estate, and cement. The company listed an education business, Hailiang Education Group, on the Nasdaq in 2015. Feng worked in a marketing collective as China entered its economic reform era in the 1980s. He started a trading company in 1985, followed by a copper products factory in 1989, which was the predecessor of Hailiang Group. Feng's sister Feng Yali is chairman of the listed company Zhejiang Hailiang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yahoo cofounder David Filo stayed out of the spotlight as the embattled tech company negotiated a July 2016 deal to sell its core business to Verizon for $4.8 billion in cash. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter of 2017. Filo, the largest individual shareholder at Yahoo with a 7.5% stake, started the company in 1994 with Jerry Yang, a classmate at his Stanford Ph.D. program. The duo dropped out to run Yahoo the following year. Filo rejoined the board in 2014 after an 18-year hiatus and oversees technical operations as "Chief Yahoo" at the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company. Filo and his wife, Angela, helped launch the Stanford Interdisciplinary Graduate Fellowship in 2008 and have endowed professorships in engineering and education. In 2013, they helped create the K12 Start Fund, which invests in education technology companies. Their Yellow Chair Foundation, launched in 2000, gives grants to nonprofits working in education, civil rights and the environment.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Gordon Getty, son of the late oilman J.Paul Getty, led the sale of his family's Getty Oil to Texaco for $10.1 billion in 1984, and followed by orchestrating the breakup of the family trust. An opera and wine aficionado, Getty is a partner in Odette Estate winery in Napa Valley. In April 2016, President Obama attended Getty's annual Democratic candidate fundraiser at his San Francisco home. The Getty family has faced numerous tragedies: The wife of Gordon's brother J. Paul Jr. died of a heroin overdose; J. Paul Jr.'s son was kidnapped by Italian gangsters, but only after they chopped off his ear did the boy's grandfather pay the ransom money, which he lent to his son with interest. In March 2015, Gordon's son Andrew Rork Getty was found dead in his Beverly Hills mansion at age 47; despite initial suspicion of foul play, authorities indicated his death was tied to medical issues and an unhealthy lifestyle. In April 2016, Gordon Getty filed a claim with the California Superior Court for his share of his son's estate.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Commodities giant Glencore's stock price fell two-thirds in the past year, pushing its longtime CEO Ivan Glasenberg's net worth down by $3 billion in the 12 months ending February 2016. The Swiss firm issued 1.3 billion new shares in September to soften the blow, and Glasenberg snatched up enough to keep his 8.4% stake intact. Glasenberg earned his MBA from the University of Southern California in 1983 and got his start with the late legendary oil trader Marc Rich, working as a marketer in the coal and coke department of Marc Rich & Co. in his native South Africa. By the time management bought out Marc Rich & Co. and re-branded it as Glencore in 1994, Glasenberg had risen to the post of worldwide director. He burst into the billionaire club in 2011 when Glencore went public. He is a former South African race-walking champion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Through his private equity firm The Gores Group, Alec Gores has spent nearly two decades competing for buyouts with his younger brother Tom, also a billionaire. The Gores Group has acquired 110 companies and is currently sitting on approximately $3.2 billion in assets. "I work best when I'm in a corner," says Alec. The brothers emigrated from Israel in 1968 and grew up in Michigan. Alec founded tech firm Executive Business Systems in 1978. When he sold that company, he used the proceeds to launch his private equity career. At first, the brothers worked together. They  went their separate ways in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2014, Stein Erik Hagen appointed his daughter Caroline Marie Hagen Kjos to take over the reins of his family's investment company Canica AS, transferring most of his shares to her. However, while Caroline, now chairman, may have gotten most of the beneficial share, Stein Erik has kept a seat on the board and the shares with most of the votes (70%). Hagen founded discount supermarket Rimi with his father in the 1970s. The chain merged with Dutch retailer Ahold in 2007 and Hagen eventually sold his stake. Hagen now has various investments across Scandinavia. He is chairman of consumer goods manufacturer Orkla ASA and owns hardware store chain Jernia. In early 2014 he donated $16 million to found the Norwegian Prostate Cancer Institute to research the disease. He has been diagnosed with the disease and has sought treatment in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlos Hank Rhon's fortune includes assets in the financial, industrial, real estate and transportation industries. His bank holding company is Grupo Financiero Interacciones, of which he and his family own more than 70%. In 2014 his son, Carlos Hank Gonz√°lez, left the company to become chairman of the board of another banking conglomerate, Grupo Financiero Banorte, in which his mother's family has a 12% stake. In addition to Interacciones, Hank Rhon owns Grupo Hermes, an industrial conglomerate with interests in construction, infrastructure projects, energy, transportation, tourism and auto dealerships. He is the son of one of Mexico's best-known politicians, the late Carlos Hank Gonzalez, who held several key government positions including Mexico City mayor, Secretary of Agriculture and governor of his home state of Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: When John Henry and partner Tom Werner bought the Boston Red Sox in 2002 for $380 million, the team hadn't won a World Series championship in 84 years. But the "Curse of the Bambino" was finally broken in 2004 -- and two more championships have followed since, the most recent in 2013. The Red Sox are the third-most valuable team in baseball at $2.1 billion (worth more than five times what Henry and Werner originally paid). This is despite the team's last place finish in their division two seasons in a row. Through their holding company, Fenway Sports Group, Henry and Werner also own 80% of New England Sports Network. FSG's other sports properties include European soccer club Liverpool FC and Nascar team Roush Fenway Racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With the renewed interest in podcasts, Stanley S. Hubbard, a media mogul for the past several decades, bought a stake in PodcastOne in August 2015 through his Hubbard Broadcasting. It's a one-stop-shop model, making 200 podcasts available on one app. The rest of the company's assets are more traditional: 13 TV stations, 48 radio stations and Reelz, a cable network with more than 70 million subscribers. Stanley runs the company as CEO, while four of his five children manage subsidiaries. His family has long played in the media industry -- Stanley's father started the first commercial TV station in Minnesota. Stanley first became a billionaire when satellite TV operation USSB went public in 1996. DirecTV bought it for $1.3 billion three years later (AT&T in turn purchased DirecTV for $48.5 billion in July 2015).
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of one of North America's largest transportation companies, Johnelle Hunt and her late husband, J.B. (d. 2006) started out with a rice hull packaging operation. The duo sold their home and took out loans to fund the venture. Johnelle, who had been a stay-at-home mom, took on office duties such as coordinating product shipping and bookkeeping. She began working full time as the business took off. In 1969, the couple launched J.B. Hunt Transport Services after buying five used trucks and seven trailers. The Lowell, Ark. business went public in 1983 and now has over 22,000 employees. Hunt, who stepped down from the board in 2008, remains the largest individual shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ji Changqun chairs Fullshare Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed real estate developer headquartered in the city of Nanjing. Ji is honorary chairman of Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine and vice chairman of the Nanjing Federation of Industry and Commerce. China Huarong, a company controlled by China's Ministry of Finance, owns 7% of Fullshare.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jiang Weiping chairs Sichuan Tianqi Lithium Industries, which produces lithium products and chemicals. The company trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sumet Jiaravanon is the older brother of Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont and executive chairman of Charoen Pokphand Group, the family's sprawling conglomerate. He also chairs the family's Chinese arm Chia Tai Group. Sumet is listed separately from Dhanin for the first time this year based on his ownership of close to a 13% stake in the family's vast assets and new information on the family's private holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Montri Jiaravanont is the older brother of Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont and honorary chairman and director of the Charoen Pokphand Group, the family's sprawling conglomerate. Montri  worked in the agroindustrial businesses and was executive director for two years at listed CP Pokphand Co. He is listed separately from his better-known sibling for the first time this year based on his ownership of a 12.63% stake in the family's vast assets and new information on their private holdings.  .

name: Billionaires
bio: Aerin Zinterhofer Lauder's launched her own lifestyle brand within her grandmother Estee Lauder's cosmetics giant. Aerin recently launched the line bearing her own name on sale at ritzy Net-A-Porter, and toasted the launch at an afternoon garden party in the Hamptons estate she inherited from Estee. "She always talked about flowers and finishing touches," Aerin said at the event. "And she used to say everything can be beautiful if you take the time." Aerin's brand started out with makeup and then a floral perfume line, and has since expanded into accessories, jewelry and decor. Lauder meanwhile still works at the publicly traded cosmetics giant founded by her grandmother as its image and style director. She and her sister Jane (also a billionaire) have spent almost all of their professional lives working at the family company; Aerin started during summer breaks at UPenn. Her husband (and college sweetheart) Eric Zinterhofer is a Harvard M.B.A. who co-founded private equity firm Searchlight Capital in 2010 after 12 years at billionaire Leon Black's Apollo Global Management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martisa Lazari is the widow of late billionaire Christos Lazari, the Cyprus-born entrepreneur who emigrated from London at age 16. After working odd jobs like washing dishes, Christos met Martisa and they married in 1965. Martisa had also emigrated from the same Cyprus village as Christos, but came to London with her family. Christos' hustling in the early days paid off: He enrolled in a London Fashion Design course, and created a successful fashion line after graduating. The couple poured the fashion profits into real estate investments, and now Lazari Investments owns 2.65 million square feet across London, mostly office rentals. Maritsa has been a director since the beginning, and her three children are involved as well with roles and their own stakes in the firm. Christos died in 2015, just a few months before his 50th wedding anniversary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once Singapore's star stockbroker, Peter Lim made a killing by selling his shares in palm oil giant Wilmar International in 2010 for an estimated $1.5 billion. Since then he has invested in healthcare, real estate and sports. Lim's Singapore-listed Rowsley is building a $1.2 billion healthcare city in Malaysia's Iskandar region, targeting the ageing population of Singapore and Malaysia; it will include hospitals, long-term care centers, a medical school and a wellness resort. In November, Rowsley formed a joint venture with former Manchester United football stars Gary Neville and Ryan Giggs to redevelop Manchester's historic Northern Stock Exchange into a hotel. Last year Lim, who owns Spanish football club Valencia, acquired the image rights of football star Cristiano Ronaldo, who plays for rival Real Madrid.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Makarov is the founder of Itera, the first independent Russian gas company. In the late 1990s, it was Russia's main exporter of gas from Turkmenistan, where Makarov was born. For a time, he capitalized on his connections to high-ranking officials at the Russian natural gas monopoly Gazprom, acquiring Gazprom assets, including big gas fields, for next to nothing. But after Vladimir Putin shook up the oil giant's leadership in 2001, Itera nearly lost its business. Makarov managed to save the company by turning over some assets to Gazprom. In 2012 Itera entered into a joint venture with Rosneft, the state controlled oil company; the next year, Rosneft bought out Makarov for $2.9 billion. Makarov is the president of the Russian Cycling Federation and was once a member of the USSR cycling team.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1984 Mansueto used $80,000 in savings to found Morningstar, then a quarterly publication meant to save investors the hassle of digging through individual investment fund prospectuses. He still runs the show as CEO and owns a 55% stake in the publicly traded firm, which constantly updates information on more than 500,000 investment offerings and manages or advises on more than $180 billion in assets. He also owns Inc. and Fast Company magazines, and is an investor in Wrapports, which owns the Chicago Sun-Times. In 2008 he and his wife donated $25 million to their alma mater, the University of Chicago, leading to the creation of a glass-domed library in their name.
title: Entrepreneur, Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Naeder heads one of Germany's largest orthopedic device makers, Otto Bock Group. The family business has worked with the Paralympics since 1988, producing hockey sledges and custom prosthetic for skiers, snowboarders and sprinters. Since taking the reins from his father at age 28, Naeder has expanded the staff more than five-fold to over 7,000 worldwide. The group operates sales and service branches in 50 countries and generates annual revenue of around $1 billion. Otto Bock was founded in 1919 by Naeder's grandfather (after whom the company is named). Naeder lives in Duderstadt, Germany with his wife and two daughters. An avid sportsman, he owns the 46-meter-long sailing yacht Pink Gin, which he helmed to victory in the New Zealand Millennium Cup in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: A descendant of Fritz Hoffmann-La Roche, founder of Switzerland-based pharma behemoth Roche, Maja Oeri joined the Forbes billionaires ranks in 2013 after pulling her 5% stake in the company out of the family pool in 2011. At the time, Oeri reportedly said there was no bad blood between her and other family members; however, the move diminished the family's majority control in the maker of blockbuster drugs like Tamiflu and Valium. An art enthusiast, Oeri runs the Emanuel Hoffmann Foundation and is a trustee of the Modern Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Oetker fortune -- of which Alfred Oetker is one of eight billionaire beneficiaries -- was built on baking and pudding powder. Now broadly diversified, Dr August Oetker KG -- a holding company whose subsidiaries employ some 26,000 people and generate around $15 billion in annual revenue -- traces its roots 1891, when August Oetker, a pharmacist, started selling non-perishable baking powder. After World War II, his grandson Rudolf August Oetker, a former Nazi SS officer, quickly rose to prominence as the driving force behind one of Germany's most recognizable brands. In 1950, according to the family history "Die Oetkers," Oetker produced more than 750 million packages of baking and pudding powder. Personifying Germany's Wirtschaftswunder, or economic miracle, he developed additional food products and expanded into beverages, container shipping, financial services and luxury hotels. He died in 2007, at age 90, leaving eight children from three marriages. The heirs, who along with their families each own 12.5% percent of the conglomerate, have disagreed over the management and future direction of Oetker, however. Split into two camps, the rivalry is between the children from Rudolf August's first two marriages -- August, Christian and Richard Oetker, plus Rosely Schweizer and Bergit Graefin Douglas -- and the siblings from the third marriage: Alfred, Carl Ferdinand and Julia Oetker. Alfred was expected to take over as general partner from his oldest half-brother, August, in 2010, but he was blocked by the older siblings, who instead crowned Richard Oetker. In January 2015, with a proxy fight pending before an arbitration tribunal, the groups agreed to recruit an outside CEO when Richard retires in 2017. Alfred and August will be represented on the advisory board. Alfred studied economics at the University of Passau and Oxford, and speaks six languages. He has two sons with his wife Princess Elvira Grimaldi. The family of Princess Grimaldi is the Sicilian branch of the Grimaldis of Genoa and Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Oetker fortune -- of which August Oetker is one of eight billionaire beneficiaries -- was built on baking and pudding powder. Now broadly diversified, Dr August Oetker KG -- a holding company whose subsidiaries employ some 26,000 people and generate around $15 billion in annual revenue -- traces its roots 1891, when August Oetker, a pharmacist, started selling non-perishable baking powder. After World War II, his grandson Rudolf August Oetker, a former Nazi SS officer, quickly rose to prominence as the driving force behind one of Germany's most recognizable brands. In 1950, according to the family history "Die Oetkers," Oetker produced more than 750 million packages of baking and pudding powder. Personifying Germany's Wirtschaftswunder, or economic miracle, he developed additional food products and expanded into beverages, container shipping, financial services and luxury hotels. He died in 2007, at age 90, leaving eight children from three marriages. The heirs, who along with their  families each own 12.5% percent of the conglomerate, have disagreed over the management and future direction of Oetker, however. Split into two camps, the rivalry is between the children from Rudolf August's first two marriages -- August, Christian and Richard Oetker, plus Rosely Schweizer and Bergit Graefin Douglas -- and the siblings from the third marriage: Alfred, Carl Ferdinand and Julia Oetker. From 1981 to 2009, August served as a general partner of Dr. August Oetker KG and chairman of the executive board of the conglomerate's food division, Dr. Oetker GmbH. His younger half-brother Alfred was expected to take over as general partner in 2010, but he was blocked by the older siblings, who instead crowned Richard Oetker. In January 2015, with a proxy fight pending before an arbitration tribunal, the groups agreed to recruit an outside CEO when Richard retires in 2017. August and Alfred will be represented on the advisory board. August studied economics and worked for the Lehmann Brothers in the 1970s, then returned to Germany to work at the family company. In 2010 at age 69, he became the advisory board chairman. He likes classic cars -- "Oldtimers," as they're known in Germany -- ships and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Oetker fortune -- of which Carl Ferdinand Oetker is one of eight billionaire beneficiaries -- was built on baking and pudding powder. Now broadly diversified, Dr August Oetker KG -- a holding company whose subsidiaries employ some 26,000 people and generate around $15 billion in annual revenue -- traces its roots 1891, when August Oetker, a pharmacist, started selling non-perishable baking powder. He died in 2007, at age 90, leaving eight children from three marriages. The heirs, who along with their families each own 12.5% percent of the conglomerate, have disagreed over the management and future direction of Oetker, however. Split into two camps, the rivalry is between the children from Rudolf August's first two marriages -- Rosely Schweizer, August, Christian and Richard Oetker and Bergit Graefin Douglas -- and the siblings from the third marriage: Carl Ferdinand, Julia and Alfred Oetker. Alfred was expected to take over as general partner from his half-brother August in 2010, but he was blocked by the older siblings, who instead crowned Richard Oetker. In January 2015, with a proxy fight pending before an arbitration tribunal, the groups agreed to recruit an outside CEO when Richard retires in 2017. Carl Ferdinand studied Economics and International Relations at Brown University, then started his career at Boston Consulting Group. Since 2009, he has been with Bankhaus Lampe KG, which caters to wealthy individuals, medium-sized corporate clients and institutional investors. A private bank founded in 1852, it is now owned by the Oetker family.

He was responsible for the food division's market research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Park Hyeon-Joo, the father of Korea's mutual fund industry, realized that small investors hungered for easier access to the market. So he quit his job as a branch manager at a brokerage firm and, amidst the rubble of the Asian financial crisis, founded Mirae Asset Investment Advisory and a venture capital affiliate in 1997. He launched Korea's first closed-end mutual fund the following year, along with an asset management company. Now operating in 12 countries, the firm has approximately $75 billion in assets under management. Specializing in Asian and emerging markets, Mirae has found a sweet spot with low-cost exchange-traded funds. In 2010, the Harvard Business School -- intrigued at how Mirae was able to outmaneuver conglomerates that had long dominated the investment business in Korea -- selected Mirae for a case study for its M.B.A. program. Park, meanwhile, has been promoting and funding a variety of charitable endeavors. The Mirae Asset Park Hyeon Joo Foundation provides scholarships to academically promising students from disadvantaged families.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hyatt heiress Jean "Gigi" Pritzker is an active Hollywood producer. Her Oddlot Entertainment production company was responsible for 2015's critically-panned Mortdecai. The Johnny Depp movie grossed just $30 million worldwide on a budget of $60 million. In 2014, she announced she was backing a new movie studio, STX Entertainment, with fellow producer Robert Simonds, private-equity firm TPG Capital and China's Hony Capital. Its first film, The Gift, was released in August 2015. Gigi also owns a steel-mill-servicing company, TMS International, which she and her brother Thomas bought for $1 billion, including debt. Her grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (her father; d. 1999), Robert (d. 2011) and Donald (D. 1972), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. She still owns 13% of Hyatt common stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicolas Puech is a fifth-generation descendant of √âmile-Maurice Herm√®s who founded one of Paris's most famous luxury fashion exports. Herm√®s started as a saddle manufacturer and now generates more than $5 billion in revenue through products including $450 printed silk scarves and $20,000 Birkin bags, named after the British actress-singer, Jane Birkin. Puech owns just under 6% of Herm√®s; he resigned from the company's supervisory board in August 2014. That September, Herm√®s and fellow fashion billionaire Bernard Arnault's LVMH group reached an agreement to distribute LVMH's 23% stake in the luxury goods company to its shareholders, settling a four-year dispute launched when LVMH accumulated the stock without its rival's knowledge prompting speculation Arnault was planning a takeover. As part of the settlement, Arnault and his companies have committed not to buy any more shares in Herm√®s over the next five years. The Arnault family group still maintains an 8.5% stake in Herm√®s, though members of the Hermes family, now in its sixth generation, continues to hold a majority stake. The clan reportedly agreed not to sell their shares for 20 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mochtar Riady is the founder of global conglomerate Lippo Group, which is run by his sons, James and Singapore-based Stephen. His grandson, John, is leading the charge into e-commerce with a $500 million investment in MatahariMall, an online version of its popular Matahari department store chain, aiming to make it the Alibaba of Indonesia. Lippo has backed Venturra, a new $150 million venture capital fund to invest in  Southeast Asian tech companies

name: Billionaires
bio: The Oetker fortune -- of which Rosely Schweizer is one of eight billionaire beneficiaries -- was built on baking and pudding powder. Now broadly diversified, Dr August Oetker KG -- a holding company whose subsidiaries employ some 26,000 people and generate around $15 billion in annual revenue -- traces its roots 1891, when August Oetker, a pharmacist, started selling non-perishable baking powder. After World War II, his grandson Rudolf August Oetker, a former Nazi SS officer, quickly rose to prominence as the driving force behind one of Germany's most recognizable brands. In 1950, according to the family history "Die Oetkers," Oetker produced more than 750 million packages of baking and pudding powder. Personifying Germany's Wirtschaftswunder, or economic miracle, he developed additional food products and expanded into beverages, container shipping, financial services and luxury hotels. He died in 2007, at age 90, leaving eight children from three marriages. The heirs, who along with their families each own 12.5% percent of the conglomerate, have disagreed over the management and future direction of Oetker, however. Split into two camps, the rivalry is between the children from Rudolf August's first two marriages -- Rosely Schweizer and Bergit Graefin Douglas, plus Richard, Christian and August Oetker -- and the siblings from the third marriage: Alfred, Carl Ferdinand and Julia Oetker.
