Hua worked for state-owned Hangzhou Telecommunication Bureau for a decade before he cofounded Shunwang in July 2005 in Hangzhou.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Li chairs Wuhan Guide Infrared, a supplier of infrared imaging systems whose customers include China's military. Huang worked for a state-owned electric power research institute in Hubei Province after graduating from Huazhong University of Science & Technology in 1987. He struck out on his own a dozen years later, founding Wuhan Guide Electric. He changed its name in 2004 and took the company public in 2010 on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Qisen chairs the Thaihot Group, which trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange and is mainly involved in property development and manufacturing agricultural chemicals. Huang worked for the Fujian branch of state-run China Construction Bank before he started his property business and founded Thaihot in 1996. Thaihot has looked to expand into financial services of late with plans to invest in a life insurance company.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former construction worker, Huang Zhenda founded Shantou Dahao Municipal Engineering Corp. in 1984, the predecessor of his privately owned Guangdong Lian Tai Group. Today the privately-held business is involved in construction, toll road operation, property development and sewage treatment. He owns the company with his son Huang Jianxun and daughter Huang Wanru.

name: Billionaires
bio: The supplier behind Victoria's Secret and Calvin Klein, Hung Yau Lit founded one of the world's largest intimate wear manufacturers, Regina Miracle International. The high school dropout first dipped his toe into the business by working as a Velcro salesman, eventually starting his own Velcro business and branching out later to shoulder pads in the 1980s. As fashions changed, Hung moved into manufacturing bra pads, setting up production facilities in Shenzhen and leaning on the molding technology he learned from his previous businesses. Regina Miracle, reportedly named after his third daughter, started mass producing undergarments in 2008.  It added sportswear to the lineup in 2011, producing shoes and seamless gym clothing to clients such as Under Armour and Adidas. Today, the company, which went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in October 2015, makes some 50 million bras a year. Hung, who is still the CEO and chairman, owns 75% of the shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johannes Karcher owns 50% of the world's largest privately held cleaning equipment company, Alfred Karcher GmbH & Co. KG. The business was founded in 1935 by his father, Alfred Karcher, when he started developing product ideas in the field of heating technology. Among its early offerings: a furnace for tempering steel and hardening light alloys, airplane cabin heaters and pre-heating burners for airplane motors. In 1950, Karcher created the first European hot-water pressure washer. Karcher died in 1959, at age 58, leaving the company in the hands of his wife Irene, who successfully built on a legacy of innovation for over three decades before transferring ownership to her children, Johannes and Susanne. Today, the company manufactures cleaning products and equipment for homes, gardens, transport, buildings and other professional applications. It employs more then 11,000 people around the globe and generates around $2.3 billion in revenue. Neither Johannes nor his sister is active in the operational management of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of wealthy Thai property clan Keeree Kanjanapas is the founder of BTS Group Holdings, operator of Bangkok's famous SkyTrain. Last year, he anointed eldest son Kavin as CEO, though he remains chairman. BTS shares have fallen due to lower revenues from its media arm. The firm has a jv with SET-listed developer Sansiri to build condo towers along mass transit stations. In October BTS sold half its stake in its property arm Nuvo Line Agency to Sansiri.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kei Hoi Pang chairs Logan Property Holdings, a real estate developer headquartered in Guangdong Province that targets the residential market for first-time buyers. The company made a splash in 2014 when its ownership was controlled by Kei's daughter Perenna Kei, who was briefly the world's youngest female billionaire. Disclosures now clarify that Kei Hoi Pang owns 85% of the Hong Kong-listed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sidney Kimmel founded popular apparel company the Jones Group more than four decades ago, but his first foray into the fashion world was working at a knitting mill. Private equity firm Sycamore Partners purchased the previously publicly traded company for $2.2 billion in 2014. By the time of the sale, Kimmel had gifted away a big chunk of his Jones Group shares to Johns Hopkins University, which houses the Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center. A noted philanthropist, Kimmel's foundation also donated $110 million to Thomas Jefferson University in 2014. The Philadelphia native now spends most of his time in Johnny Carson's former Malibu estate, and maintains a 5% stake of NBA's Miami Heat. He also owns production company Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, which produced films such as Adeline and The Kite Runner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment legend Seth Klarman runs Boston-based firm Baupost. With $30 billion under management, Baupost is one of the largest hedge funds. It posted solid returns of 9% net of fees in 2016. Klarman is seen as an expert in value investing. His book "Margin of Safety," a cult classic among investors, sells for as much as $4,000 on Amazon. An avid philanthropist, his foundation's assets hit $540 million as of the latest public filing. Klarman, whose philanthropic efforts focus on scientific research and promoting access to music learning, is also a major supporter of causes in Israel. He owns the digital, English-language Israeli newspaper Times of Israel.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire, Henadiy Boholyubov, Ihor Kolomoyskyy controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. He was unceremoniously stripped of his office last winter and stepped down as governor of the Dnipropetrovsk region after President Poroshenko stepped up his "de-oligarchization" campaign. With Boholyubov, Kolomoyskyy settled a lawsuit brought by fellow Ukrainian billionaire, Victor Pinchuk, in London for over $2 billion in damages for unfulfilled pledges on mining investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guy Laliberte cofounded Cirque du Soleil, one of the biggest live entertainment groups in the world. Known for its intricate circus shows, the Cirque has performed for more than 160 million spectators across more than 400 cities on six continents. Laliberte started out as a street performer in Quebec, walking on stilts and breathing fire. He founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 when the Canadian government awarded him a $1 million contract to develop a celebration for the 450th anniversary of the discovery of Canada. In 2015 he sold much of his 90% stake to U.S. private equity firm TPG Capital and Chinese investment group Fosun. Laliberte kept 10% of the company. He traveled to space as a tourist in 2009.
title: Cofounder and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Cirque du Soleil', 'title': 'Cofounder and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee Hwa-Kyung is the second daughter of Dongyang Group founder Lee Yang-Koo. She began her career in Donyang's confectionary business, now known as Orion Confectionary, in 1975. Orion's portfolio now includes more than 100 brands in such categories as biscuits, caramel, chewing gum and snacks. The company's most famous product is Choco Pie, consisting of a combination of biscuit, chocolate and marshmallow filling. Sales for her Orion are booming in China: the country generates twice as much revenue for the maker of Choco Pies as South Korea but the share price still fell over the past year. Husband Dam Chul-Gon serves as chairman; the figure for net worth includes his $660 million stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former emergency room doctor James Leininger is now a Texas GOP heavyweight. A champion of school reform, Leininger favors school choice, home schooling and vouchers. He founded the Texas Public Policy Foundation in 1989 to support free-market policies and research. Leininger, also known simply as "Doctor Jim," made his fortune founding medical devices company Kinetic Concepts (KCI), which focuses on wound care. Leininger started KCI in a one-bedroom apartment in 1976. In November 2012 a consortium of private equity firms led by Apax Partners closed a $6.3 billion acquisition of the company. Leininger was the largest individual shareholder and sold his stake when Apax took the company private. Since then he has mostly invested through his Medcare Investment Funds, which manage $1 billion in assets. In addition to funneling money toward school reform, he is a longtime donor to Texas Gov. Rick Perry. He enjoys fishing, bow hunting, scuba diving and hiking, and he has a small stake in the San Antonio Spurs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Weiwei is the vice chairman of Shenzhen-listed Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology, an online game business. Li and fellow billionaire Zeng Kaitian co-founded Shanghai Sanqi Wan Network Technology, a web entertainment business that later changed its name to Sanqi Interactive Entertainment (Shanghai) Network and was acquired in cash and stock transactions by China-listed Wuhu Shunrong Automotive Parts. Today, Wuhu Shunrong Automotive Parts is known as Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang Guangwei is the chairman of conglomerate Shenzhen Huaqiang Holdings. Its listed unit Shenzhen Huaqiang Industry manufactures batteries, mini motors and digital cameras, among other products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Ming-Hsiung leads Pxmart, one of Taiwan's largest discount supermarket chains, with more than 700 stores. Last year the company hired Hsu Chung-jen, who previously headed up well regarded rival President Chain Store Corp., Taiwan's biggest operator of 7-Eleven stores, to help shake up the business. Lin bought Pxmart from the government in 1998. He also heads up real estate developer Yuanlih Construction and Hwatai Bank of Taipei.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scott Lin is a cofounder of smartphone lens maker Largan Precision, which went public on the Taiwan Stock Exchange in 2010. Apple is one of its biggest customers. Sons Adam and En-Chou took over as CEO and chairman, respectively, in 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Di put some of the earliest money into drone maker SZ Dajiang Innovation Technology (commonly known as DJI), investing about $90,000 into the company in 2006. Family friends with founder and CEO Frank Wang (also a billionaire), he was endearingly called a "penny pincher" by DJI's leader and ran the company's finances in its early years. FORBES estimates that he owns about 16% of  DJI, which was on track to hit $1 billion in revenue in 2015. Some analysts estimate that DJI has 70% of the consumer unmanned aerial vehicle market through sales of its trademark Phantom drones, which retail for around $1,000. In May 2015 the company raised $75 million from Silicon Valley venture capital firm Accel Partners, valuing the company at $8 billion.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Miao Shouliang chairs privately held Shenzhen Fuyuan Group, which began in real estate development and property management, but has diversified into education, energy, food, tea and blue sapphire technology. Miao is one of China's most successful Hakkas, a group of Han Chinese that posses their own Chinese dialect and culture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gian Marco Moratti is the chairman of Saras, Italy's largest oil refiner. He and his brother Massimo inherited a controlling stake from their father Angelo, who founded the company in 1962. Its main operations are located on the island of Sardinia, where the company also runs a large wind farm. Saras, which went public in 2006 and in which each Moratti brother has a 25% stake, is also in the power generating business through a liquified fuel gasification plant. It has a chain of gas stations mainly in Spain. Gian Marco was knighted as a Cavaliere del Lavoro, an order of merit that acknowledges his contributions to Italian business. His wife Letizia is Milan's former mayor. His brother Massimo is the former owner and president of renowned soccer team Inter Milan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ou Zongrong is the chairman of Zhenro Group, a real estate and infrastructure company founded in Fuzhou. Zhenro has 70 development projects under way in 12 Chinese cities, involving total investment of $9 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nihat Ozdemir returns to the billionaires list as his conglomerate Limak Holding, which he co-founded with billionaire Sezai Bacaksiz, expands its electricity and tourism holdings. He is currently the vice president of the Turkish Football Federation. His daughter Ebru Ozdemir works at Limak in business development and finance, and his son Batuhan Ozdemir works in energy production and distribution. His wife Gulseren Ozdemir, whom Ozdemir met during university, passed away in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Markus "Notch" Persson is experiencing the ups and downs of post-sale life after selling his Minecraft gaming console to Microsoft in 2014. While jetting around the world partying, Persson has also been open about the backsides of instant success as he used Twitter to express the loneliness and emptiness followed by extreme richness. Persson created Minecraft as a hobby project, and release the boxy designed game in indie-game forums, while employed as a developer at Candy Crush maker King Entertainment. The immediate popularity of the game led Persson to leave King and form Mojang in 2010, selling 1 million copies in January 2011 and 10 million just six months later. The three million dollars Persson earned in dividends that year was split between the 25 employees of Mojang. In September 2014, after having sold 15 million copies of Minecraft across gaming consoles, a $2.5 billion cash deal with Microsoft catapulted Persson to billionaire ranks. Known online as "Notch," Persson has been a vocal critic of big corporations, leading to three million Twitter followers and a cult-status. Persson has said he mostly spends money on computer gear and traveling, although he has shown some stints of luxury - he bought a $70 million home in Beverly Hill in December 2014. Persson is a member of high IQ society Mensa.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Erika Pohl-Stroeher owes her wealth to her grandparents, Franz and Marie Stroeher, who founded German hair care and cosmetics giant Wella AG in the 19th century. When Procter & Gamble bought the company for more than $4 billion in 2003, she received around $1.1 billion for her 23% stake. Pohl-Stroeher, who started collecting stones on childhood holidays, owns one of the world's most valuable private collections of gems and minerals. It includes more than 80,000 pieces assembled over 60 years and is on permanent loan to TU Bergakademie Freiberg, a mining and technology university in Freiberg, Germany. Pohl-Stroeher studied chemistry and biology at the University of Jena and received a doctorate in biology. When escaping from East Germany with her family, she brought one suitcase of toys from her home in the Ore Mountains. This became the basis of her folk art collection. Today, Pohl-Stroeher lives quietly in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jerry Reinsdorf made his fortune in sports, buying the Chicago Bulls and Chicago White Sox in the 1980s and watching his fortune skyrocket as the value of sports teams shot up over the next three decades. Reinsdorf and other investors bought a controlling stake in the Bulls for $9.2 million in 1985, one year after the team drafted Michael Jordan. Six championships and 31 years later, the Bulls are worth $2.3 billion, and Reinsdorf owns an estimated 40% of the team. He also has an estimated 19% stake in the White Sox, valued at $170 million. Born in Brooklyn, Reinsdorf went to George Washington University before moving to Chicago for Northwestern law school at Northwestern in 1957. He hasn't left The Windy City since. He made his first fortune in real estate, cofounding Balcor Company in 1973 and selling it nine years later to American Express.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ren Jianhua chairs kitchen appliance maker Hangzhou Robam Appliances, which started a small collective factory in 1979. It trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. The company was among the first in China to develop kitchen hood products. Besides range hoods, Robam sells microwave ovens, gas ovens, electric kettles and other kitchen appliances. Robam's rivals in China include Whirlpool. Ren and his wife, Shen Guoying, own 41% of Robam.

name: Billionaires
bio: Most of the fortune built by online stock trading pioneer Joe Ricketts remains in TD Ameritrade, the company he founded nearly four decades ago. The son of a Nebraska carpenter, Ricketts got his first job working as a janitor's assistant when he was in the third grade. Eventually, he worked his way through Creighton University and became a stockbroker. The seeds of Ameritrade date back to 1975, when Ricketts co-founded a Nebraska-based discount stock brokerage, which he named Ameritrade in 1983. He merged with a small online trading firm in 1995, and the soon-to-be Internet heavyweight went public two years later. Adding to its heft, Ricketts acquired TD Waterhouse for $2.9 billion in 2006. He renamed the company TD Ameritrade. The company averages 400,000 trades placed by customers each day, helping it generate a record $3.1 billion in revenue in 2014. Ricketts stepped down as chairman in 2008, but he and his family remain large shareholders; Joe owns a 9% stake. His son, Peter, was elected governor of Nebraska in 2014. The Ricketts family bought the Chicago Cubs, Wrigley Field and a stake in a local sports network for $845 million in 2009, and Ricketts' children (Tom, Todd, Peter and Laura) run it. In 2005, Ricketts founded Opportunity Education Foundation to increase access to quality education for children in developing nations, providing school materials for some 500,000 students in 11 countries in Africa, the Middle East and Asia. He established The Ricketts Conservation Foundation in 2013 and funds efforts to help protect cutthroat trout, trumpeter swans and common loons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Comcast CEO Brian Roberts tried and failed to acquire Time Warner Cable, his next biggest competitor, for $45 billion in 2015. The combined company would have had even more national sway with content providers and local pricing power, but the deal couldn't get past regulators. Roberts has built Comcast on bold acquisitions, snapping up NBCUniversal from GE in 2013. Roberts' father Ralph cofounded Comcast in 1963 with the purchase of a 1,200-subscriber cable system in Tupelo, Mississippi, and took it public in 1972. The younger Roberts had his first Comcast internship at age 15, then made a rapid rise through the company, becoming president in 1990 at age 31 and inheriting the majority of his father's stock in 1999. A Philadelphia native, Roberts received his B.S. from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, where he was also an All-American in squash.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fernando Roig owns a 9% stake in Spanish supermarket chain Mercadona. He also owns Pamesa, a privately-held ceramic tile manufacturer, and Spanish soccer team Villarreal CF. In 2013 he reduced his stake in Mercadona and used the proceeds to pay some of the team's debt after it lost its spot in the Spanish league's first division. His billionaire brother Juan Roig is the majority shareholder of Mercadona, which was founded by their parents in 1977. Juan and Fernando took over Mercadona with their sisters in 1981 when it was only an eight-store chain. Since then they have turned it into one of Europe's largest food retailers, with 1,614 supermarkets. The company distributes 25% of its pre-tax profits to its 76,000 employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fertilizer tycoon Alexander Rovt has been pouring his money into real estate and owns more than 30 investment properties, mostly apartment buildings in New York City. In April 2012 he paid $303 million in cash for a majority stake of the 1 million-square foot office building at 14 Wall Street in Manhattan. In 2011 he sold two Eastern European fertilizer factories to Russia's Gazprom entities for upwards of $500 million. His IBE Trade is still one of the world's largest traders of ammonium-based fertilizer. Rovt grew up poor in Carpathia, a contested Soviet territory, and attended the prestigious Lvov State University of Trade and Economics in the Ukraine. He holds a Ph.D in international economics. He managed a high-end Hungarian resort in the U.S.S.R. before migrating to New York, where he first ran a deli and then sold jewelry. He has never invested money in a stock or bond, preferring hard assets like housing. In 2011 Rovt, who lives in Brooklyn, plucked Manhattan's storied Sloane Mansion out of foreclosure an hour before auction for $34 million, with plans to renovate and eventually live there. He also owns an ornate townhouse on Manhattan's Upper East Side that he has been trying to offload.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazil-born, Monaco-based billionaire Lily Safra inherited most of her fortune from her fourth husband, the late Edmond J. Safra, a multibillionaire banker. Edmond's 1999 death in a fire at his Monaco penthouse made worldwide headlines and prompted conspiracy theories despite his nurse's admission of guilt. Edmond left most of his fortune to the Edmond J. Safra Philanthropic Foundation, but he also left Lily enough assets to make her a billionaire. She chairs the philanthropic foundation, which supports education, science, medicine, religion, culture and humanitarian relief in 40 countries and has reportedly donated more than $250 million since its creation in 1977. Lily's second marriage, to Alfredo Monteverde, founder of Brazilian appliance giant Ponto Frio, ended with his suicide in 1969. He left her with a stake in Ponto Frio, which she sold in 2009 to Brazilian retailer Grupo Pao de Acucar for about $340 million. In 2012 she launched a lawsuit seeking additional payment from Ponto Frio, claiming to have suffered financial damages from the manner in which payments for the deal were set up. In August 2015 a Brazilian court ruled in her favor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Sandell has recovered greatly since the crisis, as assets under management rise and once again top the billion-dollar mark. A former badminton champion in his native Sweden, Sandell eventually got an MBA from Columbia University and in 1988 landed a spot at Bear Stearns, where he worked with famed investment banker Ace Greenberg on such deals as Kirk Kerkorian's attempted buyout of Chrysler. After many years of quiet campaigns, Sandell has turned activist, engaging in Bob Evans Farms and British transport group FirstGroup.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Markets have been unforgiving for biotech stocks in the six months through February 2016, bringing a halt to an otherwise impressive rise in the fortune of drugmaker Regeneron's founder and CEO, Leonard Schleifer. The Tarrytown, New York company has found success with Eylea, a treatment for the eye disease age-related macular degeneration; the drug generated $4.09 billion in 2015 sales. The company has high hopes for Praluent, a new cholesterol-lowering drug that it developed with drug giant Sanofi; the FDA approved the drug in June 2015. Schleifer grew up in Queens, the son of a sweater manufacturer who attended Cornell on scholarship and dreamed of a medical career but had to return to the family business. He followed his father's footsteps to Cornell and then got an M.D.-PhD degree at the University of Virginia, training with future Nobel Laureate Alfred Gilman. He founded Regeneron in 1988.
title: CEO and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Regeneron Pharmaceuticals', 'uri': 'companies/regeneron-pharmaceuticals', 'title': 'CEO and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hilton Schlosberg is one half of the billionaire duo running Monster Beverage, the largest U.S. energy drinks business. Schlosberg is vice chairman, chief operating officer and chief financial officer of Monster, while Rodney Sacks is its chairman and chief executive. Both have been at the company for more than two decades, and while Monster has grown significantly and achieved substantial success--signing a new distribution deal with Coca-Cola in June 2015--both men have almost entirely shunned the spotlight.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shao Zhongyi chairs Shandong Sunrise Group, which is the largest importer of soy in China. The privately held company, in which he has a 90% stake, is also involved in petroleum trade and processing. A native of Rizhao in eastern Shandong province, Shao reportedly dropped out of junior high school to sell livestock feed and later bought out a bankrupt soybean crusher with help from his brother.

name: Billionaires
bio: Djoko Susanto has handed day-to-day matters at Alfamart, the country's largest minimart chain, to his children. Meanwhile, his Sigmantara firm has formed a joint venture with Japan's Mitsubishi and Thailand's Ichitan Group to produce and market green tea in Indonesia. He had a humble start and never finished high school. At 17, while managing his parent's food stall, he caught the attention of tobacco tycoon Putera Sampoerna, who helped him open more stalls. Later he started Alfamart after buying part of Sampoerna's business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sukanto Tanoto's fortune is mostly held in his conglomerate Royal Golden Eagle (RGE), which has interests in paper and pulp, palm oil and energy. His Asian Agri has built five bio-gas power plants and plans to build more in a bid to reduce greenhouse gases. He also has a stake in publicly traded Bracell (formerly known as Sateri), which it repositioned itself as a pure-play cellulose company, jettisoning its viscose fiber business (RGE bought that business for more than $300 million net of debt.) The eldest of 7 boys, Tanoto dropped out of school at age 17 to start his own business. He says he taught himself English by reading Readers' Digest, Life and Newsweek.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wilma "Billie" Tisch and sister-in-law Joan Tisch share the family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Laurence and Preston Tisch. The brothers got their start with a New Jersey hotel in 1946; they acquired Loews Theatres in 1959 and soon diversified. Today Wilma owns just under 5% of the publicly traded Loews Corp. which includes oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk), and insurance (CNA). Wilma's son James is the CEO of Loews; his brother Andrew is co-chairman of the board with Joan's son, Jonathan. In keeping with the Tisch charitable legacy, Wilma and her family have given millions to educational and charitable causes throughout New York city. At NYU, the family helped create the Tisch School of the Arts and the Tisch Hospital at Langone Medical Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kenny Troutt founded long-distance phone company Excel Communications in 1988. A bartender's son, he began his career selling life insurance and used the funds to pay for his tuition at Southern Illinois University. Troutt took Excel public in 1996 and, two years later, merged it with Teleglobe in a $3.5 billion deal. He reinvested the profits in stocks, bonds and horses. He sponsors his two sons' nationally competitive youth basketball teams, which integrate disadvantaged families with middle and upper-class ones. Troutt also enjoys horse racing and owns WinStar Farm in Versailles, Ky., which houses anywhere from 300-500  horses, including the sire of American Pharoah, winner of the 2015 Triple Crown.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wim van der Leegte runs VDL Groep, one of Europe's largest privately held auto and bus manufacturers. The company also produces a range of finished products, including agricultural equipment and heating and cooling systems for the oil and gas industry. Wim's late father Pieter van der Leegte founded the company in 1953, when it started producing parts for trucking companies. In 1966, when he was just 19 years old, Wim started working at the firm while studying at a technical college. Within three months he was running the company. In 1972 he took over all of his father's shares. The company kept expanding, taking over bus manufacturer DAF Bus International in 1993 and then acquiring production automation company Steelweld. VDL Group continues to expand, and in January 2016 the company announced Wim would be stepping down in November, after 50 years as president. His three children, Pieter, Jennifer and Willem all serve on the executive board and own shares in the company. An equestrian, van der Leegte owns a stud farm where he breeds and trains top show-jumping horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thongma Vijitpongpun, who founded Pruksa Real Estate, Thailand's largest developer of town houses, is banking on the government's slew of upcoming infrastructure projects to give a boost to the residential property market. Anticipating a spurt in housing demand last year, Thongma had expanded Pruksa's prefabrication capacity and lined up 70 new projects but was able to launch only 44. He plans to invest $430 million in buying land parcels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manuel Villar, former presidential candidate and senate president, has stakes in Starmalls (operator of huge malls) and Vista Land & Lifescapes (a homebuilder). His eponymous investment arm Villar Group delved into the healthcare industry in December of 2015, announcing a $10 million, 100-bed hospital construction project in the Philippines, with 13 more projects in the pipeline. Wharton-educated son Paolo runs Vista. As a kid, Manuel helped mom sell seafood in a Manila market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heloise Waislitz's Thorney Investments, built with husband Alex Waislitz (they've since split up), holds stakes in more than 20 listed companies, ranging from gas and mining services to renewable energy, biotech and airline bookings. She also owns about 30% of listed investment company Thorney Opportunities and a property portfolio. Sister of Anthony Pratt  and Fiona Geminder who are also billionaires, the 3 siblings hold stakes in the Melbourne family's Visy packaging business, founded by the late Richard Pratt. She has overseen her family's $1 billion Pratt Foundation for 20 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Many of China's wealthiest real estate developers have earned their fortunes by catering to the rich. Wang Chaobin, one of the largest non-government real estate owners in Zhengzhou, caters to less highbrow dwellers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Han has become one of the world's youngest billionaires after inheriting shares in Shanghai-based regional airline Juneyao Air from his father Wang Junyao, who died in 2004 and was the the founder of Juneyao Group. Wang Han owns 27% of the airline, whose shares soared after it went public in May 2015, and 14% of Wuxi Commercial Mansion Grand Orient, a department store. Juneyao Group's other businesses include education and food.

name: Billionaires
bio: Urs Wietlisbach is co-founder of Partners Group, a Swiss private equity firm with $47 billion in assets under management. He started Partners Group in 1996 after stints at Goldman Sachs and McKinsey & Co. Partners Group's co-founder Marcel Erni and Alfred Gantner are also billionaires and also worked at Goldman Sachs. Wietlisbach owns 10% of the publicly traded company having sold about 4% of his stake since the company went public in 2006. He earned his MBA from the University of St. Gallen (HSG), Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dan Wilks and his brother, Farris, sold their nearly 70% combined interest in hydraulic fracturing and oil field services outfit Frac Tech to a partnership led by Singapore's Temasek Holdings for $3.5 billion in May 2011. Now they're buying up land. In all, the brothers are estimated to own some 500,000 acres across the West, including the 62,000-acre N Bar Ranch they bought from software billionaire Tom Siebel for $45 million in 2011. They come from humble beginnings: Their father, Voy Wilks, worked in a factory and the family lived in a goat shed. Voy took up bricklaying on the side so he could build a house for his family; When the factory boss refused to give him a small raise, he quit and switched to masonry full-time. Following in their father's footsteps, the brothers became masons themselves, founding Wilks Masonry together in 1995. Seven years later, the brothers founded Frac Tech. They are major supporters of Ted Cruz's campaign for president and gave $15 million to a pro-Cruz super PAC in 2015.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bit by the land bug in a big way, in the past several years Farris Wilks and his brother Dan have been buying ranches in Idaho and Montana. They are estimated to own some 500,000 across the West, including Montana's 62,000-acre N Bar Ranch, which they bought from software billionaire Tom Siebel for $45 million in 2011. The brothers have plenty of cash to spend -- they sold their nearly 70% combined interest in hydraulic fracturing and oil field services outfit Frac Tech to a partnership led by Singapore's Temasek Holdings for $3.5 billion in May 2011. But before fracking, there were bricks. Their father worked in a factory but took up bricklaying so he could build a house for his family, which had been living in a goat shed. When the factory boss refused to give him a small raise, he quit and switched to masonry full-time. Following in their father's footsteps, the brothers became masons themselves, founding Wilks Masonry together in 1995. Seven years later, the brothers founded Frac Tech. Farris remains pastor of the Assembly of Yahweh 7th Day Church near Cisco. The brothers are major supporters of Ted Cruz's campaign for president, giving $15 million to a pro-Cruz super PAC in 2015.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ev Williams has cofounded three digital publishing companies: Blogger, Twitter and Medium. A University of Nebraska dropout, Williams grew up working on his family's soybean and corn farm, learned to write computer code and ultimately created blogging platform Blogger with two friends. They sold it to Google in 2003. After spending two years working for Google, he left to join the crew that built Twitter, which he ran from 2008 to 2010. He still sits on Twitter's board and owns just over 6% of the company's stock. Williams is now focused on Medium, the online publishing platform he founded in 2012 with Biz Stone, a fellow Twitter cofounder.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Wu Gang is cofounder and chairman of Beijing Tongchuang Jiuding Investment Management, a money management company that trades over the counter in China. Trading of shares was suspended in June 2015 ahead of a restructuring. Prior to Jiuding, Wu held jobs at a cement factory, a domestic investment bank and China's securities regulator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wu Xushun is cofounder and a director of Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology. The Shenzhen-listed company in 2014 acquired 60% of Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Shanghai Technology, which owns web games operation platform 37.com and 6711.com; it changed its name from Wuhu Shunrong Auto Parts to Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology in January 2015, shifting its businesses focus from auto parts to online and mobile games. Wu dropped out of school after he finished middle school in 1963. He was once a government official in Xitan in Nanling County in Anhui Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elaine Wynn cofounded and helped run Wynn Resorts alongside her ex-husband, Steve Wynn -- earning her the nickname "Queen of Las Vegas." In April 2015, though, she was stripped of her board seat, despite making a highly public case to stay on the board. At issue was the fact that she wants to sell part of her 9% stake in the company, which some board members said showed that her interests weren't aligned with the company's. Due to a settlement from her 2010 divorce with Steve, Elaine can't unload company stock without Steve's approval. Since 2012 the two have been locked in a legal dispute over the right to sell shares at will. An education advocate, Elaine serves as the president of the Nevada State Board of Education in 2012. She is also co-chair of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and serves on the board of trustees of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.
title: Board Member
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Las Vegas, LLC', 'title': 'Board Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Takao Yasuda's discount retailer, Don Quijote Holdings, offers a wide range of products, from Rolexes to snacks and adult toys. He founded the retailer in 1980, stepped down as CEO and chairman in June 2015 and is now an advisor. The retail chain, which has over 150 stores and is publicly traded, has worked to become more tourist-friendly, setting up a "Welcome Crew" to assist foreign shoppers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yuan Fugen is the cofounder of Suzhou Dongshan Precision Manufacturing, a publicly-traded supplier of metal plates and cast metal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Bangxin is cofounder, chairman and CEO of New York Stock Exchange-listed educational tutoring firm TAL Education Group. The Beijing-based company, founded in 2003, provides after-school tutoring for K-12 students at more than 500 locations throughout China. Zhang holds degrees from Sichuan University and the China Europe International Business School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Kaiyuan chairs Beijing SPC Environment Protection Tech, which builds and operates flue gas desulfurization plants at large thermal power facilities. The company trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhangsun is the chairman of Guorui Properties, a real estate developer based in Beijing that debuted on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2014. The company, which Zhang founded in the southern Chinese city of Shantou in 1994, invests in residential and large-scale mixed-use projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zheng Xiaodong worked for state-run Shanghai Biochemistry Pharmaceutical early in his career. In 1993, Zheng founded Shanghai Tofflon Science and Technology, a supplier of pharmaceutical production equipment. Zheng, who owns a 63% stake in the company, has a degree from the China Europe International School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhu Chongyun, a self-made woman billionaire, owns Shenzhen Marisfrolg Fashion, a privately-held women's apparel retailer. Her husband owns a small stake. Head designer and founder Zhu studied science in college. Her signature brand mixes fabrics like leather, fur, wool and neoprene. One of her labels, Zhuchongyun, is inspired by ancient Chinese designs. Marisfrolg has several hundred stores in shopping malls and department stores in China, Hong Kong, Seoul and Singapore. The company has applied to go public. In 2014, Marisfrolg bought Italian fashion brand Krizia for an undisclosed amount.

name: Billionaires
bio: Susanne Zimmerman von Siefart owns 50% of the world's largest privately held cleaning equipment company, Alfred Karcher GmbH & Co. KG. The business was founded in 1935 by her father, Alfred Karcher, when he started developing product ideas in the field of heating technology. Among its early offerings: a furnace for tempering steel and hardening light alloys, airplane cabin heaters and pre-heating burners for airplane motors. In 1950, Karcher created the first European hot-water pressure washer. Karcher died in 1959, at age 58, leaving the company in the hands of his wife Irene, who successfully built on a legacy of innovation for over three decades before transferring ownership to her children, Susanne and Johannes. Today, the company manufactures cleaning products and equipment for homes, gardens, transport, buildings and other professional applications. It employs more then 11,000 people around the globe and generates around $2.3 billion in revenue. Neither Susanne nor her brother is active in the operational management of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahmet Nazif Zorlu founded a textile company with his brother Zeki Zorlu, turning it into Turkey's largest exporter. His Zorlu Holding has investments in consumer electronics and energy. It owns private label TV maker and distributor Vestel Electronics. In 2013 the company completed its Zorlu Center project, which includes a shopping mall, residences, offices and a hotel in the Zincirlikuyu neighborhood of Istanbul, after an investment of $2.5 billion. He also founded Turkey's first nickel refinery and aims to export 10,000 tons a year. A high school dropout, he shuttles around Europe in a custom-designed helicopter. He owns a private island off the Turkish coast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aras Agalarov got his start trading computers but saw greater business potential in trade fairs. In 1988 he established Crocus, which became one of Russia's largest trade-fair operators. He also started Crocus Inter, which operates four shopping malls in Moscow, including the luxurious Crocus City Mall. In 2015 Agalarov's son, Emin, split from his wife, Leyla, the daughter of Azerbaijan's president, Ilkham Aliyev. In August 2015, Crocus Group signed a $610 million agreement to construct the first phase of 326-mile Central Ring Road around Moscow. Agalarov is considered an unofficial spokesman for Russia's Azerbaijani diaspora.

name: Billionaires
bio: As one of Turkey's largest housing developers, Ali Ibrahim Agaoglu constructed more than 30,000 housing complexes, offices and commercial area units over the last decade. Last year however, he decided to take his company in new directions. First, he transferred all his active duties to a new chief executive, Onder Halisdemir. Then, he announced plans to restructure the company and invest in tourism, energy and real estate management. He also made a foray into the construction of two cement factories; the first is expected to start operations in 2018.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian metals magnate Anil Agarwal is poorer by $600 million, as shares of his London-listed Vedanta Resources plunged on falling commodity prices.  Oil-and-gas unit Cairn India's merger with Vedanta has been mired in delays and still awaits shareholder approval. Minority investors had opposed it on grounds that the terms are unfavorable and Vedanta may use Cairn's cash hoard to pay down its debt. Agarwal's long standing plan to acquire the remaining 30% stake in Hindustanc Zinc that he doesn't own from the government faced a setback recently when the Supreme Court blocked the sale. Unfazed, he's planning new investments such as building an aluminium hub in eastern India.

name: Billionaires
bio: After immigrating to Australia from Poland after World War One, Maurice Alter bought his first property in the 1950s and established Pacific Shopping Centres in 1979. He now owns malls in Melbourne, northern Victoria and Adelaide. The one in Melbourne's outer western suburbs has undergone a multi-million dollar expansion, increasing the space to 107,000 square meters, up from 80,000. His son Sam runs the group, plus a fund-management-and-property-development business called Austpac.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexandra Andresen, at just age 19, is the world's youngest billionaire. She and her sister Katharina, age 20, came into 10-figure-fortunes when their father, Johan Andresen, transferred each of them 42% of family-owned investment company Ferd. The Andresen family has been a household name in Norway for over 100 years, primarily known for their tobacco brand, Tiedemanns. In 2005 the family sold its stake in the tobacco business to Skandinavisk Tobakskompagni for $480 million. Today Ferd runs hedge funds, is an active investor on the Nordic stock exchange, and has private equity investments. Alexandra and Katharina have not yet begun to run the company; their father Johan still controls it. Alexandra is a three-time junior Norwegian champion in dressage riding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Katharina Andresen, at age 20, is the world's second-youngest billionaire. She and her sister Alexandra, age 19, came into 10-figure-fortunes when their father, Johan Andresen, transferred each of them 42% of the family-owned investment company, Ferd. The Andresen family has been a household name in Norway for over 100 years, primarily known for its tobacco brand Tiedemanns. In 2005 the family sold its stake in the tobacco business to Skandinavisk Tobakskompagni for $480 million. Today Ferd runs hedge funds, is an active investor on the Nordic stock exchange, and has private equity investments. Katharina and Alexandra have not yet begun to run the company; their father Johan still controls it. Katharina is currently a freshman at Amsterdam University College.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Angelini Rossi, along with his sister Patricia, heads one of Chile's largest investment groups, Inversiones Angelini. The group's biggest holding is publicly traded Antarchile, which distributes fuel, operates fishing and shipping businesses and invests in energy, forestry and mining. Angelini also owns stakes in Siemel, an agro business and Eperva, a commercial fishing corporation. The Angelini family is very private, typically eschewing publicity. The group was previously headed by Roberto's uncle, Anacleto Angelini, who died in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vasily Anisimov has darted in and out of the spotlight since the 1990s, when he owned banks and aluminum plants. He liquidated everything in 2000 and kept a low profile. Four years later, he emerged from the shadows as an investor in Metalloinvest, along with rising billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch. Anisimov's development company, Coalco, owns 44,000 acres of land near Moscow. He reserved a portion of it for a luxury residential complex called Akulinino, where friends of President Vladimir Putin built houses. Homeowners include billionaire Arkady Rotenberg. Since 2010 Anisimov has headed the Russian Judo Federation, the governing body of Putin's favorite sport. Anisimov is friends with Rotenberg, Putin's former sparring partner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ao Xiaoqiang, the chairman of Beijing SDL Technology, has built a fortune supplying environmental monitoring equipment to industries such as power, steel, chemicals and waste incineration. Beijing SDL's business partners include Korbi of South Korea, with which it has a water-monitoring equipment joint venture. Ao graduated from South China University of Technology with a major in automation. He worked at Beijing Beifen-Ruili Analytical Instrument as senior engineer before he quit in 1998 and took the plunge as an entrepreneur. SDL listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in March 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Naruatsu Baba is the founder and CEO of smartphone game maker Colopl, which trades on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. He owns nearly 56% of the company. It has been betting on virtual reality gaming, and in December 2015 established a $50 million fund to invest in such games. He founded the company in 2008 and has been developing games since 2003. In March 2015 Colopl created a subsidiary, colopl next, to operate in the investment business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Amazon executive, Binny Bansal, teamed up with pal Sachin Bansal, also a billionaire, in 2007 to found Flipkart as an online seller of books. The duo, who share the same surname but are not related, pooled $6,000 of their combined savings and started operating out of their apartment. Now India's top internet retailer and often touted as  the country's Alibaba, Flipkart has attracted $1.9 billion from investors such Tiger Global Management, Qatar Investment Authority and Naspers. It boasts 30 million products, 46 million registered users and 8 million shipments a month.  An avid reader, Binny took over as chief executive from Sachin in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Amazon executive, Sachin Bansal, teamed up with pal Binny Bansal, also a billionaire, in 2007 to found Flipkart as an online seller of books. The duo, who share the same surname but are not related, pooled $6000 of their combined savings and started operating out of their apartment. Now India's top internet retailer with an estimated 44% market share and often touted as the country's Alibaba, Flipkart has attracted $1.9 billion from investors such Tiger Global Management, Qatar Investment Authority and Naspers. It boasts 30 million products, 46 million registered users and 8 million shipments a month. Online gaming enthusiast Sachin recently became chairman and will reportedly oversee Flipkart's public listing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonid Boguslavsky went into the IT business in the middle of the 1980s. In the beginning of 1990s he was a partner of Boris Berezovsky in Logovaz company, one of its businesses was Oracle sales in Russia. In 1993 Boguslavsky exchanged his stake in Logovaz for its subsidiary Logovaz Systems (LVZ) and went into system integration business. In 1997 he sold LVZ for $10m to PriceWaterhouseCoopers. But Boguslavsky made most of his fortune from venture capital investments, beginning with a successful investment in Russian search engine firm Yandex in the beginning of 2000s. Boguslavsky mainly invests through Ru-Net and RTP Ventures funds. Other successful bets include Germany's Delivery Hero, DataDog and FreeCharge in the U.S., and SnapDeal in India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oleg Boyko opened Moscow's first stores with credit card readers in the 1990s. His diversified company later traded food and electronics, imported fruit and managed banks. He sold or restructured most of the group's assets during the 1995 banking crisis and moved into retail and the gambling industry. He sold his lottery and bookmaking businesses in the past year but still owns 241 gambling spots in six countries, including Germany and Italy. He also has a stake in cosmetics retailer Rive Gauche. His biggest holding today is his large stake in consumer lender 4finance, which he picked up in 2012 and now operates in  15 countries, including the U.S. Boyko, who was injured in an accident at a friend's home in 1996 and appears frequently in a scooter-style wheelchair, heads the Russian Committee for the Development of the Paralympics Movement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anna Maria Braun is president of the Asian/Pacific region for medical products company B. Braun Melsungen AG. Her father, Ludwig Georg Braun, took over B. Braun in 1977 -- when the company pulled in just $ 24 million in annual sales -- and turned it into one of the world's largest medical device manufacturers. The company, employing 54,000 people globally, reported 2014 revenue of around $5.4 billion. B. Braun has four divisions: Hospital Care, whose products include infusion and injection solutions; Aesculap, a manufacturer of surgical instruments and devices; OPM (outpatient market), which sells medical products to practitioners outside of the hospital market; and Avitum, a provider of dialysis and other technologies relating to blood treatment. Anna Maria, who owns just over 10% of the company, will join the management board in April 2016, where she'll continue to oversee the Asia/Pacific business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johanna Braun is the youngest daughter of Ludwig Georg Braun, who took over B. Braun Melsungen AG in 1977 -- when the company had just $24 million in annual sales -- and turned it into one of the world's largest manufacturers of medical products. The company, employing 54,000 people globally, reported 2014 revenue of around $5.4 billion. B. Braun has four divisions: Hospital Care, whose products include infusion and injection solutions; Aesculap, a manufacturer of surgical instruments and devices; OPM (outpatient market), which sells medical products to practitioners outside of the hospital market; and Avitum, a provider of dialysis and other technologies relating to blood treatment. Johanna Braun holds 10.03% of the family company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Karl Friedrich Braun is the son of Ludwig Georg Braun, who took over B. Braun Melsungen AG in 1977 -- when the company had just $24 million in annual sales -- and turned it into one of the world's largest manufacturers of medical products. The company, employing 54,000 people globally, reported 2014 revenue of around $5.4 billion. B. Braun's business is divided into four divisions: Hospital Care, which supplies medical products as well as infusion and injection solutions; Aesculap, a manufacturer of surgical instruments and devices; OPM (outpatient market), which sells medical products to practitioners outside of the hospital market; and Avitum, a provider of dialysis and other technologies relating to blood treatment. Friedrich Braun holds 10.03% of the family company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ludwig Theodor Braun is the youngest son of Ludwig Georg Braun, who took over B. Braun Melsungen AG in 1977 -- when the company had just $24 million in annual sales -- and turned it into one of the world's largest manufacturers of medical products. The company, employing 54,000 people globally, reported 2014 revenue of around $5.4 billion. B. Braun's business is divided into four divisions: Hospital Care, which supplies medical products as well as infusion and injection solutions; Aesculap, a manufacturer of surgical instruments and devices; OPM (outpatient market), which sells medical products to practitioners outside of the hospital market; and Avitum, a provider of dialysis and other technologies relating to blood treatment. Ludwig Theodor holds 9.69% of the family company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicola Bulgari, a great grandson of the founder of luxury jeweler Bulgari, became vice chairman of the company in 1984, the same year his brother Paolo became chairman. Their nephew Francesco Trapani was the longtime CEO. In 2011, with Bulgari established as a global luxury brand behind not only jewelry but also watches, fragrances, apparel, hotels and resorts, the family sold its controlling stake to French billionaire Bernard Arnault's luxury goods giant LVMH for $5.2 billion in cash and stock. Bulgari is also well known for his impressive car collection, housed in Rome and Allentown, Pennsylvania, which includes mostly American cars from 1920s to the 1940s. Bulgari built a 21-acre complex in Allentown with seven warehouses and four restoration shops, home to roughly 125 cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paolo Bulgari, a great grandson of the founder of luxury jeweler Bulgari, joined the company when he was 18. A law student at the time, he was asked by his father to design necklaces, rings, and bracelets. Paolo has designed jewelry for generations of Hollywood actresses, from Elizabeth Taylor to Nicole Kidman. He became chairman of Bulgari in 1984, while his brother Nicola took on the role of vice chairman and their nephew, Francesco Trapani, acted as chief executive. In 2011, with Bulgari firmly established as a global luxury brand behind not just jewelry but also watches, fragrances, apparel, hotels and resorts, the family sold its controlling stake to French billionaire Bernard Arnault's luxury goods giant LVMH for $5.2 billion in stock and cash. Paolo still sits on the LVMH advisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jean Burelle and his brother Laurent have minted billion-dollar fortunes by growing their late father's holding company, Burelle SA. The brothers share control of 77% of the company. It has interests in the financial and real estate industries, and also owns a majority stake in the publicly-traded Compagnie Plastic Omnium (Market Cap: $3.3 billion), a leading global supplier of automotive components and body control modules. Jean joined Plastic Omnium in 1967 as department manager. He was chairman and chief executive officer from 1987 to 2001, when his brother took over. He then moved on to be chairman and chief executive officer of Burelle SA. A strong advocate of business and industry, he also serves as the chairman of MEDEF, or the "Movement of the Enterprises of France," the largest union of employers in France. Jean is also a Chevalier de la L√©gion d'Honneur and Officier de l'Ordre National du M√©rite.

name: Billionaires
bio: Laurent Burelle and his brother Jean have minted billion-dollar fortunes by growing their late father's holding company, Burelle SA. The brothers share control of 77% of the company. It has interests in the financial and real estate industries, and also owns a majority stake in the publicly-traded Compagnie Plastic Omnium (Market Cap: $4 billion), a leading global supplier of automotive components and body control modules. Laurent took over for his brother in 2001, becoming the executive chairman of Plastic Omnium. Laurent is a director of Fondation Jacques Chirac pour l'Enfance Handicap√©e, a non-profit organization named after the former French President which supports handicapped children. Laurent is also an Officier de la L√©gion d'Honneur and Chevalier de l'Ordre National du M√©rite.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cai Xiaoru is chairman of Shenzhen-listed radio-frequency identification (RFID) product maker Tatwah Smartech. He became a billionaire in mid 2015 as the stock price of Tatwah Smartech surged.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cao Kejian is the chairman of Zhejiang Kaishan Compressor, China's largest manufacturer of air compressors and rock drilling equipment. Its name literally translates as "cut into a mountain." Customers include American giant GE.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Qingzhou chairs Hytera Communications Corporation, a manufacturer of radio communications equipment. Early in his career, Chen worked at a mobile radio communications factory as a sales manager in Fujian Province. He later became a deputy general manager, and went on to found Hytera in Shenzhen in 1993. The company's products are often used by police and local governments. Chen and his wife, who holds no position in Hytera, own 59% of the company. Its U.S. headquarters are located in Miramar, Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Yansheng is chairman of Shenzhen-listed Rastar Group. The group was formed as a plastic products manufacturing firm in 1995, and became one of China's largest producers of remote-control cars and baby seats. It has obtained manufacturing and distribution licenses for more than 200 vehicles from 26 famous vehicle brands including Ferrari, Lamborghini, Audi, BMW, GM and Mercedes-Benz. In November the group bought a majority sake in Spanish soccer team Espanyol for about $20 million. In 2013, Rastar Group entered the mobile game, film and television studio business through a series of acquisitions. The group was formerly called Xinghui Auto Model.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheng Xianfeng is the chairman of 2016 Forbes Billionaires List newcomer Zhejiang Hangzhou Xifu Pharmaceutical.  The company supplies vitamin B5, and sells about 80% of production overseas.  Xifu Pharmaceutical went public at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marc Coucke made his billion-dollar fortune building Omega Pharma into a juggernaut purveyor of over-the-counter drugs and health and wellness products. He founded the company in 1987 and sold it to pharma manufacturer Perrigo in 2014 for more than $3 billion. He owned half and was paid in cash and stock. Since then, he's made small investments in healthcare companies including Fagron, Mithra, and MDxHealth, with a focus on fighting cancer. A sports enthusiast, Coucke owns a Belgian pro cycling team, as well as stakes in Belgian soccer club K.V. Oostende, which he chairs, and French soccer club Lille, in which he has a 5% stake. In 2012, he won the Belgian version of the show MasterChef.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Davis is the chairman of staffing firm Allegis Group, which he co-founded with cousin and business partner Stephen Bisciotti in 1983. The company was originally called Aerotek, and it matched job seekers with aeronautics, engineering and light industrial jobs. The duo expanded into other sectors, including tech and energy services staffing, before renaming the firm Allegis Group in 1998. Now a $10 billion (revenues) company, Allegis places 11,000 contract employees in jobs every week and processes 8 million paychecks annually. A friend of the DeWitt family, owners of baseball's St. Louis Cardinals, Davis bought in as a minority partner of the club in 2010. He serves as a trustee of his alma mater, Villanova University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heiress Maria del Pino y Calvo Sotelo is the eldest child of the late billionaire Rafael del Pino y Moreno, who founded Ferrovial S.A., Spain's largest infrastructure construction and management company. She has been a member of Ferrovial's board of directors since 2006 and owns slightly less than 10% of the company. Her main focus is the del Pino Foundation, which she chairs. Founded in 1999 by her late father, it develops future business leaders and organizes conferences on globalization, grants fellowships to students and professionals with leadership qualities and supports cultural events. She is also a member of the board of trustees of Fundaci√≥n Codespa and the Scientific Foundation of the Spanish Association Against Cancer. She enjoys traveling with her husband and playing tennis with friends.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrea Della Valle and his brother, Diego, are billionaires thanks to their majority ownership of publicly-traded Italian luxury goods maker Tod's S.p.A. Founded by their grandfather in the early 1900s, Tod's is now a $1.1 billion (sales) producer of shoes and purses. Andrea serves as its vice chairman (Diego is chairman). The brothers also share stakes in a number of Italian companies, including Vespa-maker Piaggio, investment bank Mediobanca and Florence's top soccer team, ACF Fiorentina. The club nearly ceased to exist after its previous owner drove it into bankruptcy, but the Della Valle brothers rescued the team and helped bring it from Italy's fourth division to its first. Andrea served as Fiorentina's chairman until 2009 and is now honorary president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Five years after stepping down from the board of Indian IT giant Infosys, cofounder K. Dinesh, along with wife Asha, is focusing on philanthropy. They have funded a new cancer center at the Narayana Health Hospital in Mysore, which was inaugurated by Bangladesh's Nobel laureate, Muhammad Yunus, last August. Their daughters, who are animal lovers, are involved with improving a national animal park near Bangalore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ready to wear retailer Sefik Yilmaz Dizdar joins the Forbes Billionaires list on strong growth of his fashion empire. Along with partner and fellow billionaire, Mustafa Kucuk, he controls LC Waikiki which operates 594 stores in 28 countries. The company was founded in 1985 in France by George Amoual, and purchased in 1997 by Dizdar and his partners. Today, K√º√ß√ºk's brother is LC Waikiki's CEO and spokesman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Dzhaparidze is CEO and the largest shareholder of Eurasia Drilling Company, the leading onshore & offshore drilling service provider in Russia. A deal with Schlumberger that would have given the oil services giant a 46% stake plus the option to later buy the rest of the company fell apart in September 2015, reportedly because of delays in regulatory approvals. Two months later, Eurasia Drilling went private. Dzhaparidze started out buying outdated seismic facilities abroad and offering exploration services. He founded service company Petroalliance, which he later sold to Schlumberger. He bought oil giant Lukoil's drilling subsidiary for $130 million in 2004 and turned it into Eurasia Drilling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swiss investor Martin Ebner quietly rebuilt a huge fortune after his indebted BG Group lost most of its value in 2002. Today he owns multimillion dollar stakes in various companies through his investment vehicle, Patinex, including in healthcare company Galenica AG, injection system developer and manufacturer Ypsomed and banking software vendor Temenos Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Edelstenne has spent his whole career with French firm Dassault. A qualified accountant, Edelstenne started working at Dassault Aviation in 1960 as head of the financial studies department. In 1975 he moved up to general secretary, then became vice-chairman responsible for economic affairs in 1986. The Parisian businessman cofounded Dassault Syst√®mes, the aviation giant's software and consulting arm, in 1981. From 1993 to 2002, Edelstenne was chairman and CEO of Dassault Syst√®mes; he resigned as CEO upon becoming the larger Dassault Aviation's CEO. Today, Dassault Syst√®mes produces 3D Product Lifecycle Management software, including 3D simulations of body parts like hearts that can be used to treat medical conditions. Edelstenne remains chairman of the board of Dassault Syst√®mes; he and his family own more than 6% of Dassault Syst√®mes' capital. In 2014, Edelstenne was named the eventual successor to replace patriarch Serge Dassault as head of the Dassault Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gary Fegel became a billionaire running the aluminum business for Swiss commodities giant Glencore, which he joined in 2001 after earning his MBA from the University of St. Gallen. Fegel left Glencore in 2013 and since then he's been diversifying his fortune. He started his own investment firm GMF Capital, based in Zurich and New York, where he began focusing on global private equity and real estate deals. He and his wife Yael, a British lawyer, split their time between Switzerland, London and New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: In early 2014, the founder of the Green Alliance party, Gleb Fetisov, sold all of his business interests including a stake in telecom outfit Vimpelcom for approximately $1.4 billion in cash. He then left the business world to become a full-time opposition politician. He was arrested soon after, accused of embezzling assets of now-bankrupt My Bank in Moscow. He paid $200 million to creditors in February 2015. In August that year, he was released from prison, and at the end of 2015, he announced he was leaving politics. A trained economist, Fetisov joined Alfa Group in 1995. There he first worked at the food-and-commodity-trading division, Alfa Eco, and later led the group's takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. He also became a lobbyist and a member of the Federation Council, the upper house of Russia's parliament, but stepped down in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abhay Firodia, chairman of Pune-based Force Motors, run by son Prasan, is benefiting from his holdings in companies of the Bajaj group controlled by billionaire Rahul Bajaj.  Last year, Force opened a new factory near Chennai in southern India, to assemble engines for BMW. It already produces engines for Daimler, but has invested $15 million to build another factory to make engines and axles near its Pune headquarters. To diversify his portfolio, Firodia personally invested $30 million for a 20% stake in Israeli drip irrigation firm Rivulus. His privately-held Jaya Hind Industries has a joint venture with French auto parts maker Montupet.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a teenager Paul Foster got his start in the oil fields, welding pipees, digging ditches, cleaning tanks. He has called that labor "the single biggest motivation to get an education." The Baylor graduate became a CPA handling the books for small oil refineries across the Southwest. Then in 1997 he founded Western Refining and took it public in 2006. The company operates two plants that process 150,000 barrels per day and owns 200 filling stations. Western in late 2015 agreed to acquire rival refiner Northern Tier Energy. Foster is part owner of MountainStar Sports, which owns Triple-A baseball team the El Paso Chihuahuas.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Engineer from the Indian Institute of Technology, Sameer Gehlaut saw his fortune dip as shares of his mortgage lender Indiabulls Housing Finance fell in November when it announced the $100 million acquisition of a 40% stake in UK-based OakNorth Bank, which specialises in lending to small business. Gehlaut's property arm is building a $500 million luxury development called Blu in midtown Mumbai. It will have 300 apartments priced from $2 million to $15 million each. In February, Gehlaut hosted the 15-year celebration of his group at the property site.

name: Billionaires
bio: Geng Jianming was born into a poor family in Nanjing in Jiangsu Province. In 1995, together with several friends, Geng started his own business in a temporary work shed. Geng spent many years building a small fortune in construction. He then later moved into property development. Today Geng chairs RiseSun Real Estate, which develops real estate in medium-sized cities across China. In 2015, the real estate firm bought a small stake in the Bank of Hebei. Geng graduated from four universities including the North China Institute of Aerospace Engineering and Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. He is a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli-born Dan Gertler built a fortune through shrewd mining ventures in Africa's developing economies -- primarily in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Although he's been dogged by accusations from NGOs that he snapped up mining assets on the cheap by cozying up to politicians, he vigorously denies the claims and has taken steps to show he's a good faith actor. In 2013, his Gibraltar-based firm Fleurette joined the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative and reconfirmed its commitment in early 2016. Gertler's grandfather was the first president of the Israeli Diamond Exchange; Gertler sold off those diamond assets to fund purchases in copper, gold and oil mining. He bought his first mine in the DRC in 1997 and soon became friends with DRC President Joseph Kabila. Fleurette claims to be one of the country's largest taxpayers and employers, with 30,000 Congolese employed directly or indirectly by the companies in which it has a stake. Gertler plans to drill for oil in the DRC's Lake Albert, where early seismic tests have revealed as many as 3 billion barrels of oil. He has also developed a 1,482-acre kibbutz-style farm in the DRC, which he hopes can be a model to help address food insecurity. His charitable foundation, also operating in the DRC, supports teenage women who become mothers after being raped, among other initiatives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Serge Godin founded Canadian tech firm CGI Group in 1976 at age 26. He was president and CEO of the $10-billion (sales) company, which specializes in IT and business process services, until 2006 when he became chairman. The firm won a $93.7 million contract to help develop the Healthcare.gov website, making headlines for its role in the site's botched launch in October 2013. Godin has overseen more than 70 acquisitions, including the 1998 purchase of Bell Canada's telecom services subsidiary, Bell Sygma, which nearly doubled the size of the company at the time. One of nine children, at age 12 Godin started working for his father, who had just a fifth-grade education, at the family's sawmill. When the uninsured mill burned down, Godin worked full-time -- at a convenience store after school on weekdays and at a dry cleaner's on Saturdays -- to help pay the bills. After studying computer science and earning an MBA from Quebec's Universit√© Laval, he worked for two consulting firms before using $5,000 in savings to start CGI Group.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Ayman Hariri is one of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri's four sons. He's involved in running Saudi Arabian construction company Saudi Oger, the principal source of the Hariri family fortune. Saudi Oger was part of a venture that in January 2013 won a $653 million contract to build a branch of the Jean Nouvel-designed Louvre museum in Abu Dhabi (expected to open in late 2016). The Hariri family's other interests include telecommunications. Ayman and his siblings own a stake in Turk Telekom via Oger Telecom. The siblings also own shares in Jordan's publicly-traded Arab Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fahd Hariri is the youngest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. He graduated from the Ecole Speciale d'Architecture de Paris in 2004. While a student, he ran an interior design studio on the outskirts of the city and sold furniture to clients in Saudi Arabia. While he doesn't live in Beirut (home is Paris now), he develops residential buildings there and credits his father for his love of real estate development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alfredo Harp Helu is the son of Lebanese immigrants and a cousin of Mexican telecom tycoon Carlos Slim Helu. Harp Hel√∫ was a shareholder of Mexican bank Banamex and made a fortune when Citigroup bought Banamex in 2001. Today he owns the country's largest sporting goods retail chain, Grupo Mart√≠, which also runs fitness centers under the brand Sport City. He took the group private in 2012 when he acquired the 17.5% he didn't already own. He has a minority stake in tile producer Internacional de Ceramica. He is also a philanthropist, funding restoration projects in his home state of Oaxaca, including the San Pablo Convent in downtown Oaxaca. He owns two Mexican baseball teams, Los Diablos Rojos of Mexico City and Los Guerreros of Oaxaca and a minority stake in the San Diego Padres. He was kidnapped in 1994 for 106 days and released, reportedly after a payment of $30 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reed Hastings revolutionized how the world watches its entertainment. He's the co-founder of Netflix, the video-streaming service that offers TV shows and movies, as well as original content like Emmy-winning House of Cards. Hastings, son of a Nixon Administration lawyer, studied math at Bowdoin then served in the Peace Corps, where he taught math in Swaziland. He returned to the U.S., enrolled in Stanford and received a graduate degree in artificial intelligence. Hastings' first hit company, Pure Software, went public in 1995 and was bought by Rational Software two years later. He founded Netflix that same year and first built it as a DVD subscription service. In 2007, the company started streaming content via the Internet and now has 75 million members globally. Outside of business, Hastings is interested in education, having served on California's Board of Education and offering support to charter school organizations. Hastings is also a member of the Giving Pledge and recently started The Hastings Fund focused on education initiatives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former hippie Richard Hayne opened his first apparel shop with his ex-wife in the mid-70s near the University of Pennsylvania with only $4,000. Today, Urban Outfitters is a nationwide chain with more than 400 locations and over $3 billion in revenue. Hayne, Urban Outfitter's chairman and president, became the company's CEO in 2012 after former CEO Glen Senk left to run New York-based jeweler and watchmaker David Yurman. Urban Outfitters, which targets teens and young adults, has been at the center of controversy over the years, and its products have offended a wide swath of America, including transgender and gay communities, Navajos, Irish Americans and Jews. More recently, in late 2015, Philadelphia-based Urban Outfitters bought a chain of popular restaurants, a move that puzzled company observers and left others to speculate that it may add dining areas to its stores. Hayne's wife Margaret sits on Urban Outfitters' board and is president of wholly-owned brand Free People. Together, they also own the 700-acre Doe Run Dairy farm in Pennsylvania, which produces cheese.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters', 'uri': 'companies/urban-outfitters', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawrence Ho saw $800 million wiped off of his net worth over the course of a year, thanks to Macau's plummeting fortunes. A son of Macau gambling-industry legend Stanley Ho, he gets the bulk of his fortune from his stake in Hong Kong-listed holding company Melco International, the leisure and entertainment outfit he runs. Its Melco Crown Entertainment, a venture with Australian billionaire James Packer, has one of six concessions and subconcessions to own and operate gambling outfits in Macau. Ho's gaming interests stretch well beyond Macau--Melco Crown owns and operates the $1.6 billion City of Dreams in Manila. His new $3.2 billion Studio City, which was conceived in better times, opened on Oct. 27, 2015. Ho's gamble is that he can reinvent the business model in the world gaming capital as audaciously as his legendary father, Stanley Ho, did during his 40 years as the city's casino king. The younger Ho grew up mainly in Toronto and worked as an investment banker until Stanley, now 94 years old and largely retired since a 2009 fall at home, lured him into gaming.

name: Billionaires
bio: A lesser-known Berkshire Hathaway billionaire, Stewart Horejsi began buying up stock in the conglomerate for as little as $265 per share shortly after reading in John Train's "The Money Masters" in 1980. He attended board meetings when they were fewer than a dozen people sitting in in folding chairs; now Berkshire's class A stock, worth six figures per share, is the most expensive in the world. Horejsi (pronounced hor-ish) still holds some of those shares, but has also put hundreds of millions of dollars from previous Berkshire sales into a closed-end mutual fund, Boulder Growth & Income Fund. After graduating from the University of Kansas, Horejsi had ambitions of heading to Wall Street. Instead went home to Salina, Kansas to help with his father's company -- a distributor of industrial, medical and specialty gases -- though he spent much of his life managing his family's investments as well. He still advises the Boulder fund, of which he owns more than 40%. Horejsi and his wife, Ellen, split time between homes in Arizona, Oregon and Barbados, where he purchased an 18th-century plantation beach house formerly owned by Claudette Colbert.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Chulong is the chairman of Galaxy Group, a private real estate developer based in Shenzhen. Galaxy Group also holds a 5% stake in Sunshine Insurance Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: In Korea, Hur Young-In is know as "The Franchise King." He opened his first Paris Croissant store in 1986 and two years later, launched Paris Baguette, a bakery caf√© franchise brand. With more than 3,000 Paris Baguettes in Korea, and plans for another 3,000 in 60 other countries by 2020, Young-In aims for his company, SPC Group, to become the world's top bakery and confectionary maker. The company traces its roots to a small bakery opened in Ongjin by Young-In's father, Chang Sung-Hur, in 1945.
