Eugene Kaspersky is Forbes contributor. In 2016 Kaspersky Lab opens corpotate lab-shop, it sales souvenirs, apparel and computer accessories.

name: Billionaires
bio: British citizen Raghuvinder Kataria, who chairs Dubai's Kataria Holdings was an early investor in Indian telecom. He sold a minority stake in Sunil Mittal's Bharti Airtel at the stock's peak, cashing in an estimated $500 million. During the 2009 Dubai downturn, he bought 2 buildings in Emaar Square in the central business district for $205 million, a  deal that is said to have turned the tide for Dubai's real estate market. Also has stakes in Danish technology firm Vopium, a Skype rival, India's Dhanalaxmi Bank and brokerage firm Destimoney Securities. Born in India and raised in Uganda, Kataria divides his time between London and Dubai. Has a passion for music and owns a large private art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kim Taek-Jin made a fortune creating online video games. While still a student at Seoul National University's College of Engineering, he developed software that helped users practice typing in Korean.  After received his master's degree in 1991, he worked for Hyundai Electronics' R&D Center in Boston and later became head of development for AmiNet, the division of Hyundai Electronics that launched Korea's first Internet access service. He founded NCSoft in 1997 and turned it into the world's top online game company after developing the hit "Lineage," a MMORPG (Massive Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game). He took the company public in 2003, and still serves as CEO. NCSoft now provides online game services to over 60 countries. As part of an effort to accelerate the rollout of mobile versions of its games, NCSoft opened a studio in San Mateo, CA in 2015. An avid sports fan, Kim founded the Korean professional baseball team NC Dinos in 2011. He sold most of his NCSoft shares in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Friedrich Knapp presides over one of Europe's largest fashion companies, New Yorker GmbH, which has approximately 1,000 stores in 39 countries across Europe, Asia and the Arabian Peninsula. The low-profile billionaire started the retailer with Tilmar Hansen and Michael Simson in 1971 with one store in Flensburg, a northern German town. New Yorker does not sell its clothes online as the number of returns is too high and the return on the investment required to manage and fulfill online orders is far too low, according to Knapp. Today, the chain employs 16,000 people and has revenues exceeding $1.6 billion. Like Forever 21, it targets younger customers. Knapp promotes cultural education among underprivileged children and teens through the New Yorker Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With robust revenue and profit growth at his Hartalega Holdings, Kuan Kam Hon breaks into the billionaire ranks for the first time. The company, founded in 1988, is the world's largest and fastest maker of nitrile gloves, which it exports to 40 countries. He started in 1969 at his father's company building high-end homes around Kuala Lumpur. He set off on his own in 1978 and started a manufacturing business. As the AIDS epidemic hit he moved into rubber and then synthetic gloves for the medical industry. Nitrile gloves are made of material that is more puncture-resistant than rubber or latex gloves. Kuan plays mentor and spokesman, leaving operations to his two sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since 2000, Tony Langley has been on a buying spree, completing seven acquisitions that transformed his British manufacturing company into a global giant spanning 80 countries. He founded Langley Holdings in 1975 after picking up the pieces of his grandfather's bankrupt mining equipment maker. Lacking any formal university training, Langley taught himself engineering on the job. To keep tabs on his far flung global holdings, which include producers of printing presses, power supply systems, manufacturing materials and more, Langley flies himself around via private jet and helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Lau is the chairman and CEO of Lifestyle International, a shopping mall concern whose Sogo flagship is set in the heart of Hong Kong's pricey Causeway Bay district. He sits on the board of Shanghai Jiao Tong University. Like his brother, billionaire Joseph Lau, Thomas collects art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jane Lauder, the granddaughter of cosmetics legend Est√©e Lauder, now runs the makeup company's Clinique unit, a mall-staple skin-care line and one of the 30 brands under the Est√©e Lauder umbrella. She's been at grandma's company since 1996, a year after graduating from Stanford. Before Clinique, she managed Origins, maker of all-natural makeup. She replaced her father, Ronald, on the Est√©e Lauder board in 2009 and now serves alongside big sister Aerin and cousin William. Her husband, Kevin Warsh, also a Stanford grad, was the youngest-ever appointee to the Federal Reserve Board; he is currently a visiting fellow at their alma mater's Hoover Institution. The couple lives in Manhattan's trendy neighborhood Nolita.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee Ho-Jin is the youngest son of Lee Eam-Yung, the founder of Taekwang Industrial. Continues to battle liver cancer. Starting out in the 1950s, the elder Lee built Taekwang Industries into an vertically integrated manufacturer that would become synonymous with Korea's textile and petrochemical prowess. Ho-Jin is known mostly for successfully turning the core industrial business he inherited from his father into a diversified group with financial, media and leisure components.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairwoman of Shinsegae Group, Lee Myung-Hee is the youngest daughter of late founder of Samsung Group, Lee Byung-Chull, and the sister of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee. Samsung owned Shinsegae until the two separated in 1991. The group, which began in 1955 with the Donghwa deptartment store, has diversified into fashion, hospitality (Chosun hotels in partnership with Westin), food and beverage and other sectors. Spun off as a public company in 1996, Shinsegae International imports and distributes approximately 30 premium brands, including Armani, Dolce & Gabbana and Givenchy, to approximately 260 stores throughout Korea. It also manufactures and distributes its own fashion labels (VOV, G-Cut and Tomboy) and markets household and consumer goods under the brand name Jaju as well as the Vidi Vici cosmetics line.  In May 2011, Shinsegae, while holding onto its department stores, spun off E-Mart Co. Ltd., now the country's biggest discount store chain (150 domestic locations as of September 2014). The multi-channel retailer, founded in 1993, also consists of grocery stores (Emart Everyday), e-commerce (Emart Mall) and specialty retailers: Molly's Pet Shop, Sports Big Ten, Boons (health and beauty) and Payless (shoes). Shinsegae formed a joint venture with Starbucks in 1999 and now operates more than 500 licensed locations. Shinsegae I&C, spun out as a public company in 1997, provides IT services to outside clients and maintains technology infrastructure for Shinsegae retail operations. Likewise, Shinsegae Engineering & Construction, founded in 1991, builds department stores, hypermarkets, themed shopping malls and (in partnership with Simon Property Group) premium outlets for the group. Lee Myung-Hee's only son, Chung Yong-Jin, is vice chairman of Shinsegae Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's largest manufacturer of machine tools, with annual revenue of around $3 billion, TRUMPF GmbH traces its roots to 1923 when Christian Trumpf and two partners acquired a machine shop in Stuttgart. The company's first product: flexible shafts for use in dental tools and printing. Peter's father, Berthold Leibinger, joined the company as the head of its engineering division in 1961 and developed the first contour "nibbling" machine tool with numerical control. (Nibbling is a method of punching metal in the fabrication process.) Christian Trumpf, who had no children, chose Leibinger as his successor and successfully handed over the company's shares to him in 1972. Leibinger expanded the product line not only through acquisitions in bending, electronics and medical technology, but also through internal development, most notably involving lasers. The company has played a decisive role in the broad industrial application of laser technology. After retiring from management in 2005, Berthold passed the company's ownership to his three children. Since November 2005, Nicola, who owns a 26.73% stake, has served as president and chairwoman of the holding company's managing board. She's responsible for TRUMPH's strategic development, corporate communication, real estate, facilities, legal affairs, sustainable development and security. Her brother, Peter, is vice-chairman of the managing board and¬†head of TRUMPF's Laser Technology/Electronics division, while her sister, Regine, an architect by training, serves on the company's supervisory board but is not involved day-to-day operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Tan, with Li Li,  is part of the husband-wife billionaire team that leads Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical, a supplier of heparin sodium.  She graduated from Sichuan University -- the same school her husband --  in July 1987 with a bachelor's degree in chemistry. Li worked as a bureaucrat in Anhui Province in 1987-92 before joining her husband at Chongqing Tongda, a heparin sodium supplier.  Shenzhen Hepalink was founded in 1998. Li Tan owns 32% of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Yong is a director of CEFC China Energy Company. The Shanghai-based company is involved in energy trading, industrial investment and financial services businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Zhen chairs Hefei Guoxuan High-Tech Power Energy, which makes lithium batteries. The company is publicly traded in China and was founded in 2006. Li owns about 34% of the shares.

name: Billionaires
bios: ["Lin Bin is co-founder and president of Xiaomi, one of the world's most popular smartphone brands. ", 'Before joining Xiaomi, he was an engineering director at Google in 2006-2010.', 'Earlier in his career, Lin worked at ADP and Microsoft. ', 'Lin currently is a member of the board of advisors at the Tufts University School of Engineering.', "Lin holds a bachelor's degree in radio electronics from Sun Yat-sen University and a master of science degree from Drexel University. "]

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Baolin chairs Jointown Pharmaceutical Group, which operates pharmacies and is involved in wholesaling pharmaceuticals and medical equipment. Jointown went public in 2010 and has more than 800 drugstores across China. The company also distributes Church & Dwight electric toothbrushes and Trojan condoms, among other brands. Liu was born in a village in Yingcheng in 1953. After finishing middle school during China's chaotic Cultural Revolution, he became a "barefoot doctor," minimally trained to work in rural areas. He eventually went into the drug distribution business, founding Wuhan Junda Storage, a predecessor of Jointown, in 1999 with his brother Liu Shulin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Zhenguo is the vice chairman of Beijing Originwater Technology, a sewage treatment company that is listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. The company has grown amid increased spending on infrastructure, the result of more urbanization in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Zhiqiang is the chairman and co-founder with billionaire wife Zhai Meiqin of the Heung Kong Group. From an early focus on furniture retailing, the couple's empire today includes real estate and investment. They also have stakes in GF Securities, Guangdong Nanyue Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jose Llado Fernandez-Urrutia's fortune is tied to Tecnicas Reunidas, the construction company he founded in 1960 and built into a multibillion-dollar business. The company has projects around the world, including refineries in Turkey, Belgium and Russia and a sea water desalination plant in Australia. Llado serves as chairman. He's also an art lover who has served as on Spain's Museo del Prado foundation since 1983. He became a patron of the Museo Reina Sof√≠a in 2013. Llado Fernandez-Urrutia was Spain's Communication and Transportation Minister from 1976 to 1978 and the country's ambassador to the United States from from 1978 to 1982.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard grad Anand Mahindra chairs the $17 billion (revenues) Mahindra Group, an auto-to-aerospace conglomerate cofounded by his grandfather in 1945. Known for its homegrown sport utility vehicles, Mahindra has lately been battling a flood of competitors and India's regulatory restrictions against SUVs. It recently launched the KUV 100, a compact SUV, to beef up its market share and bought a controlling stake in Italian automotive design outfit Pininfarina. Mahindra and Airbus have a joint venture to make helicopters in India. It has launched a $3,000 electric scooter designed in Silicon Valley. Assets include a small but valuable holding in Kotak Mahindra Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ermirio Pereira de Moraes is the son of Jose Ermirio de Moraes, who founded family-owned Grupo Votorantim, one of Latin America's largest diversified industrial conglomerates. Votorantim is present in more than 20 countries through the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, agribusiness and cement industries. The group dates back to 1918, when Ermirio Pereira's father bought a textile factory in Sao Paulo. Today the family still controls 100% of the business. Ermirio Pereira's sister, Maria Helena, is also a billionaire. Their brother Antonio Ermirio, a former billionaire, ran to become the governor of Brazil's richest state, S√£o Paulo; he died in 2014. Media-shy Ermirio Pereira earned his B.S. in Petroleum Engineering from the University of Tulsa in Oklahoma, and is a member of the Advisory Council of AACD, a Brazilian NGO that treats disabled children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria Helena Moraes Scripilliti is daughter of Jose Ermirio de Moraes, who founded family-owned Grupo Votorantim, one of Latin America's largest diversified industrial conglomerates. Votorantim is present in more than 20 countries in the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, agribusiness, and cement industries. The group dates back to 1918, when Maria Helena's father bought a textile factory in Sao Paulo. The family still controls 100% of the business. Maria Helena's brother, Ermirio Pereira, is also a billionaire. Their other brother Antonio Ermirio ran to become governor of Sao Paulo, Brazil's richest state; he died in 2014. Maria Helena's late husband, Clovis Scripilliti, helped expand Votorantim throughout northeast Brazil during the 1960s and 1970s. Their son Clovis Erm√≠rio de Moraes Scripilliti serves as vice chairman of the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Africa's first black billionaire, African Rainbow Minerals founder and chairman Patrice Motsepe, launched a new private equity firm focused on investing in Africa in April 2016. Called African Rainbow Capital, it is a subsidiary of Motsepe's Ubuntu-Botho Investments. Motsepe also has a stake in Sanlam, a listed financial services firm, and is the president and owner of the Mamelodi Sundowns Football Club. He became the first black partner at law firm Bowman Gilfillan in Johannesburg, and then started a contracting business doing mine scut work. In 1994, he bought low-producing gold mine shafts and turned them profitable. South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license, benefited Motsepe. In 2013, the mining magnate was the first African to sign Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge, in which he promised to give at least half his fortune to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property developer Mofatraj Munot's Mumbai firm, Kalpataru Constructions, is busy with a slew of new projects despite the market slump. The biggest is a 9.6-million-square-foot township in the suburbs and a complex of luxury villas at a hill resort close to the city. Another showpiece is the upcoming Kalpataru Avana, a midtown 43-story luxury condo. Munot, along with son, Parag, is also building up a portfolio of redevelopment projects, notably near the Bandra-Kurla financial district in suburban Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nan Cunhui chairs Zhejiang Chint Electrics, a supplier of meters and power transmission equipment. Chint has more than 29,000 employees and $5 billion in assets. Nan is a member of the standing committee of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce, chairman of Zhejiang Federation of Industry and Commerce and president of Zhejiang Chamber of Commerce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oei Hong Leong, the Singapore-based son of Indonesian billionaire Eka Tjipta Widjaja, gets a boost on a better understanding of his property assets in Canada, where he owns the Plaza of Nations in Vancouver. He holds more than 30% of Singapore-listed IPC, which in November sold its portfolio of  7 Japanese hotels to Tokyo-listed Ichigo Group Holdings for $120 million. Oei's other assets include a minority stake in Raffles Education, which has a network of 30 colleges and universities across the region. Oei owns a valuable Buddhist art museum in Singapore consisting of 50,000 artifacts he has collected over four decades.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino and slot machine mogul Kazuo Okada chairs publicly-traded Universal Entertainment Corp., which manufactures and sells pachinko machines and casino equipment and manages casino hotels. Universal Entertainment has been taking steps to develop a casino resort in the Philippine city of Manila, but has faced regulatory delays. In the U.S. state of Nevada, Okada and Steve Wynn's Wynn Resorts have been in a legal battle since 2012. Okada has claimed that Wynn Resorts forced him to sell his 20% stake in the company at a discount after Wynn accused Okada of bribery. Okada denies wrongdoing and maintains the buyback was illegal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pan Weiming chairs the Fullsun Group, whose main business is construction and property development. Pan quit his job of a magistrate in Guangdong in 1993 and started his first property company in Guangzhou with his brother. Fullsun Group is privately held.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lirio Parisotto built his fortune through the Brazilian stock market. A former entrepreneur, he invested profits from Videolar, a video and audiotape company he founded in 1988. He avoids IPOs and favors stocks that pay high dividends. His portfolio runs the gamut from banking, electricity and mining to steel companies. In addition, Parisotto owns Brazilian bonds, real estate throughout Brazil, and a majority stake at Videolar, which merged with Innova to become a petrochemical company operating four high-tech industrial facilities: three in the Manaus Industrial Pole (in the Amazon, north of Brazil) and one at the Southern Petrochemical Pole, in southern Brazil. The self-made billionaire was born in Brazil's southern countryside. He has a degree in medicine and is a staunch conservationist; he is vice president of the Foundation for a Sustainable Amazon. Brazilian tabloids have linked Parisotto to former Brazilian Playboy cover girl and Carnaval queen Luiza Brunet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdulsamad Rabiu is the founder of BUA Group, a Nigerian conglomerate active in sugar refining, cement production, real estate, logistics and port operations. Rabiu is expanding cement production. In September 2015, BUA signed a $600 million deal with Sinoma International Engineering, a Chinese cement equipment and engineering service provider, to construct a second production line at its flagship Obu cement plant, located in Edo State in the western part of Nigeria. Rabiu's aim is to double capacity and expand BUA's current 10% market share in Nigerian cement. In January 2016, BUA Group agreed to sell its flour milling and pasta making businesses to Olam Group of Singapore for $275 million. Rabiu, the son of a businessman, inherited land from his father. He set up his own business in 1988, importing rice, sugar and edible oils as well as iron and steel rods.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Rappoport worked for two billionaires before becoming one himself. After graduating from university in Ukraine, he moved to Russia and soon became chairman of billionaire Mikhail Fridman's Alfa-Bank, a post he held from 1992 to 1996. He then became first vice president of former billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky's YUKOS-Rosprom. For a decade from 1998, he was deputy chairman and a board member of RAO UES, a former electric power holding company. After leaving Inter RAO, Rappoport bought Georgian Global Utilities, a key Georgian water and power company. He is a Russian master of sports in high-speed pistol shooting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known to all as Tony, Ressler is an industry veteran, having cofounded Apollo Management with brother-in-law and fellow billionaire Leon Black, and had a prominent role in the bond department of legendary Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert. In 1997 he cofounded  private equity and investment firm Ares Management; he took it public in 2014 and joined the ranks of the World's Billionaires that same year. Ressler owns approximately 30% of Ares, which has the backing of the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority and has invested in companies like Neiman Marcus, Samsonite and vitamin store GNC. He owns a minority stake in the Milwaukee Brewers baseball team and is the majority owner of the NBA's Atlanta Hawks. He is married to TV actress Jami Gertz.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ru Jiyong chairs wood flooring supplier Der Future Science & Technology Holding Group. After an entrepreneurial youth that reportedly included his own stereo brand in 1990 at age 22, Ru entered the field that would create his biggest fortune a decade later: flooring. Today, Der is also expanding into smart home furnishings. Ru serves as a board member at Nanjing University and Soochow University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fashion billionaire Remo Ruffini turned around nearly bankrupt jacket maker Moncler, taking it public in 2013 in one Italy's largest IPOs in years. Originally founded in 1952 by two French mountaineers, Moncler grew as its down jackets became popular on the slopes, particularly after sponsoring the French ski team in the 1968 Winter Olympics at Grenoble. The buzz fizzled, though, and towards the turn of the century Moncler was nearing bankruptcy. Enter Remo Ruffini, who in 1999 had become the company's creative director and a few years later bought the brand outright for an undisclosed amount. Ruffini got his start in the U.S. working for his father's clothing company, Gianfranco Ruffini; his only higher education consisted of a single marketing class at Boston University. He returned to Italy in 1984 and founded his own brand, New England Company, which was sold in 2000 to the Stefanel Group. At Moncler, Ruffini introduced new colors and designs while partnering with the Carlyle Group to push for internationalization. By 2003, Ruffini took the company public, seeing the stock surge nearly 50% in its first day of trading, immediately making him a billionaire. It's not all work for Ruffini, who still holds on to most of his stake and remains chairman and CEO: he spends his summers aboard his 128-foot yacht Blackwood of London sailing across the Mediterranean and most winter weekends in his restored chalet in St. Moritz, Switzerland's prime luxury ski town.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yoshiyuki Sankai, president of robot maker Cyberdyne, founded the firm in 2004 after years of tinkering with its key product, the Robot Suit HAL (Hybrid Assistive Limb), whose robot arms and legs take over when our own fail as a result of age or physical impairment. The company rents its HAL suits -- which read electrical pulses in patients' nerves and offer the potential to restore muscle movement -- to hospitals and nursing homes. In early 2016 the Japanese government approved national health insurance coverage for medical use of the suits. The company is listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martin Selig escaped Nazi Germany with his family when he was three years old, starting them on a long trek of hiding and passing through Germany and Poland before Moscow, where they snuck onto the Trans Siberian Railroad. It let them off in Korea, where they found a place in steerage on a trans-pacific steamer going to San Francisco. It stopped in Seattle one day, unplanned, and his father told them they were getting off. Martin has been in Seattle ever since, and he's now one of the biggest property developers there. He jokes about why he got into real estate: "I didn't trust the stock market." He started off building shopping malls, and now has 4 million square of properties across the city, and another 1.5 million under development, including a big historic project turning the city's former federal reserve building into a glassy office high rise. The developer is also a painter and enjoys bicycling, riding his Harley motorcycle and skiing ("I skied 42 days last year. This year, I'm going for 50," he says).  Married with three children, one daughter is in the family business, while another daughter is  a producer with two films that debuted in 2015 at the Venice Film Festival, where Martin accompanied her.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brian Sheth co-founded Vista Equity Partners in 2000 and is the firm's president. He has helped rack up one of the best records in private equity buying and fixing up an unglamorous collection of enterprise software companies. Neuberger Berman bought a stake in the $15.9 billion (assets) Austin, Texas firm in July. A graduate of University of Pennsylvania where he met his wife, he spent one year at Deutsche Bank, one year at Goldman Sachs and six months at Bain Capital. Robert Smith, who hired him at Goldman, then approached him about helping him start Vista.  The son of an Indian immigrant who worked at the Department of Environmental Conservation and a teacher, he is the founding donor and chairman of Global Wildlife Conservation. He is also a director of more than a dozen companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of 5 Infosys cofounders on the billionaires list, S.D.Shibulal oversees his family office, Innovations Investment Management, since stepping down as the company's CEO in 2014. He also chairs The Tamara, a boutique resort chain that daughter Shruti founded and runs. It is building two resorts in south India and reportedly eyeing a hotel acquisition in Germany.  Portfolio includes Lilac, a serviced apartment complex in Bangalore. Along with wife, Kumari, he has donated $11 million to their 2 family foundations, which support various causes, including education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nobutoshi Shimamura started out with one small kimono shop and turned it into one of Japan's leading discount retailers. Publicly-traded Shimamura Co. has nearly 2,000 stores, including shoe stores. In 2013, the company expanded into China and has stores in Taiwan as well. Nobutoshi Shimamura retired more than two decades ago and is no longer involved in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of U-Haul founder Leonard Samuel (L.S.) Shoen, Joe grabbed control of the business in 1986, alienating his father and most of his 12 siblings. Decades later he is still firmly in control of U-Haul. He is the president and chairman of U-Haul's $3.3 billion (sales) parent company, Amercowhich has 139,000 trucks and 108,000 trailers on the road.  Despite his problems working with his own dad, Joe's sons Stuart and Sam are both executives. Shoen debuts on The 400 due to new information tied to a restructuring.

name: Billionaires
bio: His wealth comes from his shares of Wilmar International, the company he founded 24 years ago with Kuok Khoon Hong, nephew of Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok. it's now an agri-giant with 450 manufacturing plants in 15 countries and some 90,000 employees worldwide. He also owns London skyscraper Aviva Tower. Sitorus started with something much smaller--trading shrimp. He bought his first palm oil plantation in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Spuhler, CEO of Stadler Rail, built a fortune buying up railcar makers across eastern Europe. Spuhler got his start in 1987 at a locomotive-parts manufacturer called Stadler. His wife's grandfather had started it five decades earlier, and in 1989, he bought Stadler from her grandmother for $6 million. It then employed 18 people and had $5 million in revenue. He embarked on a two-decade-long acquisition journey, buying up parts of crumbling rivals. Today, Stadler has 5,000 employees and does about $2 billion in sales. When building railcars, Stadler has favored bespoke work (while competitors stuck with a one-size-fits-all approach), and over the years, it has built cars to climb to Germany's highest peak and designed ones to withstand brutal Helsinki winters. Spuhler, a former Swiss Army officer, served for 13 years in parliament where he advocated a pro-business agenda; he favored increased immigration to Switzerland and opposed the country's minaret ban, fearing Muslim boycotts. Stadler sold 20% of his business in 2005 to a private equity shop, but later repurchased nearly all the stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shanghai-born entrepreneur Tang Hsiang-chien built a fortune in manufacturing, first in textiles and then with printed-circuit-board-maker Meadville, which he started in 1985. His son Henry served as financial secretary and then chief secretary of Hong Kong from 2003 to 2011 before running for chief executive in 2012; he lost after a series of controversies and scandals cut his support.

name: Billionaires
bio: He is the owner and CEO of BIM, Turkey's largest chain of discount stores. His daughter is married to Ali Ulker the son of another billionaire, Ahsen Ozokur. Aside from family ties, he also has business partnerships with Ulker. He also has a long standing friendship with the President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his family. The store chain BIM, of which he is the main shareholder also has branches outside Turkey in Morocco and Egypt. According to the results of this year?s third quarter, the company?s  ebitda has grown 14,7% .However since the Turkish currency has lost value this past year his wealth has decreased compared to last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kenneth Tuchman is the chairman and CEO of call center outsourcing giant TeleTech. Tuchman's personal frustration with the difficulties businesses faced when trying to interact with customers led him to found the company in 1982. The company went public in 1986. Tuchman got into business at a young age. He got his first job at 12, working at a bike shop. Three years later, he started a small venture selling puka shell necklaces to friends. Before long, he was the one of the largest shell importers from the Philippines and was selling millions of necklaces to department stores. "That was really my first look into what it's like to have a start-up business take off into high gear very quickly," Tuchman told FORBES. Tuchman studied architecture at a junior college and had planned to transfer to UCLA. Instead, he dropped out of college to pursue a variety of business ventures before starting TeleTech. Today, the company has 44,000 employees and operates in 80 countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and CEO of film production company Legendary Entertainment, Thomas Tull is a comics "fanboy" making movies for others like him. Some of his biggest hits have come from cofinancing and co-producing the Dark Knight trilogy, the Hangover series, 'Interstellar' and 'Godzilla.' In January 2015, Tull inked a deal with Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's Wanda Group to purchase Legendary for $3.5 billion. The pair are forming a new venture of which Tull will remain CEO, helming Hollywood's charge into China's swiftly expanding movie marketplace. Tull was born to a single mother in Binghamton, New York and grew up poor. After attending Hamilton College on a football scholarship, he started a chain of laundries and then purchased a string of tax-prep businesses before going to into private equity. He raised $500 million from Wall Street and headed to Hollywood to finance films in 2005. He struck a deal with Warner Bros. to cofinance and co-produce movies with the studio--some of the most successful being reboots of old comics franchises like Batman and Superman and big-budget action fare like 'Inception' and 'Pacific Rim.' In 2013 Legendary announced a new partnership with Universal Pictures. The company also has TV and comic book divisions. A sports fan, Tull has a small stake in the Pittsburgh Steelers, owns an extensive collection of baseball memorabilia and is a backer of Derek Jeter's Players' Tribune site.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tung Chee Hwa is the eldest son of shipping magnate Tung Chao Yung, who founded what has now become one of Hong Kong's largest shipping companies. After running Orient Overseas for 14 years, Chee Hwa handed over the reins to younger brother Chee Chen in order to serve as Hong Kong's first chief executive. Though he is not actively involved in management, Chee Hwa continues to hold a substantial stake in the company, where his two sons Alan and Andrew both hold executive posts.

name: Billionaires
bio: More than 60% of Surin Upatkoon's wealth comes from the 10% stake in Thai telecom InTouch he sold in 2013. The Thai national also has interests in gambling company Magnum. He started his career as a manager at his father's textile company, MWE Weaving Mills, in 1971. He made a bid for a takeover of MWE in December 2015 but later aborted it. He got his biggest break when he participated in the acquisition of a major stake in Multi-Purpose Holdings Bhd., which he later split into MPHB Capital, an insurance and real estate outfit. He's lived in Malaysia since 1965, when he arrived in Penang for school and stayed to work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Susanne Veltins is a fifth-generation family member to head C. & A. Veltins brewery, which has operated from the same site in Grevenstein, Germany since 1824. In 1852, Veltins' great-great-grandfather, Clemens Veltins, who had studied brewing in the U.S., took over his family's tavern brewery and established a legacy that garners fervent admiration from beer aficionados. Operating a state-of-the-art facility at the base of a mountain, Veltins, famous for its premium pilsner, is know for using choice ingredients including soft, crystal-clear water drawn from surrounding springs that have been safeguarded from contamination. According to a comprehensive Euromonitor report on the German beer industry, Veltins' share of the German market was 3.2% in 2013. Annual revenues are estimated at close to $800 million. Veltins is a longtime sponsor of one of the most popular soccer clubs in Germany's premiere Bundesliga, FC Schalke 04. The team's home field is the Veltins-Arena in Gelsenkirchen, which has a retractable roof and can accommodate over 60,000 fans. Susanne Veltins, who studied law, joined the company full-time in 1993 and inherited it after her mother's death in 1994. She married Peter Oser, an architect, in 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lang Walker has been in the building industry for more than half a century and has had multiple successes. He sold the bulk of his property development company, Walker Corp., twice before: in 1999 before the dot-com bust, and again in 2006, just before the financial crisis hit. He has since quickly rebuilt an empire that now has office towers, industrial estates and residential projects. Now he's looking to sell his biggest property, the $2 billion Collins Square project in Melbourne. He owns a fleet of yachts, all called Kokomo after his childhood dinghy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Wanzhen chairs advanced ceramics maker Chaozhou Three-Circle Group, which trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. Zhang joined the workforce at age 16 after finishing junior high school. Chaozhou Three-Circle Group was founded in 1970 as a state-owned business. The ownership was restructured in 1992, and the company today makes ceramic products for optic telecommunication, machinery, and environmental protection. Customers include advanced fuel cell maker Bloom Energy, fiber optics producer Amphenol and semiconductor firm Vishay.

name: Billionaires
bio: Online and mobile game entrepreneur Wang Yue is the CEO of Shanghai Kingnet Technology.  He joined the ranks of the world's youngest billionaires after the company successfully completed a backdoor listing in China in December 2015. Wang received 148.7 million new shares, or 22% of Shenzhen-listed footwear materials maker Taiya Shoes, in exchange for his 29.7% stake in Kingnet. Qifei Investment, which is 1.1% owned by Wang, received another 43.9 million new shares, or a 6.5% stake in the listed company for its stake in Kingnet. Kingnet was founded by Qian Hua and Feng Xianchao in 2008 with 100,000 yuan. Wang paid about $9,600 to Qian Hua in August 2009 for a 62.5% stake in the company. Wang, formerly an executive at 51.com in China, has since built Kingnet into a leading online and mobile game developer in China. Kingnet also runs a popular mobile phone application platform, xy.com.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prem Watsa founded Toronto-based financial services firm Fairfax Financial Holdings in 1985 and remains its chairman and CEO. Born in Hyderabad, India, he later joined his brother in Canada, and then enrolled in the University of Western Ontario's MBA program. He paid his way through school by selling appliances door-to-door. After a stint as an investment analyst, Watsa struck out on his own in 1984. He began snatching up insurance companies, modeling his business after the success of his idol: Warren Buffett. Fairfax now maintains property and casualty insurance and reinsurance interests across four continents and holds stakes in numerous companies, including IBM and phone maker BlackBerry. He also owns a stake in Fairfax India, a publicly traded subsidiary investing in Indian businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gjert Wilhelmsen and his family own about 7% of publicly traded Royal Caribbean, the cruise ship company that Gjert's brother Arne (also a billionaire) cofounded in 1969. Holding company A Wilhelmsen A S, owned by the Wilhelmsen family is active in real estate, shipping, retail and asset management. Gjert earned a degree as a naval architect from The University of Trondheim.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gustav Magnar Witzoe, 22, owns 47% of Salmar ASA's equity but none of the control, after his father gifted him all his B-class shares in 2013. The Norwegian salmon producer, one of the world's largest, was founded by Witzoe's father (also called Gustav Witzoe) in 1991. Salmar has lead the industrialisation of fish farming in Norway, refining the product that before primarily had been exported as gutted and frozen into a more sophisticated cuts with higher margins. Fish farming is now one of Norway's biggest industries. Witzoe's father still runs the company and has a seat on the board of directors. The younger Witzoe, without a role in Salmar, has ventured out on his own as a real estate and tech start-up investor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Allan Wong cofounded electronic toymaker Vtech Holdings. His net worth fell by a half-billion dollars over the course of a year as sales of his electronic-learning devices and cordless phones continue to slip in the U.S, his largest market. His contract manufacturing of audio equipment and wireless and LED light products continues to do well, but it's little more than a quarter of total sales. Wong is the deputy chairman of the Bank of East Asia, and an independent non-executive director of China- Hongkong Photo Products Holdings and sourcing and logistics giant Li & Fung.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swift Xie heads up marketing at SZ Dajiang Innovation Technology Co. (known as DJI), the world's largest consumer drone manufacturer. Xie, who was high school friends with DJI founder and CEO Frank Wang, owns an estimated 14% stake in the company, which was expected to hit $1 billion in 2015 revenue. Some analysts estimate that DJI has 70% of the consumer unmanned aerial vehicle market through sales of its trademark Phantom drones, which retail for around $1,000. In May 2015 DJI raised $75 million from U.S. venture capital firm Accel Partners, valuing the company at $8 billion.
title: Entrepreneur
employment: {'name': 'DJI Technology Co.', 'title': 'Chief Marketing Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Yao Xinyi is the chairman of Zhejiang Dun'an Artificial Environment, a supplier of air conditioning and ventilation systems. He also has a stake in Anhui Jiangnan Chemical Industry, a Shenzhen-listed company that produces explosives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert Yeung is ubiquitous in Hong Kong through his Emperor Watch & Jewellery chain and long-time links to Canto-pop and movie stars. His Emperor International Holdings also counts property and--in North Korea and Macau--casino interests. The Macau casino sports red-coated faux Coldstream Guards and real gold bars imbedded in the lobby floor. The self-made tycoon says he always carries 40,000 or 50,000 in Hong Kong dollars to ward off feelings of inferiority.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yin Xingman chairs Shenzhen-listed Xinzhi Motor, a supplier of automotive motor parts. Yin and his family own nearly 61% of the company. His family has been in the industry since the 1970s. Yin and his family ran a canned food factory in the 1990s and operated coal and steel trading businesses prior to 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yu Peidi is the chairman of China real estate developer Greattown Holdings. Founded in 1986, the company went public on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gavril Yushvaev has gotten rich betting on everything from a dance club to a juice and dairy company to a gold producer. His latest bet was a $25 million investment alongside billionaire Len Blavatnik in a biotech. In the early 90s he cofounded Trinity, which owned car dealerships, one of Moscow's first casinos and Moscow dance club Metelitsa. He later invested in dairy and juice company Wimm-Bill-Dann, which went public in 2002. The prospectus revealed that Yushvaev had served nine years in a Soviet prison camp after being found guilty of a "violent crime" in 1980.  Yushvaev sold his 19.6% stake in Wimm-Bill-Dann to Pepsico for $1.1 billion in 2010. Three years later, he and billionaire Zelimkhan Mutsoev bought billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov's 38% stake in gold producer Polyus Gold for $3.6 billion. He sold his stake to companies owned by billionaire Suleiman Kerimov's son in 2015. He also partnered with Vladislav Doronin, an ex-boyfriend of supermodel Naomi Campbell, investing $300 million in a 4.3-million-square-foot Moscow real estate development that will include an 85-story tower, a boutique hotel, offices, a multiplex and parking for 3,900 cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhai Meiqin is co-founder with billionaire husband Liu Zhiqiang of the Heung Kong Group. From an early focus on furniture retailing in the 1990s, the couple's empire today includes real estate and investment. They also have stakes in GF Securities and Guangdong Nanyue Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhongneng is the controlling shareholder of Shanghai-listed Guangdong HEC Technology Holding, a producer of aluminum foil. He also invests in pharmaceutical firms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Antti Aarnio-Wihuri heads Wihuri Group, a Finnish conglomerate that has been in his family for over 100 years. The group, which employs 5,000 people, has interests in the packaging, technical trade, food wholesale and aviation sectors, and operates Caterpillar construction equipment dealerships, Metro daily goods wholesale stores and a private jet charter and ambulance service. He is the largest shareholder of Winpak, a Canadian company that specializes in producing packaging materials.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hamdi Akin joins the billionaires list as his Afken Holding, a conglomerate with investments in airports, energy, tourism, and infrastructure, continues to grow. Akin began his career producing fuel tanks in his father's workshop. After graduating from university, he founded Akfen as a contracting company where he won tenders for operating the Istanbul Ataturk Airport and the Ankara Esenboga Airport. His successes here led him to establish TAV Airports Holding; 38% of its shares were sold in 2012 to the Aeroports de Paris Group for 874 million dollars. His daughter Pelin Akin and son Selim Akin are also on the board of Akfen Holding.

name: Billionaires
bio: When Mohed Altrad moved to France from Syria 46 years ago, he didn't speak French and survived on one meal a day. Now he heads Montpellier-based Altrad Group, one of the world's leading manufacturers of scaffolding and cement mixers, with a presence in more than 100 countries. After acquiring competitor Hertel in 2015, the group doubled its annual revenues to more than $2 billion and has 16,700 employees. Altrad's current station is a world a way from his beginnings as an orphaned Bedouin in the Syrian desert. Altrad's mother died when he was around 4, and his father disowned him. Altrad was raised by his grandmother, who banned him from going to school. He attended anyway, eventually winning a scholarship to study in France, where he earned an undergraduate degree in physics and math and a Ph.D. in computer science. After stints at tech firms and the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, he bought a bankrupt scaffolding manufacturer in southern France with a partner in 1985. Despite knowing nothing about the industry, he led the firm to turn a profit and has expanded ever since. Altrad also owns a majority stake in Montpellier H√©rault Rugby and has written three acclaimed novels, including semi-autobiographical Badawi; an English-language version will be published in the U.S. in 2016. Altrad was named Ernst & Young's World Entrepreneur of the Year in 2016.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexei Ananyev began his career importing computers to Russia with his brother, fellow billionaire Dmitry Ananyev. The two then founded a bank named Promsvyazbank and have also invested in real estate and media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general strategy. Their company Technoserv is Russia's biggest in systems integration. The brothers own Novospassky Dvor, a 21.5-acre business district along the Moscow River, and business park Pressa, a former printing house. They also own Alfa Arbat Center, an office complex in central Moscow. In 2010 they sold their telecom company, Synterra, to billionaire Alisher Usmanov's Megafon for $745 million. Both brothers are very religious. Alexei owns the largest collection of Socialist realist art in Russia and opened a museum to display it in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dimitry Ananyev began his career importing computers to Russia with his brother, Alexei. The two then founded Promsvyazbank, now one of Russia's largest private banks, where they continue to own the controlling stake. In February 2016, Dmitry became CEO. In 2015 they bought another bank: Vozrozhdenie. The brothers have also invested in real estate and media. Among their real estate holdings: the Alfa Arbat Center, an office complex in central Moscow they bought in 2011 for $230 million. In 2010 they sold their telecom company, Synterra, to billionaire Alisher Usmanov's Megafon for $745 million.  Both brothers are very religious. From 2006 to 2013, Dmitry represented the gas-rich polar region of Yamal in Russia's Federation Council. He quit after a new law barred government officials from holding bank accounts or other financial assets abroad.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Austin opened his first hearing-aid repair shop in 1967 in St. Louis Park, Minnesota, laying the first brick in what today is one of the world's largest hearing aids companies, Starkey Hearing Technologies. The private company sells about 900,000 hearing aids a year, and its customers have reportedly included five U.S. presidents, two popes and singer Dolly Parton. Austin, the company's sole shareholder, no longer runs the company. Instead he focuses on the Starkey Hearing Foundation, which receives a cut of every product Starkey Hearing Technologies sells. To date the foundation has donated 1 million hearing aids around the world to people who can't afford them.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roman Avdeev controls the Credit Bank of Moscow, one of Russia's biggest by assets. The bank, in which he has a nearly 57% stake, went public in June 2015.  He bought nearly two-thirds of a pharmacy chain called A5 in December 2015 and plans to combine it with 36.6, another pharmacy chain that he owns. He also picked up several residential real estate developments in Moscow. Avdeev began his career making decoders in the late 1980s before buying a bank in the 1990s. Avdeev has 23 children, 19 of them adopted. He is vegetarian and practices yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Rustu Basaran heads Habas Industrial and Medical Gases Production Industries, a leader in industrial and medical gases and one of Turkey's largest producers of steel. The company operates in banking, energy, heavy machinery industry; distributing Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and Compressed Natural Gas (CNG), offering sea transportation services for LPG and operating sea ports. The company was founded in 1956 in Istanbul Topkapi by his father Hamdi Basaran under the name "Hamdi Basaran Topkapi Oxygen Plant "and his sister Aysel Basaran Tugluk is also a small shareholder. Basaran is known for his passion for fast cars, but he never appears in public. Ever since he bought Anadolu Bank during its privatization in 1997, he has never been photographed by the press.

name: Billionaires
bio: As founder of Newegg, Fred Chang oversees an electronics web retailer, which does more than $2.5 billion in sales a year. Newegg caters to computer geeks and hardcore gamers, selling PC parts and other accessories. Chang's stake is estimated to be more than 50% in Newegg, which filed for an initial public offering in 2010 but withdrew its plans a year later. The company opened up its business to the U.K. and Australia in 2014.
title: CEO and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Leon Charney, a New York real estate mogul, entertainment lawyer, TV show host and sometime diplomat, died on March 21, 2016. He was 77. Forbes had estimated his net worth at $1 billion. The son of a sewing supply salesman, Charney inherited the small sum of $34 from his father. He paid his way through Brooklyn Law School by singing in synagogues. As an entertainment lawyer he represented stars including Sammy Davis, Jr. He built his practice by maximizing tax benefits for oil partnerships. Charney also became an adviser to President Jimmy Carter and helped broker the Camp David peace accords between Egypt and Israel in 1978. On the night Carter lost his re-election in 1980, Charney bought his first building, One Times Square. He published several books in his lifetime and in 1998 began hosting the New York weekly public affairs cable TV program ?The Leon Charney Report." At the time of his death, he owned three skyscrapers in Times Square. He is survived by his wife, Tzili, and twin sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Jiancheng is the chairman of China's Wolong Holding Group. The group's Shanghai-listed unit, Wolong Electric, supplies motors for industrial use and power transmission equipment. Chen's real estate arm, Wolong Real Estate, is also listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Chen was born in Shangyu, Zhejiang Province and started working at age 16. In 1984, he quit a factory job and cofounded the predecessor to Wolong with six fellow workers. Looking abroad for growth, Wolong Electric acquired the parent company of ATB Group of Austria in 2011, making it one of the largest suppliers of electric drive systems for industrial applications in Europe. Chen's daughter Yanni chairs Wolong Real Estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Jiangtao is the chairman of Shenzhen-listed Beijing Watertek Information Technology, a provider of embedded testing products. He received an undergraduate degree from Nanchang University in 1983 and a master's degree from the Harbin Institute of Technology in 1989. Chen went on to work for aerospace and electronics companies before he founded Watertek in 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mainland-born Bruce Cheng was a pioneer in Taiwan's postwar electronics industry when he founded Delta Electronics in 1971, then a TV parts maker. The company has since evolved into a supplier of components such as switches, game consoles, laptops and power supplies to the computer industry. Among its customers are Dell, IBM and Fujitsu. Cheng retired in 2012. Son Ping is now CEO. Although he has been lauded for restructuring management to boost new ideas, Delta's sales and stock have faltered.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheng Wei is CEO of ride-hailing firm Didi Kuaidi, which was formed in early 2015 when Cheng's company Didi Dache merged with Alibaba-backed competitor Kuaidi Dache. Before founding Didi Dache, Cheng spent 8 years at e-commerce firm Alibaba and became vice president for Alibaba's online payment service Alipay. He also goes by Will Wei.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cho Jung-Ho, chairman of Meritz Financial Group, is the youngest of the four sons of Hanjin Group founder Cho Choong-Hoon, who started out with a single truck and went on to built an empire based mostly on transportation. Choong-Hoon died in 2002, having divided his companies, including Korean Airlines (KAL) and a major container shipper,  among his sons. Feuding erupted over how the assets were divvied up, and Jung-Ho is no longer on speaking terms with this oldest brother, Cho Yang-Ho, who heads KAL. After attending boarding schools in Massachusetts and California, Jung-Ho studied economics at the University of Southern California. He worked for several years for KAL in Europe before getting his M.B.A. from the International Institute for Management Development (IMD) in Switzerland. He returned home in 1989 as a director with Hanjin Investment & Securities, as Meritz was then named. Known for his laser focus and intense work ethic, Jung-Ho has amply proven his own merit in building the "leftovers" he inherited into a diversified financial services giant -- and stock market darling -- that lives up to its name. Meritz Financial is active in insurance, investment banking, asset management, securities brokerage and trading.

name: Billionaires
bio: A so-called Tiger Cub who worked for famed hedge fund manager Julian Robertson, Citrone founded Discovery Capital Management in 1999. His hedge funds tend to make macro bets and invest in emerging markets. In 2016, after losing money for two straight years, his Discovery Global Macro Fund produced a 9% gain, reportedly from stock bets made in the last two months of the year. Citrone was a wrestler in high school and today owns a small slice of his favorite football team, the Pittsburgh Steelers.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Husain Djojonegoro has become a billionaire by supplying Indonesia with life's necessities. His ABC Group controls the country's largest producer of batteries (Intercallin), as well as a broader manufacturing unit (Orang Tua). He runs the businesses with his two brothers. Orang Tua's goods range from toothbrushes to cookies to tea. His family started with his father selling a stronger drink: herbal wine.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Under the age of 40, tattooed entrepreneur Jack Dorsey has been running two tech heavyweights: Twitter and Square. At Twitter, cofounder Dorsey is back as CEO after the departure of Dick Costolo in June 2015. Since taking back the reigns, Dorsey fired 8% of Twitter's staff and promised a third of his shares to the remaining employees. Dorsey is also heading payments company Square, which he cofounded in 2009; Square went public in November 2015 at a stock price well below its latest $6 billion private valuation. A self-taught computer coder, Dorsey dropped out of New York University in 1999, became a certified masseur and dabbled in fashion design before gravitating fully to tech. In 2006, with Ev Williams, Biz Stone and Noah Glass, he cofounded Twitter and was the company's chief executive until 2008.
title: Entrepreneur
employment: {'name': 'Square, Inc.', 'title': 'CEO and Cofounder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Dou Zhenggang leads Hangzhou Jinjiang Group, one of China's largest private-sector companies in the waste incineration industry. Dou made his early fortune in textiles, starting his first business in 1983 in Zhejiang Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alfredo Egydio de Arruda Villela Filho is a low-profile member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families. He is the largest individual shareholder of Itausa, the bank's holding company. Alfredo's great-grandfather founded Itau, one of Brazil's largest banks, which merged with Unibanco in 2008 to form Itau-Unibanco, Latin America's biggest non-state bank. Itau-Unibanco denied any wrongdoing. Business acumen runs in the family: Alfredo's grandfather founded publicly-traded Duratex, a Brazilian maker of wood paneling and bathroom fixtures, which Alfredo also owns a stake of. With his sister, Ana Lucia, Alfredo supports the Alana Institute, a non-profit organization they co-founded in 1994 to promote social work, education and culture. The siblings lost their parents in a plane crash in 1982, and were raised by their aunt, Maria de Lourdes, who has also been listed as a billionaire thanks to her shares in Itau-Unibanco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Piero Ferrari, Vice Chairman of Ferrari SpA and son of the founder of one of the world's most famous luxury race car companies, became a billionaire when Ferrari N.V. listed its shares in October 2015; he owns a 10% stake. The company went public as part of a spin off from Fiat Chrysler, which officially took place in early January 2016. Piero has served as Vice Chairman of Ferrari since 1988, the same year that his father Enzo Ferrari died. Piero is Enzo's illegitimate son with longtime mistress Lina Lardi. Enzo's first son Alfredo, called Dino, was primed to be the Ferrari heir before his untimely death due to muscular dystrophy in 1956. This left Piero as Enzo's only son - however, reportedly he was not legally recognized as part of the Ferrari family until the death of Enzo's wife Laura in 1978. He is now the sole heir of what has been called the world's most powerful brand. He is also the Chairman of HPE COXA, a moto-industry engineering services company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fireman bought the U.S. distribution rights for a small British shoe company in 1979, turned it into Reebok and rode the craze of sneakers amid the 1980s aerobics trend. Nike pulled ahead early 1990s, and shareholders demanded Fireman step down 1996. He responded with a two-year deadline to increase sales or step down, which he eventually did. But he returned in 1999 and restored the business before spinning it to Adidas, a deal that earned him $600 million. Fireman has since continued to invest in sports and owns Liberty National Golf Course, a $250 million country club built on a New Jersey landfill overlooking the Statue of Liberty. The club is one of the most exclusive courses in the world, with members paying $500,000 to join.

name: Billionaires
bio: J. Christopher Flowers has a taste for the most precarious assets in the financial services industry. In 2008, he helped advise Bank of America and Merrill Lynch on the spur of the moment merger that helped stabilize the U.S. banking system. He was reportedly among the first to warn Secretary of the Treasury Henry Paulson of the impending crisis. Eight years earlier, J.C. Flowers and Co. focused on a similarly beleaguered bank in Japan, the Long Term Credit Bank, which had been nationalized in 1998 after the burst of Japan's asset bubble. Flowers later resold the business to the public under the moniker Shinsei Bank. In 2012, he moved to London in search of opportunities to profit from Europe's financial woes. Flowers' focus on banks hasn't always served him well. His JC Flowers II fund has reportedly lost up to half of its value in the wake of the 2008 crisis. Flowers graduated from Harvard University in 1979.
title: Founder and Managing Director
employment: {'name': 'J.C. Flowers & Co. LLC', 'title': 'Founder and Managing Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Donald Friese's fortune stems from C.R. Laurence, which manufactures or distributes more than 65,000 products for the glass industry. The company sells everything from frameless shower door hardware to display cases and cleaning supplies -- everything but the glass itself. Friese grew up poor in rural Pennsylvania, and enlisted in the Army straight out of high school in 1958. Three years later he moved to California with $125 in his pocket. He landed in the warehouse of C.R. Laurence, which was just a small distributor of supplies. Friese was employee number six. He climbed the ladder, steadily amassing equity in the company until he owned 100%. He expanded by purchasing competitors and moving into manufacturing. In August 2015, Friese sold C.R. Laurence to Oldcastle BuildingEnvelope, a subsidiary of Irish building-materials conglomerate CRH for $1.3 billion. Out of his proceeds from the deal -- about $885 million after taxes -- Friese gave his employees $85 million. All 1,600 of the employees who had worked for the company for than a year got a bonus check -- some got more than $1 million. Despite cashing out, Friese continues to run the company's day-to-day operations. He works 12 hour days during the week, plus a half-day every Saturday.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fu Kwan leads the Macrolink Group of Beijing. The group's Macrolink Real Estate Co. trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. It develops real estate, sells construction materials and leases office properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gao Dekang is the founder and chairman of Bosideng International Holdings, one of the world's largest manufacturers of down jackets. The company trades on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Bosideng has struggled as a result of the explosion of e-commerce and foreign fast fashion competitors. Gao's father taught him how to sew.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suzhou entrepreneur Don Gao started manufacturing hand tools and won a large order for angle grinders -- a handheld tool for cutting and grinding -- from U.S. tool giant Black & Decker in the 1990s. After Black & Decker decided to make the grinders itself, Gao launched his own brand, Worx. His firm, Positec, is now one of China's largest producers of power tools; its tools are sold at retailers such as Lowe's, Home Depot and Sears in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Valentin Gapontsev is considered by Russians to be the father of the fiber-optic laser industry. In 1990, at age 51, he founded IPG Photonics, which produces high-power fiber-optic lasers for cutting materials and telecommunications. The company is based in Oxford, Mass., but operates all over the world. He studied laser physics at the Soviet Academy of Science's Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics. Gapontsev holds Russian and U.S. citizenships and lives in Worcester, Mass.

name: Billionaires
bio: Craft beer pioneer Ken Grossman founded Sierra Nevada brewery in 1978 when there were only 45 independent breweries in America. Today, the $100 billion-a-year industry is dominated by global giants like Anheuser-Busch InBev. But big beer is stagnant, and double-digit growth is coming from higher-price, bolder-flavor craft beers made by smaller brewers. Sierra Nevada is famous for its Pale Ale; company revenues grew to  $300 million in 2015. Grossman, whose son runs a new brewery in North Carolina, is keenly aware of Sierra Nevada's environmental impact. More than 10,000 solar panels are installed at the original Chico, California brewery, and 99.8% of the facility's waste is recycled.

name: Billionaires
bio: Most of Achmad Hamami's fortune comes from Trakindo Utama, Caterpillar's Indonesia distributor. In addition, he has a license to operate Carl's Jr. burger restaurants and LOKA supermarkets. He turned over the reins to his son Muki after he lost his sight to glaucoma in 1999. Hamami was a former Navy jet pilot and the youngest colonel in the Indonesian military. He got his start as a private math tutor before getting a job with a state investment fund which put him in touch with Caterpillar.

name: Billionaires
bio: He Zhiping's fortune comes from investments in several Chinese companies: Shenzhen-listed Shanghai RAAS Blood Products, Qinhuangdao Tianye Tolian Heavy Industry and Telling Telecommunication Holding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ilona Herlin is the great-granddaughter of Finnish business legend Herald Herlin, who invested in Kone Elevators in 1924. After her father's death in 2003, Illona and her siblings Ilkka and Niklas discovered their father had rewritten his will in 1999 and left most of the ownership in Kone to their brother Antti. Angered that they had never been informed, the siblings battled for control. The dispute ended in 2005, with Kone being split in two. Antti maintained control over the core elevator business and received a majority stake in Kone, while his three siblings were given a majority stake in Cargotec, which produces machinery that handles heavy duty cargo for ships and ports, and a minority stake in Kone. All four siblings are billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Hindawi cofounded cybersecurity firm Tanium with his son Orion in 2007. The duo previously started BigFix, an IT software patching system that they sold to IBM for $400 million in 2010. By then, the Hindawis already had moved on to Tanium, building the software in secret for five years before unveiling a new, super-fast way to scan and control security across thousands of networked computers in a company. In September 2015, they raised $120 million in new funding that valued Tanium at $3.5 billion, doubling their valuation of five months prior. In February 2016, Orion took over as CEO from his father, but in practice they co-manage Tanium. David is an immigrant who was born in Baghdad, grew up in Israel, and went to UC Berkeley to earn a PhD.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Orion Hindawi cofounded cybersecurity firm Tanium with his father David in 2007. The duo previously started BigFix, an IT software patching system that they sold to IBM for $400 million in 2010. By then, the Hindawis already had moved on to Tanium, building the software in secret for five years before unveiling a new, super-fast way to scan and control security across thousands of networked computers in a company. In September 2015, they raised $120 million from investors who valued Tanium at $3.5 billion. In February 2016, Orion took over as CEO from his father, but in practice he is co-managing Tanium with his dad. In November, Orion said in a media interview that Tanium may go public in 2017. Orion's father David was born in Baghdad, grew up in Israel, and went to UC Berkeley to earn a PhD. Orion also ended up at Berkeley in 1997, but dropped out before graduating to work with his father.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian property tycoon Niranjan Hiranandani cofounded Hiranandani Group with brother Surendra who now owns his independent venture. The brothers still own some assets jointly, mainly a township in suburban Mumbai. In what was billed as Mumbai's largest office lease deal, software giant Tata Consultancy Services signed a 15 year contract in January for 1.9 million square feet. Niranjan is now betting on India's infrastructure buildout: he is building a natural gas storage terminal in West Bengal and another on the west coast. His bid for a new airport near Mumbai along with Zurich Airport is awaiting security clearance. New projects include two budget hotels in Dubai, one to be managed by Accor under Ibis Styles and the other by Starwood, branded Aloft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surendra Hiranandani, the younger brother of Mumbai developer Niranjan Hiranandani, runs his independent outfit, the House of Hiranandani, which specializes in luxury residences. Daughter Neha, a University of Virginia grad, who helps him run the company, has moved to London and will oversee an expansion abroad. Surendra too has set up base in Singapore. He still owns 50% in older projects that he built along with brother Niranjan, notably the Powai township in suburban mumbai. The brothers are in the process of divvying up their jointly owned assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: A third-generation retail business owner, Daniel Hirschfeld is the chairman of The Buckle, a casual clothing, footwear and accessories chain. His grandfather opened a men's clothing store in Nebraska in the early 1900s, and dad David founded the current business when he bought Mills Clothing in 1948. The family purchased a second store, Brass Buckle, in 1967. Under Daniel Hirschfeld, the stores took a different direction, focusing on denim and adding women's clothing in the 1970s.  Today the publicly traded company operates more than 460 stores in 44 states and has its own branded merchandise; denim accounted for over 40% of 2014 sales.  Hirschfeld stepped down as CEO in 1991, but he derives the majority of his fortune from the one-third stake he owns in The Buckle. He is also the president of Hirschfeld Family Foundation, which supports educational and medical causes, among others.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Ra-Hee is the director of Leeum Samsung Museum of Art and the wife of Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-Hee -- Korea's richest individual. In May 2014, he suffered a heart attack and was hospitalized amidst a major restructuring of the family empire driven in part by the need to prepare for transferring control to the next generation. Since then, little concrete information has emerged about Lee's condition or Samsung's plan for succession (although his only son, billionaire Jay Y. Lee, vice chairman of Samsung Electronics, has long been groomed as heir apparent). Hong Ra-Hee's billionaire daughters both hold the position of president at affiliate Samsung C&T. Lee Seo-Hyun heads the company's fashion division, while Lee Boo-Jin oversees resort, theme park and construction activities. Hong's personal stake in Samsung Electronics  -- 1.083 million shares -- makes her a billionaire. Her father, Hong Jin-Ki, was chairman of one of Korea's largest-circulation newspapers, JoongAng Daily, currently run by her brother Hong Suk-Hyeon. Although not involved in Samsung's management, Hong is active in running the museum and in philanthropic work. She is known for being a prolific buyer of art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Drew Houston is CEO of Dropbox, a file sharing service he cofounded in 2007, when he was 24, with MIT classmate Arash Ferdowsi. The company was valued at $10 billion in January 2014 after it raised more than $1.1 billion from venture capital firms Sequoia Capital, Accel Partners and others. The service boasted 500 million users in late 2016 and has been shifting its focus from consumer to business applications. Several mutual funds have written down the value of their investments in Dropbox, reportedly reflecting declines in value among publicly-traded competitors and the fact that Dropbox hasn't raised money in nearly two years. FORBES has lowered our estimate of the company's value to $8 billion; Houston owns an estimated 13% stake. Houston (pronounced like the New York City street, not the Texas city) has reportedly explored taking the company public as early as 2017. He started playing around on computers when he was very young and got involved in startups during high school.
title: Cofounder and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Bingwen is the founder of Shantou Dongfeng Printing, a manufacturer of paper packaging for cigarettes. Shantou Dongfeng went public on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2012. Huang stepped down as chairman in 2010. Today, his son Huang Xiaojia, who used to be known as Huang Jiaer, chairs the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morris Kahn made his fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. He sold nearly $1 billion worth of shares after Amdocs went public in 1998.  Kahn now lives on the Israeli coast and spends most of his time on a 100-foot yacht. He is a cofounder of Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations such as the Bahamas and Australia. His son Benjamin is a marine biologist and president of Coral World. Through his Aurum Ventures, Morris has invested in several emerging life science and tech companies like Atlantium, which specializes in water disinfection, and N-Trig, which makes a touch screen for computers. He is also an active "venture philanthropist" with recent investments in digital learning platform Time to Learn and 3D printing company Nano Dimension. He also invests in Israeli youth program SpaceIL, which is designed to get kids interested in space exploration and has announced plans for a trip to the moon in 2017.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Mathias and Peter, Jonas Kamprad has inherited the fortune and responsibility previously held by his father, Ikea founder Ingvar Kamprad.  Ikea's founder, Kamprad ranked among the top 10 richest people in the world for five years thanks to Forbes' estimate of the global furniture giant, but his net worth took a drastic slide in 2011 after his lawyers produced documents proving that he had irrevocably transferred the majority of his stake in Ikea to entities beyond his economic control decades earlier. The three brothers still own Ikano Group, which originally was created to manage Ikea's real estate, insurance and financial services, but was spun off as a separate company in 1988. Today Ikano Group is a $7 billion (annual sales) company that operates across Europe and Asia with interest in banking, real estate and shopping centres. Jonas, the middle child, got his education in industrial and furniture design in Switzerland, and has applied his skills in Ikea-run subsidiary Habitat. He is a board member of Netherlands-based Ikea parent Stichting INGKA Foundation and Ikano Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Peter and Jonas, Mathias Kamprad has inherited the fortune and responsibility previously held by his father, Ikea founder Ingvar Kamprad.  Ikea's founder, Kamprad ranked among the top 10 richest people in the world for five years thanks to Forbes' estimate of the global furniture giant, but his net worth took a drastic slide in 2011 after his lawyers produced documents proving that he had irrevocably transferred the majority of his stake in Ikea to entities beyond his economic control decades earlier. The three brothers still own Ikano Group, which originally was created to manage Ikea's real estate, insurance and financial services, but was spun off as a separate company in 1988. Today Ikano Group is a $7 billion (annual sales) company that operates across Europe and Asia with interest in banking, real estate and shopping centres. Mathias, the youngest son, is the chairman of Inter Ikea, the owner of the intellectual property assets of the Ikea group, and sits on the board of Ikano Group.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With brothers Jonas and Mathias, Peter Kamprad has inherited the fortune and responsibility previously held by his father, Ikea founder Ingvar Kamprad.  Ikea's founder, Kamprad ranked among the top 10 richest people in the world for five years thanks to Forbes' estimate of the global furniture giant, but his net worth took a drastic slide in 2011 after his lawyers produced documents proving that he had irrevocably transferred the majority of his stake in Ikea to entities beyond his economic control decades earlier. The three brothers still own Ikano Group, which originally was created to manage Ikea's real estate, insurance and financial services, but was spun off as a separate company in 1988. Today Ikano Group is a $7 billion (annual sales) company that operates across Europe and Asia with interest in banking, real estate and shopping centres.  
Peter, the oldest son, got his Ikea training by running the Belgian operations for 12 years. He is now chairman of the Ikano Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Natural resource investor Thomas Kaplan became fascinated with commodities as a doctoral student studying history at Oxford University, where he wrote his dissertation on how demand for tin and rubber effected the Malayan counterinsurgency. In 1993, he founded Apex Silver Mines to cash in on the metal's rising prices and left the company in 2004. He founded Leor Exploration & Production in 2003 and sold the company's natural gas field for $2.55 billion in 2007, investing the proceeds in gold and silver. Kaplan has developed a reputation for being bullish on gold, and he correctly predicted the steep increase in the commodity's price following the Great Recession. He serves as the executive chairman of Panthera, a foundation dedicated to the preservation of wild cats that he cofounded with his wife Daphne in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kenji Kasahara founded social networking site Mixi. When he first launched it in 2004, investors believed he could overtake Facebook because of the unique privacy and sharing features on his platform. After a meteoric rise, by 2013 he was losing customers and investors as competitors raced ahead. He stepped down as CEO and refocused his business on mobile gaming and e-commerce, including dating and apartment hunting. His hugely popular Monster Strike game has been downloaded more than 20 million times.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kharitonin created Farmstandart toghether with his partner Roman Abramovich and other Sibneft shareholders by combining five factories bought from US ICN Pharmaceuticals in 2003. In 2008, a year after Farmstandart went IPO in London with the company being estimated by investors at $2.2b, Kharitonin and Egor Kulkov bought out their partners' stakes. In summer of 2013 Farmstandart acquired Singapore Bever Pharmaceutical for $590m. Farmstandart owns eight drug factories in Kursk, Ufa, Tomsk, Vladimir and Kharkov (Ukraine), and a medical equipment factory in Tyumen. The company is one of the leaders on Russian drug market. In 2016 shareholders plan to delist Farmstandart and make the company private.

name: Billionaires
bio: Habil Khorakiwala chairs Wockhardt, a pharma company he founded in 1967 after breaking away from his family's storied retailing empire. Today it is among India's top generics makers, getting 72% of its $670 million revenues from overseas. Its shares took a hit after a U.S. import ban on drugs made at 2 of its factories, but an approval from the U.K.'s health regulator for one factory partially restored investor confidence. Younger son Murtaza runs the company. Daughter Zahabiya oversees the hospital arm while another son heads the charitable foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Singapore budget hotelier turned property magnate Koh Wee Meng continued expanding in Australia, announcing plans to build two new hotels in Hobart, Tasmania.
