His Singapore-listed Fragrance Group is also developing a 77-story tower in the Australian city, which will feature close to 800 apartments and a 187-room hotel. Son of a jeweler and school teacher, Koh broke away from the family's jewelry business, now known as Aspial, to start his own property venture in the 1990s. He was once known as the Geylang King for Fragrance's beginnings in Singapore's red light district.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yuriy Kosiuk heads MHP, the Ukraine?s biggest producer of poultry. The son of teachers, he studied food process engineering at Kiev Food Industry Institute. He got his start importing furniture and Turkmenistan gas. He then began trading grain after the Soviet Union's collapse and eventually moved into poultry. He took MHP, the precursor of which he founded in 1998 with 10 employees, public in 2008. Kosiuk pays himself handsomely through dividends and has used the cash to buy himself airplanes, a helicopter, a yacht and several cars including a Lamborghini.

name: Billionaires
bio: When Al Lerner died in 2002, his daughter Nancy inherited a piece of his banking fortune. The son of Russian immigrants, Al started as a furniture salesman, invested his earnings in Cleveland-area real estate, then got into finance. He bought control of Equitable Bancorp in 1981, merged it with Maryland National in 1989 and spun off credit card giant MBNA two years later. The family sold MBNA to Bank of America  in 2005 for $35 billion in stock and cash. Al Lerner brought pro football back to Cleveland in 1999. His family sold the Cleveland Browns to billionaire Jimmy Haslam for $987 million in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norma Lerner is the widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Al was born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, and invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. He bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to Bank of America.¬†Al returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999 and owned the team until his death. His family sold it to billionaire Jimmy Haslam for $987 million in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Randolph Lerner owns the English Premier League soccer team Aston Villa. His father Al (d. 2002) worked as a furniture salesman, invested his earnings in Cleveland-area real estate, then made a fortune in finance. Al bought control of Equitable Bancorp in 1981, merged it with Maryland National in 1989, and spun off credit card giant MBNA in 1991. After his death, the family sold MBNA to Bank of America for $35 billion in stock and cash. They also sold the NFL's Browns, which Al had returned to Cleveland in 1999. Randy bought Aston Villa in 2006 and put it up for sale in 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as the "King of Diamonds," Lev Leviev owns a diamond outfit that operates in places like Angola, South Africa and Botswana. Leviev was born in Uzbekistan. His Lubavitcher Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. He made his name undercutting the De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. He owns high-end diamond jewelry boutiques in New York, London, Dubai and Singapore. Leviev is also the controlling shareholder of Africa Israel Investments, a real estate and construction company listed on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. In January 2016, Africa Israel settled with residents of three New York apartment buildings that the company had sold but failed to renovate and develop as promised. Leviev is president of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: The oil and gas bust has gutted the value of Rod Lewis' oil and gas operations on 500,000 acres in south Texas, where he's been drilling for four decades years. "We'll survive because we've rolled back our cash into the company," he says. "Reinvested in the ground." Lewis's other passion has always been airplanes. The son of an Air Force pilot, he bought his first in 1981 (an Aeronca Chief) because he was tired of driving Texas' wide-open spaces to check gauges on oil and gas wells. After a bout with esophageal cancer in 2004, he began buying up other planes in earnest. Lewis now owns two dozen Warbirds -- World War II-era planes -- including a P-51 Mustang and one of only two surviving T-6G trainer planes used by the Tuskegee airmen. His famed racer Rare Bear holds the speed record for piston-driven aircraft. He also has a B-25 bomber that he flew at an event honoring the 70th anniversary of Doolittle's raid. "But I'm just flying around," he says. "They were actually fighting, and trying to save their ass, for our country." The jewel of the collection is Glacier Girl, a P-38 Lightning dug out of the Greenland ice and restored to mint condition.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Fuchao chairs auto parts manufacturer Guilin Fuda. Li listed the company's shares on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2014. Customers include Eaton of the U.S., as well as Chinese automakers Geely Automobile Holdings and BYD.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Shaoxi chairs Guangdong Yihua Timber, a furniture supplier. The Liu family also controls Shenzhen-listed Yihua Real Estate, which changed its name to Yihua Healthcare in February 2015.  Yihua Healthcare in September 2015 said it acquired a home care products supplier and a high-end physical examination company for a total of $303 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lo Siu-tong started redeveloping old buildings in 1966 and today his Yu Tai Hing Co. owns an array of offices, residences and shops that includes the prime 100 Queen's Road Central office building. He also owns a chain of 10 budget hotels under the Bridal Tea House brand. Youngest son, Dennis Law, runs the company and is also a movie scriptwriter, producer and director.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Coal king Low Tuck Kwong's Bayan Resources controls eight mines. (His family also owns several golf resorts and an art gallery, and he recently expanded into health care with Farrer Park Hospital in Singapore in December 2014.) When his thoughts aren't down in the mines, they're on paintings and animals, having established Gunung Bayan Zoo in Indonesia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Feng leads privately held Wind Information of Shanghai, one of China's largest financial information providers. Lu owns 29% of the company, which sells financial market data and competes with Bloomberg and Reuters, among others. Xinhu Zhongbao, controlled by fellow billionaire Huang Wei, said it would pay $94 million for 1% of Wind Information last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Yonghua is the founder and chairman of Jiangsu Linyang Electronics, a supplier of electronic energy meters and power management information systems. The company was established in 1995 and trades on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lv Yongxiang chairs Shenzhen-listed Jilin Yongda Group, a supplier of magnetic switches. Lv worked for Jihua Group, owned by Petrochina, before he founded the predecessor of Yongda in 1986.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since co-founding private equity firm First Reserve in 1983, Bill Macaulay has presided over 450 transactions involving mining, solar power and insurance companies. First Reserve now has over $17 billion in assets under management. Macaulay grew up in the Bronx, studied economics at the City University of New York, and spent the 1970s in Oppenheimer's private equity business. Over the years Macaulay has given more than $30 million to fund the Macaulay Honors College at CUNY. With his wife Linda, a professional ornithologist, he has donated millions to Cornell; the Macaulay Library there now holds world's largest collection of wildlife sounds. He often carries his wife's recording equipment when the two track birds in wild. "I like bird watching," he says. "It's quiet."

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill MacMillan III is an heir to Cargill Inc, the $111 billion global food giant his great-great-grandfather W.W. Cargill founded in 1865. W.W.'s descendants still own 88% of the company, which is nothing like the business he started two and a half centuries ago. Today Cargill is a global food conglomerate with business on every continent but Antarctica. It makes its money doing everything that happens between the farm and your dinner plate. Cargill buys, transports and sells crops all over the world -- operating the world's largest fleet of ships transporting dry bulk commodities, some 550 ships stopping at 6,000 ports. It also develops ingredients, the most famous of which is its sugar alternative Truvia. It operates one of America's largest slaughterhouses, modifies food derivatives into things like asphalt and car-seat foam, offers financial risk management to farmers, makes livestock feed and processes eggs. Cargill MacMillan III does not have an active role in the business, but as one of 14 billionaire relatives who control the company, he continues to get a portion of its profits as dividends.

name: Billionaires
bio: John MacMillan and 13 other billionaire relatives control Cargill Inc., the largest private company in America. The Cargill-MacMillan clan has more billionaires than any other family in the world, Forbes has found. All are descendants of W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who founded the business as a one-grain storage warehouse at the end of an Iowa railroad line back in 1865. He made a fortune as railroads continued to push westward, opening up the stretch of land that still feeds America today. Today his company looks nothing like it did two-and-a-half centuries ago. Now it is a global food powerhouse, dominating all roads between the farm and your dinner plate. Cargill sells food, processes crops, trades commodities, sources ingredients and offers financial risk management. The family still owns 88% of the company, which distributes 20% of its earnings to shareholders.

name: Billionaires
bio: When Cargill MacMillan Jr. died in 2011, his daughter Martha MacMillan inherited an estimated 2% stake in food giant Cargill Inc. Her great-great-grandfather founded the company in 1865, and 14 of his descendants are billionaires today. Martha MacMillan does not have an active role in the company, which sells food, processes crops, trades commodities, sources ingredients and offers financial risk management. Her uncle Whitney MacMillan was the last family member to serve as CEO. Like the rest of her billionaire relatives, MacMillan lives a very private life. "They want to draw the curtain down," Cargill CEO David MacLennan told Forbes in 2014. "A lot of rich people want to be on TV, want you to know who they are and that they own this and that. Not these people."

name: Billionaires
bio: William MacMillan is one of 14 billionaire relatives who control Cargill Inc., the largest private company in America. A global food conglomerate, Cargill sells food, processes crops, trades commodities, sources ingredients and offers financial risk management. W.W. Cargill founded the company in 1865, and his descendants still own 88% of the business today. William served on Cargill's board of directors and was a staunch advocate of keeping the company private in the 1990s, according to a book on the company's history published in 2008. His father, Cargill MacMillan Jr., who died in 2011, was a senior vice president at the company; his uncle Whitney MacMillan was the last family member to serve as CEO, retiring in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Francisco Bay Area real estate broker George Marcus has been in the business since 1971, joining forces with partner William Millichap for most of those years. Most of Marcus's fortune stems from a 52% stake in Marcus & Millichap, a public real estate brokerage that closed 7,660 investment transactions in 2014 -- more than any other firm. The brokerage specializes in transactions with private clients valued at less than $10 million. Marcus also controls a 2.4% stake in Essex Property Trust, a REIT he founded that owns 57,500 apartments along the West Coast. Marcus also has a stake in several private real-estate and investment companies, including SummerHill Housing Group and Pacific Urban Residential. Previously, Marcus was a director of Plaza Commerce Bank and Greater Bay Bancorp, which sold to Wells Fargo in 2007. Marcus was reportedly born on a Greek island and immigrated to the United States when he was four. He graduated with a B.A. in economics from San Francisco State University and served on the Board of Regents of the University of California from 2000 to 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Miguel McKelvey is the other half of WeWork, the $10 billion communal work space company, cofounded in 2010 with CEO Adam Neumann. Raised in a five-mother collective in Oregon, McKelvey now serves as Chief Creative Officer directing construction, architecture and web design for the business that has raised more than $900 million from investors like Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, and Benchmark Capital and has set up offices in 78 locations in 23 cities including in the U.S., Israel, Canada and the U.K. WeWork's post-funding valuations have skyrocketed from $1.5 billion to $10 billion in little more than a year; it touts perks like arcade rooms and on-site beer kegs, and also cuts down on overhead costs for members by offering cloud computing services and health insurance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Cisco CEO John Morgridge holds most of his fortune in Cisco shares. After a stint as a Honeywell executive, he became Cisco's chief in 1988. He took the company public in 1990, stepped down in 1995 and became a billionaire the following year as the company's stock continued to climb. Morgridge and his wife, Tashia, are avid philanthropists. They have given numerous gifts to his alma maters: the University of Wisconsin, where he went for undergrad, and Stanford University, where he earned his M.B.A. Their $100 million gift to Wisconsin, announced in November 2014, is the largest gift by an individual donor in the school's history. An avid hiker, Morgridge is a former chair of the Nature Conservancy, which uses private funds to buy and protect land from development.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Masahiro Noda is chairman and CEO of publicly-traded computer system integrator and custom software maker Obic, which is known for its accounting software and its television ads featuring a kabuki actor. He began the business with his wife's savings, and grew it to its prominent position today.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peng Jianhu chairs Chongqing New Century Cruise, a China luxury cruise operator and travel agency company. He debuts on the 2016 Forbes Billionaires List after a jump in the company's stock on plans announced in October 2015 to merge with online game company Giant Interactive in an all-stock transaction. Peng graduated from Sichuan International Studies University as an English major. He worked as a tour guide in the 1980s, and has also been in the restaurant and jewelry business. Peng and son Peng Junheng owned 74.3% of the listed company after it went public in March 2011 at Shenzhen Stock Exchange; that stake will fall to 10% when the Giant transaction is finished.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mark Pincus cofounded Zynga, an online social game maker known for popular apps Words With Friends and FarmVille. Pincus stepped down as chief executive to give way to Microsoft exec. Dan Mattrick in June 2013, then returned as CEO in April 2015. A serial entrepreneur, Pincus launched a string of successful websites, including Support.com, before creating Zynga in 2007. Pincus was also an early investor in Napster, Twitter and Facebook. He made headlines in April 2012 when he sold off about 16.5 million Zynga shares in a move that was widely criticized. He was able to sell while employees were forced to hold on to their shares during the stock's steep decline in the following months. Pincus' wife, Alison, cofounded One Kings Lane, a flash sales site for home goods.
title: Chief Product Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Zynga', 'title': 'Chief Product Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with their famous sister, Alberto and Marina Prada inherited the family business founded by their grandfather in 1913. Considered fashion royalty, Miuccia Prada is the co-CEO and lead designer of the handbag and fashion empire Prada. Alberto and Marina each hold a 15% stake in the company the Pradas inherited in 1977. Their sister Miuccia met Patrizio Bertelli, who ran a luxury leather company, at a Milan trade show in 1977 and signed him on as a contractor. A year later, they were married and Bertelli joined the company, taking care of the business side of things while pushing Prada into new directions. (His stake in the company also makes him a billionaire.) In 1986 Prada opened its first store in New York and expanded beyond high-end suitcases, handbags, and steamer trunks. A few years later, they unveiled a ready-to-wear women's collection and a lower-end brand, Miu Miu. In 2011, Miuccia and Bertelli took the company public in Hong Kong; the family remains firmly in control.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with their famous sister, Alberto and Marina Prada inherited the family business founded by their grandfather in 1913. Considered fashion royalty, Miuccia Prada is the co-CEO and lead designer of the handbag and fashion empire Prada. Alberto and Marina each hold a 15% stake in the company the Pradas inherited in 1977. Their sister Miuccia met Patrizio Bertelli, who ran a luxury leather company, at a Milan trade show in 1977 and signed him on as a contractor. A year later, they were married and Bertelli joined the company, taking care of the business side of things while pushing Prada into new directions. (His stake in the company also makes him a billionaire.) In 1986 Prada opened its first store in New York and expanded beyond high-end suitcases, handbags, and steamer trunks. A few years later, they unveiled a ready-to-wear women's collection and a lower-end brand, Miu Miu. In 2011, Miuccia and Bertelli took the company public in Hong Kong; the family remains firmly in control.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Dmitry Pumpyansky has moved well beyond making pipes, the source of his wealth. Sinara Group, which he owns jointly with German industrial giant Siemens, created a joint venture that won a nearly $3 billion contract from Russian Railways to deliver modern electric trains Lastochka. In 2015 Uralskiye Locomotivy delivered first 23 Lastochkas to RZhD, and the delivery contract (it is planned to deliver 240 trains) and maintenance until 2020 were reconsidered and decreased to $1.9b due to the fall of ruble exchange rate.
His companies are also giving a facelift to a stadium that will host the 2018 World Cup in Ekaterinburg. The contract for the reconstruction of the stadium by developer division of Sinara group of companies was signed with Russian Ministry of Sport in 2015. Graduating from the Urals Polytechnic Institute with a concentration in metallurgy, Pumpyansky began as a trader, then oversaw several metals plants in the Urals during the 1990s before taking over the Sinarsky Pipe Factory. Joining hands with fellow billionaires Sergei Popov and Andrei Melnichenko, Pumpyansky became CEO of MDM Group, acquiring 35% of pipe conglomerate TMK. In full acquisition mode, MDM clashed with Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group for control of a fourth major pipe factory and won. Seeking further consolidation, Pumpyansky bought out Melnichenko and Popov in late 2006, and listed TMK on the London Stock Exchange, raising $1 billion. But, badly in need of capital, he was forced to surrender his controlling stake to state-owned banks as security for a $1.85 billion loan. Two years later, after the terms were renegotiated, Pumpyansky was back in control of TMK.

name: Billionaires
bio: Megdet Rahimkulov has been a fastidious investor who until recently ran his own diversified investment portfolio. Now his assets are   managed by a holding company based in Cyprus. In the mid-1990s he became chief executive and 10% owner of a joint venture between gas giant Gazprom and Hungary's oil and gas concern MOL. Gazprom bought a Hungarian bank, Altalanos ErtekForgalmi Bank (AEB), to process payments from its local customers; Rahimkulov headed AEB as well and later bought it from Gazprom. In 2007 he sold the bank and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, Hungary's largest bank. He also owns shares in Gazprom and VTB.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sudthida Ratanarak, the low-profile sister of Thai billionaire Krit Ratanarak, holds stakes in family's Bangkok Broadcasting & TV empire, which operates the country's leading Chanel 7 TV station. She plays no active role in any of the businesses, which her late father Chuan founded in 1969 as a cement maker.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrea Reimann-Ciardelli is a descendant of chemist Ludwig Reimann, who, in 1828, joined with Johann Adam Benckiser. Five years earlier, Benckiser had founded an eponymous chemical company. Reimann married one of his daughters and wound up owning the business, based in Ludwigshafen, Germany, after Johann's death. Great-grandson Albert Reimann Jr. took the reins after his father died in 1952, and added consumer goods. Upon Albert's death in 1984, Andrea and eight other heirs each inherited 11.1% of Luxembourg-based Investment holding JAB Holding Company s.√†.r.l (JAB). Today, JAB owns stakes in a variety of consumer products companies including Reckitt Benckiser -- a multinational (health, hygiene and home products) formed via the 1999 merger of the Reimann family business with Britain's Reckitt & Colman Ltd. -- Peet's Coffee & Tea and Coty, a maker of perfume and beauty products. Only four of the original nine Reimann heirs retain an interest in JAB. Reimann-Ciardelli, now a U.S. citizen, sold her JAB stake for close to $1 billion in 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alberto Roemmers is the head of Laboratorios Roemmers, Argentina's largest pharmaceutical company. It was founded by his father, German immigrant Alberto J. Roemmers, in 1921. The company is one of the largest players in Latin America, with operations in Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Mexico. Roemmers also owns land in Argentina's Patagonia region, as well as Arenas de Garzon, a real estate development in Uruguay where he is building a private beachfront neighborhood near the chic vacation town of Punta del Este. He collects the works of Fernando Fader, a French-born Argentine impressionist painter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arkady Rotenberg is one of the most influential businessmen in Russia. He and his billionaire brother, Boris, were once judo sparring partners with President Vladimir Putin. An ice hockey fan, he apparently still plays with Putin and is chairman of the executive board of Russian Ice Hockey Federation. The close ties with Putin made him and his brother targets of U.S. and European sanctions in 2014. The U.S. Treasury Department claimed that Putin had awarded the Rotenbergs billions of dollars in contracts with oil and gas giant Gazprom and for the Sochi winter Olympics. In September 2014, the Italian police seized millions in assets from Arkady including a luxury hotel in Rome and two villas in Sardinia. After the sanctions, Arkady transferred some assets to his son Igor, including stakes in drilling company Gazprom Bureniye, road construction company Mostotrest, and TPS Real Estate Holding. Arkady still owns Stroygazmontazh Corporation (or SGM Group), one of Russia's biggest construction contractors in the energy field. SGM Group is also building Kerch Strait bridge between Russia and Crimea peninsula. Rotenberg also holds an 80% stake in nitric fertilizer manufacturer Minudobreniya, and has an indirect stake in Sheremetyevo Airport near Moscow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boris Rotenberg and his older brother, Arkady, are the billionaires and co-owners of SMP Bank. The Rotenberg brothers were hit by U.S. sanctions and had assets frozen in 2014 because of their close ties to Putin.  The U.S. Treasury Department claimed that Putin had awarded the Rotenbergs billions of dollars in contracts with oil and gas giant Gazprom and for the Sochi Winter Olympics. Boris, unlike Arkady, was not subject to European Union sanctions because he has Finnish citizenship. Boris is vice president of the Russian Judo Federation. He sponsors the SMP Racing Project, which supports young Russian drivers. Boris's son Roman is vice-president of Russian Ice Hockey Federation and vice-president KHL's club SKA Saint Petersburg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sevket Sabanci is a second generation representative of Sabanci Holding, one of Turkey's largest holding companies; he previously served as the vice chairman of the Holding. While his brother Erol Sabanci and his family remain on the board of Akbank, Sevket Sabanci, his wife Hayirli Sabanci and their children (Ali, Emine, Sadika) have partially sold their shares of Akbank. Their family wealth comes primarily from Esas Holding which includes Turkey's largest private aviation company, Pegasus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deniz Sahenk was married to the late Ayhan Sahenk, founder of Dogus Holding, who died of a heart attack in 2001. Dogus has interests in finance, media, tourism and construction. The main source of her wealth is her stake in Garanti Bank, one of Dogus' main holdings. Her son Ferit and daughter Filiz Sahenk are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nobutada Saji is the Chairman of drinks powerhouse Suntory Holdings, which bought U.S. Beam, purveyor of Jim Beam and Maker's Mark bourbon, for $16 billion in 2014. His heir, Nobuhiro Torii, is president of Suntory Beverage & Food, the non-alcoholic drinks and food business, which was spun off as a listed entity in 2014. In December 2015, Suntory Holdings announced that Torii will become chief operating officer and executive vice president of Suntory Holdings, overseeing mid-to long-term strategy and the domestic business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Visual bookmarking site Pinterest has grown in popularity partly thanks to its chief creative officer and cofounder Evan Sharp. Sharp met Silbermann through a mutual friend when he was a student in Columbia University's architecture program and was soon invited to join Cold Brew Labs, a startup Silbermann and third Pinterest cofounder Paul Sciarra had started together. Soon after, Silbermann, Sharp and Sciarra launched the first desktop version of Pinterest in March 2010. As chief creative officer Sharp uses his architecture background to lead the front-end engineering and design divisions of Pinterest. Valued at $11 billion in 2015, the site is reportedly expecting to bring $300 million in revenue this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shen Dongri chairs China's women's clothing retailer Lancy. The Shenzhen-listed company's brands include "Lime Flare" and "Jigott."  Lancy's chain included 480 stores at the end of June 2015, some 320 of which were directly owned. Shen and his sister, Shen Jinghua, cofounded Lancy in 2006 in Beijing. He holds an EMBA from the Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business. Shen Jinghua is Lancy's general manager and holds an 8% stake; Shen Dongri owns 51%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Neil Shen was already considered one of China's most successful entrepreneurs before he entered venture capital. In 1999 Shen cofounded and served as president of Ctrip.com International, the country's largest travel booker. But his legacy may be greater as founding managing partner of Sequoia Capital China since 2005. Last year, he played a central role in the $15 billion combination of two portfolio companies, Meituan.com and Dianping Holdings, two of China's largest Internet startups. Shen, who also helped to bring LinkedIn and Airbnb to China, led his firm's investment into drone powerhouse DJI. Portfolio companies that have successfully gone public include Vipshop Holdings, Qihoo 360 Technology and e-commerce giant JD.com. Shen's best bets aren't always in tech: the one-time programming whiz in 2002 founded Homeinns Hotel Group, the first economy hotel chain in China. It went public on the Nasdaq in 2006. Shen serves as co-chairman.
title: Entrepreneur, Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Bruno Steinhoff rang the bell at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in December 2015, celebrating as the furniture manufacturer he founded in 1964 returned to Germany after 17 years on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. Steinhoff International Holdings is now Europe's second largest furniture retailer, behind Ikea. Steinhoff first started his furniture distribution business in 1964 in Westerstede, Germany. He moved into manufacturing in 1971 and in the 1980s started acquiring numerous smaller companies, forming Steinhoff International Holdings, which traded in Steinhoff's city of residence, Johannesburg, until this year. He was chairman of the company until September 2008 but still serves as the non-executive director. In late 2014 Steinhoff announced it was paying $5.7 billion for 92% of discount South African retailer Pepkor; the deal closed in early 2015.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamond tycoon Beny Steinmetz is the owner of BSGR, an embattled mining company with a heavy presence in Africa. Born and raised in Israel, Steinmetz moved to Belgium in 1978 to run his father's diamond business. He eventually became chairman of Geneva-based Steinmetz Diamond Group and sold his stake to his brother in 2014. Steinmetz's iron ore mining efforts in Guinea have erupted into a political and legal battlefield. Iron ore deposits in the west African nation's Simandou region are among the world's most promising. Steinmetz's BSGR acquired mining the rights from the late Guinean dictator Lansana Cont√© for free, after Cont√© stripped the rights from Australian mining giant Rio Tinto. In 2010, Steinmetz sold 51% of the mining rights to Brazilian multinational Vale for $2.5 billion, but as of February 2016 he's only collected $500 million. Rio Tinto sued BSGR in New York but the case was thrown out of court in November 2015. Guinea's first democratically elected president, Alpha Cond√©, decided in April 2014 to strip BSGR of its interests in the Simandou region after an inquiry determined they were illegally obtained and is in the process of auctioning them off. BSGR is asking an international tribunal to halt the proceedings and return its claim to the rights.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Indiana native started financial-software firm SS&C Technologies in 1986 with the $20,000 he had saved from his days as a KPMG executive. Ten years later, he guided the company to an IPO, as its software started to gain steam among asset managers, bankers and insurers who wanted to electronically manage their books. But the dot-com crash nearly crippled the company. "We had 610 people in June 1999. By December 2001, we had 250," said Stone. The former high school football captain doubled down, adding services such as data centers to the company's repertoire, and took the business private in 2005, selling 70% of the shares to a subsidiary of Carlyle Group for nearly $1 billion. In 2010, Stone took a resurgent SS&C public again; he remains the firm's largest individual shareholder today.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Hongbin is the founder and chairman of property developer Sunac China Holdings, one of China's largest real estate developers. Sunac is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Tianjin, and its shares trade at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.  Sun is a U.S. citizen, holds a master's degree in engineering from Tsinghua University and has completed an advanced management program at Harvard Business School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Qinghuan chairs MLS, one of China's largest makers of light-emitting diodes (LED). He became a billionaire after the company went public in February 2015 on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. In May 2015 two of its products received the U.S. government's Energy Star designation, which will help it expand overseas. Sun worked at a photoelectric equipment company in Zhongshan before founding MLS in 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yoshikazu Tanaka is the CEO of Tokyo-listed Gree, which develops free-to-play mobile and social network-based games. Tanaka founded the company in 2004 and it went public in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media shy Mehmet Sinan Tara is the CEO of one of Turkey's largest construction companies, ENKA. He took over from his billionaire father, Sarik Tara, when he was only 26 and his father was 54. ENKA does contracting, construction, energy production, real estate investment and management and is  Turkey's biggest private electricity producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Timber baron Tiong Hiew King holds forestry concessions in 16 countries. Also holds property, oil-and-gas and palm oil interests, and runs a print and digital media business for Chinese-language consumers. His four dailies comprise nearly 70% of Malaysia's Chinese newspaper sales and three-quarters of advertising revenue, but he's been in talks to pare his stake. Most valuable asset is his privately held Oregon Group, which is based in New Zealand and builds housing developments and hotels, harvests salmon and logs and manufactures plastic containers. As a teenager Tiong tapped rubber to support his poor family before building his empire. He's an avid practitioner of tai chi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financial and real estate investor Ion Tiriac pared down his portfolio selling off banking and retail stakes in order to focus on his real estate empire. He continues to hold shares in insurance and auto leasing concerns and still runs his high end car museum dedicated to cars and motorcycles from Jaguar, Bentley, Mercedes-Benz, Rolls Royce and their ilk. Tiriac competed in the 1960 Olympics as an ice hockey player and later switched to tennis, eventually coaching several tennis greats including Boris Becker, Steffi Graf and Goran Ivanisevic. Most recently he advised Romanian tennis ace Simona Halep to sign sponsorship contracts with companies like Adidas and Vodafone.

name: Billionaires
bio: In September 2015, Dutch entertainment mogul Joop van den Ende sold a 60% stake in his Stage Entertainment to private equity group CVC Capital Partners in a deal rumored to be worth $550 million. The live entertainment company that puts on around 50 plays and shows attracts 10 million visitors annually to its 21 theaters. Its U.S. division, with 12 Tony Awards under its belt, most recently brought $17.5-million musical Rocky to Broadway, but it closed in August 2014 after just six months. Van den Ende started his career as a party supply salesman. He partnered with John de Mol, also a billionaire, to create reality TV production company Endemol. The duo scored big with worldwide hit Big Brother; they sold Endemol to Spanish telecom company Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. van den Ende remains on the supervisory board of Stage Entertainment as a co-chairman following the deal with CVC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Murat Vargi is the founder of Turkey's largest cell phone operator, Turkcell. He now owns only a 0.7% stake in the company, but owes most of his assets to the success of this enterprise. He's cast his net widely investing in many different sectors ranging from shark trade to animated movie production to search engines. His latest forays include student residences and hotels, funded by the cash he obtained after selling his Turkcell shares. He is also a shareholder of one of Turkey's largest wind energy companies through his company Dost Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Vik comes from a wealthy family of fur merchants and has dabbled in everything from closed-end country funds to insurance companies and tech start-ups. He's been locked in a contentious three-year legal dispute with Deutsche Bank over an unpaid debt. In late 2013, a judge in London's high court of justice made a $250 million judgment against Vik's trading operation, which is based largely out of Vik's Connecticut home. Vik motioned for an appeal, denying any wrongdoing. His appeal was denied in January 2016 by the England and Wales Court of Appeal, who said he had to pay. Vik's lawyer has not responded to a request for comment. In 2014 Deutsche Bank started legal proceedings in New York and Connecticut to investigate his assets, to try to retrieve the debt in the U.S.. Sebastian Holdings, Vik's trading entity, has ceased its operations, but Vik has other companies, including Norway-based market-research software company Confirmit. A Norwegian who was raised in Sweden and schooled in the Canary Islands, Vik was a former golf champion at Harvard University. An avid collector of art, he has developed luxury hotel properties in Uruguay and a winery in Chile. During the first Internet bubble, Vik was behind Xcelera.com, one of the biggest dot.com boom and bust stocks of the era.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Wan Lianbu is the chairman of fertilizer and chemical producer Shandong Kingenta Ecological Engineering, which trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. The company makes controlled-release fertilizers, which it says are less harmful to the environment than traditional fertilizers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Jinshu is the chairman of chemical supplier Shandong Yuhuang Chemical Group. One of its products is isoprene, used in making synthetic rubber. Privately held, it was founded in 1986. He is behind a $1.85 billion investment in a methanol plant in Louisiana, through his Yuhuang Chemical subsidiary, which has an administrative office in Houston. Wang is a delegate to China's National People's Congress and secretary for the northeastern Chinese village of Yuhuang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Junmin chairs Xizang Haisco Pharmaceutical Group, a Tibet-based maker of anti-infective drugs and active pharmaceutical ingredients. Wang holds a bachelor's degree from Shenyang Pharmaceutical University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Wenliang chairs the privately-held China Rilin Construction Group, which holds a majority stake in Dadong Port Group, a Chinese port near North Korea. Wang sits on the board of trustees at New York University. In early 2015, The New York Times reported that Wang was the unnamed person behind a shell corporation that paid $25.6 million for three pricey condos in the exclusive Time Warner building in New York City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Shaojun chairs Longjitaihe, a privately-held real estate developer based in Hebei Province. The company's projects are mostly in smaller Chinese cities, including Qinhuangdao, Tangshan and Langfang. Wei's business partners include the government-run Hebei Port Group. Wei is a member of China's National Party Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sanford "Sandy" Weill spent decades developing his singular vision of banking. He saw it as something akin to a supermarket, a one-stop shop for any financial craving, and from that, Citigroup was created. Weill landed his first job as a Bear Stearns runner in 1955, earning $150 a week. He formed a brokerage firm with partners, built it into Shearson Loeb Rhoads, and sold it to American Express for nearly $1 billion in 1981. He later created insurance giant Travelers Group through acquisitions and merged it with Citicorp in 1998 in a $76 billion deal, making the newly-named Citigroup one of the world's largest financial services companies. He was CEO until 2003 and chairman until 2006, and the group's success landed Weill on The Forbes 400 list for many years during the 2000's. When Citigroup almost perished in the 2009 financial crisis and needed a government handout to survive, Weill fell off The Forbes 400. In 2012, Weill told CNBC that the big banks should be broken up. They weren't, obviously, but recovering Citi shares have restored his place on The Forbes Billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wu Chung-Yi is the chairman of central Taiwan auto parts maker Fine Blanking. Most of his fortune comes from selling a stake he previously owned in Hong Kong-listed beverage and instant noodle maker Tingyi in 2007. He is still a board member of Tingyi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiu Laigui worked as an equipment manager in the police department in the northeastern Chinese city of Tonghua before switching fields and helping to turn around a struggling company, which has now become his main business, Xiuzheng Pharmaceutical. Xiu's privately owned Xiuzheng Pharmaceuticals ranks as one of China's largest pharmaceutical firms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jane Yan is the CEO of China network security product supplier Beijing Venustech. Founded in 1996, the Shenzhen-listed company today employs more than a staff of 2,000. Yan is also known as Wang Jia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Luis Enrique Yarur Rey is the chairman of Banco de Credito e Inversiones (Bci), a Chilean retail and commercial bank with more than 300 branches throughout Chile and Florida. The bank was founded by the Yarur family in 1937, and today is one of Chile's largest banking institutions with more than $30 billion in assets. In 2015, Bci purchased Miami-based City National Bank of Florida for $947 million. The acquisition marked the first time a Chilean bank purchased a U.S. financial institution.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fatma Tuba Yazici and her three sons became the largest shareholders in Diler Holdings when her husband, Recep Sami Yazici, died suddenly in 2009. Diler Holding owns Diler Iron and Steel, Yazici Iron and Steel, Diler Investment Bank, and the 2,000-bed Cornelia Deluxe Hotel in Antalya. The holding also owns a port that exports to 50 countries and Atlas Energy, whose assets include thermal and hydroelectric power plants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ye Cheng chairs privately-held Shandong Landbridge Group, which is active in petrochemicals, logistics, real estate and international trade, and runs a deep-water port. Government-controlled giants Cnooc and China National Petroleum are among Landbridge's business partners. The company is also an investor in Rizhao Bank in Shandong.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zeng Kaitian became a billionaire after the company he cofounded, Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Shanghai Technology, was acquired by an autoparts supplier, Wuhu Shunrong Auto Parts, in 2015. Sanqi Interactive owns web game platforms 37.com and 6711.com. Wuhu Shunrong is now called Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Keqiang is one of the biggest shareholders in Shanghai-listed Poly Real Estate Group. The company builds and sells homes and is involved in the rental business. He also owns a stake in Qinghai Salt Lake Industry Group, a potash producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Wanzhen chairs advanced ceramics maker Chaozhou Three-Circle Group, which trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. Zhang joined the workforce at age 16 after finishing junior high school. Chaozhou Three-Circle Group was founded in 1970 as a state-owned business. The ownership was restructured in 1992, and the company today makes ceramic products for optic telecommunication, machinery, and environmental protection. Customers include advanced fuel cell maker Bloom Energy, fiber optics producer Amphenol and semiconductor firm Vishay.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparel maker Hongdou Group has come a long way since it was founded in 1957 by Zhou Yaoting's father as a cotton processing operation with three employees. Local officials forced him to merge with two other businesses into what was in effect a government-controlled collective. Over time, the family bought back government shares. Now its Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Hongdou Industrial is a large apparel designer and manufacturer. The group has added real estate holdings to its portfolio and owns the 48-story Hongdou International Plaza, one of the tallest towers in the eastern Chinese city of Wuxi. It has several other commercial and residential properties in Wuxi, Nanjing and Zhenjiang in Jiangsu Province, as well as in Donggang in northeastern Liaoning Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhuang Min chairs Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Protruly Vision Technology Group, a supplier of security and surveillance products. The company went public in March 2015 through a backdoor listing, in which it acquired a stake in a publicly-traded firm. Zhuang owns a 37% stake. A native of Guangdong Province, Zhuang graduated from Guangdong Pharmaceutical University in 1987 and holds a graduate degree from Sun Yat-sen University. Zhuang founded Protruly in 2006.
